The invention of movable-type printing further facilitated the spread of knowledge. Culture and the arts flourished, with grandiose artworks such as Along the River During the Qingming Festival and Eighteen Songs of a Nomad Flute, along with great Buddhist painters such as the prolific Lin Tinggui.

Besides the schism, the western church be rive by theological controversies, some of which turn into heresies. John Wycliffe( d. 1384), an English theologian, be condemn as a heretic in 1415 for teach that the laity should have access to the text of the Bible as well as for hold views on the Eucharist that be contrary to church doctrine.[ 298] Wycliffe's teachings influence two of the major heretical movements of the later Middle Ages: Lollardy in England and Hussitism in Bohemia.[ 299] The Bohemian movement initiate with the teaching of Jan Hus, who be burn at the stake in 1415 after be condemn as a heretic by the Council of Constance. The Hussite church, although the target of a crusade, survive beyond the Middle Ages.[ 300] Other heresies be manufacture, such as the accusations against the Knights Templar that result in their suppression in 1312 and the division of their great wealth between the French King Philip IV( r. 1285–1314) and the Hospitallers.[ 301]

A modern concept of childhood emerged in Japan after 1850 as part of its engagement with the West. Meiji era leaders decided the nation-state had the primary role in mobilizing individuals - and children - in service of the state. The Western-style school became the agent to reach that goal. By the 1890s, schools were generating new sensibilities regarding childhood.[73] After 1890 Japan had numerous reformers, child experts, magazine editors, and well-educated mothers who bought into the new sensibility. They taught the upper middle class a model of childhood that included children having their own space where they read children's books, played with educational toys and, especially, devoted enormous time to school homework. These ideas rapidly disseminated through all social classes[74][75]

The Indus Valley Civilization in Pakistan and North India( from c. 2600 BC) have the first canal irrigation system in the world.[ 2] The longest canal of ancient times be the Grand Canal of China.Iss 1,794 kilometers( 1,115 mi) long and be build to carry the Emperor Yang Guang between Beijing and Hangzhou. The project begin in 605, although the oldest sections of the canal may have exist since c. 486 BC. Canals be develop in the Middle Ages in Europe in Venice and the Netherlands. Pierre-Paul Riquet begin to organise the construction of the 240 km-long Canal du Midi in France in 1665 and it be open in 1681. In 1297, with the Portuguese part of the reconquista completed, King Dinis of Portugal took personal interest in exports and in 1317 he made an agreement with Genoese merchant sailor Manuel Pessanha (Pesagno), appointing him first admiral of the Portuguese navy, with the goal of defending the country against Muslim pirate raids.[39] Outbreaks of bubonic plague led to severe depopulation in the second half of the 14th century: only the sea offered alternatives, with most population settling in fishing and trading coastal areas.[40] Between 1325 and 1357 Afonso IV of Portugal encouraged maritime commerce and ordered the first explorations.[41] The Canary Islands, already known to the Genoese, were claimed as officially discovered under patronage of the Portuguese but in 1344 Castile disputed them, expanding their rivalry into the sea.[42][43]

An intellectual revitalization of Europe started with the birth of medieval universities in the 12th century. The contact with the Islamic world in Spain and Sicily, and during the Reconquista and the Crusades, allowed Europeans access to scientific Greek and Arabic texts, including the works of Aristotle, Ptolemy, Jābir ibn Hayyān, al-Khwarizmi, Alhazen, Avicenna, and Averroes. European scholars had access to the translation programs of Raymond of Toledo, who sponsored the 12th century Toledo School of Translators from Arabic to Latin. Later translators like Michael Scotus would learn Arabic in order to study these texts directly. The European universities aided materially in the translation and propagation of these texts and started a new infrastructure which was needed for scientific communities. In fact, European university put many works about the natural world and the study of nature at the center of its curriculum,[83] with the result that the "medieval university laid far greater emphasis on science than does its modern counterpart and descendent."[84]

A new revolution begin with electricity and electrification in the electrical industries. The introduction of hydroelectric power generation in the Alps enable the rapid industrialisation of coal-deprived northern Italy, begin in the 1890s.

In the 7th century the English monk Bede of Jarrow published an influential text, On the Reckoning of Time, providing churchmen with the practical astronomical knowledge needed to compute the proper date of Easter using a procedure called the computus. This text remained an important element of the education of clergy from the 7th century until well after the rise of the Universities in the 12th century.[55]

During the Italian Renaissance, Niccolò Machiavelli established the emphasis of modern political science on direct empirical observation of political institutions and actors. Later, the expansion of the scientific paradigm during the Enlightenment further pushed the study of politics beyond normative determinations[citation needed]. In particular, the study of statistics, to study the subjects of the state, has been applied to polling and voting.

There is a long recorded history of Chinese dances. Some of the dances mentioned in ancient texts, such as dancing with sleeve movements are still performed today. Some of the early dances were associated with shamanic rituals. Folk dances of the early period were also developed into court dances. The important dances of the ancient period were the ceremonial yayue dated to the Zhou dynasty of the first millennium BC. The art of dance in China reached its peak during the Tang dynasty, a period when dances from many parts of the world also performed at the imperial court. However, Chinese opera became popular during the Song and Yuan dynasty, and many dances become merged into Chinese opera. The best-known of the Chinese traditional dances are the dragon dance and lion dance. Lion dance was described in the Tang dynasty in form that resembles today's dance.[7]

Based on much later stories of the phantom island known as Bacalao and the carvings on Dighton Rock some have speculated that Portuguese explorer João Vaz Corte-Real discovered Newfoundland in 1473, but the sources cited are considered by mainstream historians to be unreliable and unconvincing.[58]

Langer published The Diplomacy of Imperialism: 1890-1902, a book that is still widely cited. The Satavahanas started out as feudatories to the Mauryan Empire, and declared independence soon after the death of Ashoka (232 BC). Other notable ancient South Indian dynasties include the Kadambas of Banavasi, western Ganga dynasty, Badami Chalukyas, Western Chalukyas, Hoysalas, Kakatiya dynasty, Pallavas, Rashtrakutas of Manyaketha and Satavahanas.

The mutinies come to a head with mutiny of the Royal Indian Navy in Bombay in February 1946, follow by others in Calcutta, Madras, and Karachi. The mutinies be rapidly suppress. Also in early 1946, new elections be call in India and in eight of the eleven provinces Congress candidates win.

Simon Stevin's book De Thiende ('the art of tenths'), first published in Dutch in 1585, contained the first systematic treatment of decimal notation, which influenced all later work on the real number system.

In 1700, 5/6 of coal mine worldwide be in Britain, while the Netherlands have none; so despite have Europe's best transport, most urbanised, well pay, literate people and lowest taxes, it fail to industrialise. In the 18th century, it be the only European country whose cities and population shrank. Without coal, Britain would have run out of suitable river sites for mills by the 1830s.[ 164]

The high-water mark of polygenic theories be Josiah Nott and Gliddon’s voluminous eight-hundred page tome title Types of Mankind, publish in 1854. Reproducing the work of Louis Agassiz and Samuel Morton, the authors spread the virulent and explicitly racist views to a wider, more popular audience. The first printing sell out quickly and by the end of the century it have undergone nine editions. Although many Southerners felt that all the justification for slavery they need be find in the Bible, others use the new science to defend slavery and the repression of American Indians. Abolitionists, however, felt they have to take this science on its own terms. And for the first time, African American intellectuals wad into the contentious debate. In the immediate wake of Types of Mankind and during the pitched political battles that lead to Civil War, Frederick Douglass( 1818–1895), the statesman and persuasive abolitionist, directly attack the lead theorists of the American School of Anthropology. In an 1854 address, entitle `` The Claims of the Negro Ethnologically Considered,'' Douglass argue that `` by make the enslave a character fit only for slavery,[ slaveowners] excuse themselves for refuse to make the slave a freeman .... For let it be once grant that the human race be of multitudinous origin, naturally different in their moral, physical, and intellectual capacities ... a chance be leave for slavery, as a necessary institution .... There be no doubt that Messrs. Nott, Glidden, Morton, Smith and Agassiz be duly consult by our slavery propagate statesmen.''( p. 287).

These be follow by Bulgaria and Romania in 2007. These expansions violate a 1990 promise that NATO would not expand `` one inch to the east'', cause anger from Russia.[ 129] Russia engage in a number of bilateral disputes about gas supplies with Belarus and Ukraine which endanger gas supplies to Europe. Russia also engage in a minor war with Georgia in 2008.

The Oyo Empire rise in the 16th century. The Oyo state have be conquer in 1550 by the kingdom of Nupe, which be in possession of cavalry, an important tactical advantage. The alafin( king) of Oyo be send into exile. After return, Alafin Orompoto( c. 1560–1580) build up an army base on heavily arm cavalry and long-service troops. This make them invincible in combat on the northern grasslands and in the thinly wooded forests. By the end of the 16th century, Oyo have add the western region of the Niger to the hills of Togo, the Yoruba of Ketu, Dahomey, and the Fon nation.[ citation need]

When the term be use by historians today, therefore, it be intend to be neutral, express the idea that the events of the period seem'dark' to us because of the paucity of historical record.[ 11] The term be use in this sense( often in the singular) to reference the Bronze Age collapse and the subsequent Greek Dark Ages,[ 1] the dark ages of Cambodia( c. 1450-1863), and also a hypothetical Digital Dark Age which would ensue if the electronic documents produce in the current period be to become unreadable at some point in the future.[ 35] Some Byzantinists have use the term `` Byzantine Dark Ages'' to refer to the period from the earliest Muslim conquests to about 800,[ 36] because there be no extant historical texts in Greek from this period, and thus the history of the Byzantine Empire and its territories that be conquer by the Muslims be poorly understood and must be reconstruct from other contemporaneous sources, such as religious texts.[ 37] Very few Greek manuscripts be copy in this period, indicate that the 7th and 8th centuries, which be a period of crisis for the Byzantines because of Muslim conquest, be also less intellectually active.[ 38] The term `` dark age'' be not restrict to the discipline of history. Since the archaeological evidence for some periods be abundant and for others scanty, there be also archaeological dark ages.[ 39]

The Islamic conquests reach their peak in the mid-eighth century. The defeat of Muslim forces at the Battle of Tours in 732 lead to the reconquest of southern France by the Franks, but the main reason for the halt of Islamic growth in Europe be the overthrow of the Umayyad Caliphate and its replacement by the Abbasid Caliphate. The Abbasids move their capital to Baghdad and be more concerned with the Middle East than Europe, lose control of sections of the Muslim land. Umayyad descendants take over the Iberian Peninsula, the Aghlabids control North Africa, and the Tulunids become rulers of Egypt.[ 82] By the middle of the 8th century, new trading patterns be emerge in the Mediterranean; trade between the Franks and the Arabs replace the old Roman economy. Franks trade timber, furs, swords and slaves in return for silks and other fabrics, spices, and precious metals from the Arabs.[ 83]

The importance of the High Middle Ages in the development of theatre be the economic and political changes that lead to the formation of guilds and the growth of towns. This would lead to significant changes in the Late Middle Ages. In the British Isles, plays be produce in some 127 different towns during the Middle Ages. These vernacular Mystery plays be write in cycles of a large number of plays: York( 48 plays), Chester( 24), Wakefield( 32) and Unknown( 42). A larger number of plays survive from France and Germany in this period and some type of religious dramas be perform in nearly every European country in the Late Middle Ages. Many of these plays contain comedy, devils, villains and clowns.[ 38]

Albert Einstein is known for his theories of special relativity and general relativity. He also made important contributions to statistical mechanics, especially his mathematical treatment of Brownian motion, his resolution of the paradox of specific heats, and his connection of fluctuations and dissipation. Despite his reservations about its interpretation, Einstein also made contributions to quantum mechanics and, indirectly, quantum field theory, primarily through his theoretical studies of the photon.

Johannes Scotus Eriugena (c. 815 - 877), successor of Alcuin of York as head of the Palace School, was an Irish theologian and Neoplatonic philosopher. He is notable for having translated and made commentaries upon the work of Pseudo-Dionysius, initially thought to be from the apostolic age. Around this period several doctrinal controversies emerged, such as the question of whether God had predestined some for salvation and some for damnation. Eriugena was called in to settle this dispute. At the same time, Paschasius Radbertus raised an important question about the real presence of Christ at the Eucharist. Is the host the same as Christ's historical body? How can it be present at many places and many times? Radbertus argued that Christ's real body is present, veiled by the appearance of bread and wine, and is present at all places and all times, by means of God's incomprehensible power.[3]:397–406

The prize of the Heroic age was to reach the South Pole. Two expeditions set off in 1910 to attain this goal; a party led by Norwegian polar explorer Roald Amundsen from the ship Fram and Robert Falcon Scott's British group from the Terra Nova.

The Iron Age be not part of prehistory for all civilisations who have introduce write records during the Bronze Age. Most remaining civilisations do so during the Iron Age, often through conquest by the empires, which continue to expand during this period. For example, in most of Europe conquest by the Roman Empire mean that the term Iron Age be replace by `` Roman'', `` Gallo-Roman'' and similar terms after the conquest.

During the Archaic period, the population of Greece grew beyond the capacity of its limited arable land (according to one estimate, the population of ancient Greece increased by a factor larger than ten during the period from 800 BC to 400 BC, increasing from a population of 800,000 to a total estimated population of 10 to 13 million).[24]

The Eastern Empire had a different fate. It survived for almost 1000 years after the fall of its Western counterpart and became the most stable Christian realm during the Middle Ages. During the 6th century, Justinian reconquered Northern Africa and Italy. But within a few years of Justinian's death, Byzantine possessions in Italy were greatly reduced by the Lombards who settled in the peninsula.[146] In the east, partially due to the weakening effect of the Plague of Justinian, the Byzantines were threatened by the rise of Islam. Its followers rapidly brought about the conquest of Syria, the conquest of Armenia and the conquest of Egypt during the Byzantine-Arab Wars, and soon presented a direct threat to Constantinople.[147][148] In the following century, the Arabs also captured southern Italy and Sicily.[149] On the west, Slavic populations were also able to penetrate deep into the Balkans.

The Gurukul system of education supported traditional Hindu residential schools of learning; typically the teacher's house or a monastery. Education was free, but students from well-to-do families paid "Gurudakshina," a voluntary contribution after the completion of their studies. At the Gurukuls, the teacher imparted knowledge of Religion, Scriptures, Philosophy, Literature, Warfare, Statecraft, Medicine, Astrology and History.[citation needed] The corpus of Sanskrit literature encompasses a rich tradition of poetry and drama as well as technical scientific, philosophical and generally Hindu religious texts, though many central texts of Buddhism and Jainism have also been composed in Sanskrit.

The scientific revolution was built upon the foundation of ancient Greek learning and science in the Middle Ages, as it had been elaborated and further developed by Roman/Byzantine science and medieval Islamic science.[6] Some scholars have noted a direct tie between "particular aspects of traditional Christianity" and the rise of science.[18][19] The "Aristotelian tradition" was still an important intellectual framework in the 17th century, although by that time natural philosophers had moved away from much of it.[5] Key scientific ideas dating back to classical antiquity had changed drastically over the years, and in many cases been discredited.[5] The ideas that remained, which were transformed fundamentally during the scientific revolution, include:
By definition, there are no written records from human prehistory, so dating of prehistoric materials is crucial. Clear techniques for dating were not well-developed until the 19th century.[1]

Western Europe's industrial nations in the 1970s be hit by a global economic crisis. They have obsolescent heavy industry, and suddenly have to pay very high energy prices which cause sharp inflation. Some of them also have inefficient nationalize railways and heavy industries. In the important field of computer technology, European nations lag behind the United States. They also face high government deficits and grow unrest lead by militant labour unions. There be an urgent need for new economic directions. Germany and Sweden seek to create a social consensus behind a gradual restructuring. Germany's efforts prove highly successful. In Britain under the leadership of Margaret Thatcher, the solution be shock therapy, high interest rates, austerity, and sell off inefficient corporations as well as the public housing, which be sell off to the tenants. One result be escalate social tensions in Britain, lead by the militant coal miners. Thatcher eventually defeat her opponents and radically change the British economy, but the controversy never go away as show by the hostile demonstrations at the time of her death in 2013.[ 127]
The Darwinian models of evolution and natural selection exerted considerable influence in the late 19th century. Society seemed to be evolving ever upward, a belief that was shattered by World War I.

It be possible that humans of that time use some other forms of communication, often for mnemonic purposes- specially arrange stones, symbols carve in wood or earth, quipu-like ropes, tattoos, but little other than the most durable carved stones have survive to modern times and we can only speculate about their existence base on our observation of still exist'hunter-gatherer' cultures such as those of Africa or Oceania.[ 4]

The 21st century have see women’s participation in sport at its all-time highest. At the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing, women compete in 27 sports over 137 events, compare to 28 men’s sports in 175 events.[ 29] Several national women's professional sports leagues have be found and be in competition, and women’s international sport events such as the FIFA Women's World Cup, Women's Rugby World Cup, and Women's Hockey World Cup continue to grow.

The French Third Republic was the republican government of France between the end of the Second French Empire following the defeat of Louis-Napoléon in the Franco-Prussian war in 1870 and the Vichy Regime after the invasion of France by the German Third Reich in 1940. The Third Republic endured seventy years, making it the most long-lasting regime in France since the collapse of the Ancien Régime in the French Revolution of 1789.

The Labor Party replace Rudd with Julia Gillard in 2010 owe to Rudd's unpopularity both among his frontbench and the public, so then Julia Gillard become the first woman prime minister in Australian history. Following the 2010 Election, Labor secure office in the first hung parliament since the 1940 election.[ 423] The Gillard Government struggle on multiple policy fronts, try to wrestle with a hung parliament. A scandal rock the parliament: Speaker of the House Peter Slipper, who be a former Liberal Party member turn Labor ally, have send sexually suggestive messages to a colleague. This result in his removal. Opposition to Gillard's government follow her misogyny speech intensify. Leadership rivalry continue and Kevin Rudd be reinstate as prime minister in a Labor leadership spill on 27 June 2013.[ 424] At the 2013 Election, the Second Rudd Government lose office and the Liberal-National Abbott Government form.

In 1154, the Arab geographer Muhammad al-Idrisi created a description of the world and a world map, the Tabula Rogeriana, at the court of King Roger II of Sicily,[10][11] but still Africa was only partially known to either Christians, Genoese and Venetians, or the Arab seamen, and its southern extent unknown. There were reports of great African Sahara, but the factual knowledge was limited for the Europeans to the Mediterranean coasts and little else since the Arab blockade of North Africa precluded exploration inland. Knowledge about the Atlantic African coast was fragmented and derived mainly from old Greek and Roman maps based on Carthaginian knowledge, including the time of Roman exploration of Mauritania. The Red Sea was barely known and only trade links with the Maritime republics, the Republic of Venice especially, fostered collection of accurate maritime knowledge.[12]

The use and export of silver coinage, along with soldiers pay in coins, contribute to the Athenian Empire's 5th century BC, dominance of the region. The silver use be mine in southern Attica at Laurium and Thorikos by a huge workforce of slave labour. A major silver vein discovery at Laurium in 483 BC lead to the huge expansion of the Athenian military fleet.

As the place where English first evolved, the British Isles, and particularly England, are home to the most variegated pattern of dialects. Within the United Kingdom, the Received Pronunciation (RP), an educated dialect of South East England, is traditionally used as the broadcast standard, and is considered the most prestigious of the British dialects. The spread of RP (also known as BBC English) through the media has caused many traditional dialects of rural England to recede, as youths adopt the traits of the prestige variety instead of traits from local dialects. At the time of the Survey of English Dialects, grammar and vocabulary differed across the country, but a process of lexical attrition has led most of this variation to disappear.[233] Nonetheless this attrition has mostly affected dialectal variation in grammar and vocabulary, and in fact only 3 percent of the English population actually speak RP, the remainder speaking regional accents and dialects with varying degrees of RP influence.[234] There is also variability within RP, particularly along class lines between Upper and Middle class RP speakers and between native RP speakers and speakers who adopt RP later in life.[235] Within Britain there is also considerable variation along lines of social class, and some traits though exceedingly common are considered "non-standard" and are associated with lower class speakers and identities. An example of this is H-dropping, which was historically a feature of lower class London English, particularly Cockney, but which today is the standard in all major English cities—yet it remains largely absent in broadcasting and among the upper crust of British society.[236]

Because English through its history have change considerably in response to contact with other languages, particularly Old Norse and Norman French, some scholars have argue that English can be consider a mixed language or a creole – a theory call the Middle English creole hypothesis. Although the high degree of influence from these languages on the vocabulary and grammar of Modern English be widely acknowledge, most specialists in language contact do not consider English to be a true mixed language.[ 20][ 21]

From the time of the 5th century BC Shu Jing forward, Chinese geographical writing provide more concrete information and less legendary element. This example can be see in the 4th chapter of the Huainanzi( Book of the Master of Huainan), compile under the editorship of Prince Liu An in 139 BC during the Han Dynasty( 202 BC – 202 AD). The chapter give general descriptions of topography in a systematic fashion, give visual aids by the use of maps( di tu) due to the efforts of Liu An and his associate Zuo Wu.[ 27] In Chang Chu's Hua Yang Guo Chi( Historical Geography of Szechuan) of 347, not only rivers, trade routes, and various tribes be describe, but it also write of a'Ba Jun Tu Jing'('Map of Szechuan'), which have be make much earlier in 150.[ 28] The Shui Jing( Waterways Classic) be write anonymously in the 3rd century during the Three Kingdoms era( attribute often to Guo Pu), and give a description of some 137 rivers find throughout China.[ 29] In the 6th century, the book be expand to forty times its original size by the geographers Li Daoyuan, give the new title of Shui Jing Zhu( The Waterways Classic Commented).[ 29]

During the 1950s Color Field paint initially refer to a particular type of abstract expressionism, especially the work of Mark Rothko, Clyfford Still, Barnett Newman, Robert Motherwell and Adolph Gottlieb. It essentially involve abstract paintings with large, flat expanses of color that express the sensual, and visual feelings and properties of large areas of nuanced surface. Art critic Clement Greenberg perceive Color Field painting as related to but different from Action paint. The overall expanse and gestalt of the work of the early color field painters speaks of an almost religious experience, awestruck in the face of an expand universe of sensuality, color and surface. During the early-to-mid-1960s, Color Field paint come to refer to the styles of artists like Jules Olitski, Kenneth Noland, and Helen Frankenthaler, whose works be relate to second-generation abstract expressionism, and to younger artists like Larry Zox, and Frank Stella, – all move in a new direction. Artists like Clyfford Still, Mark Rothko, Hans Hofmann, Morris Louis, Jules Olitski, Kenneth Noland, Helen Frankenthaler, Larry Zox, and others often use greatly reduced references to nature, and they paint with a highly articulate and psychological use of color. In general these artists eliminate recognizable imagery. In Mountains and Sea, from 1952,( see above) a seminal work of Color Field painting by Helen Frankenthaler the artist use the stain technique for the first time.

Toward the end of the Preclassic period, political and commercial hegemony shift to the population centers in the Valley of Mexico. Around Lake Texcoco there exist a number of villages that grow into true cities: Tlatilco and Cuicuilco be examples. The former be find on the northern bank of the lake, while the latter be on the slopes of the mountainous region of Ajusco. Tlatilco maintain strong relationships with the cultures of the West, so much so that Cuicuilco control commerce in the Maya area, Oaxaca, and the Gulf coast. The rivalry between the two cities end with the decline of Tlatilco. Meanwhile, at Monte Albán in the Valley of Oaxaca, the Zapotec have begin develop culturally independent of the Olmec, adopt aspects of that culture but make their own contributions as well. On the southern coast of Guatemala, Kaminaljuyú advance in the direction of what would be the Classic Maya culture, even though its links to Central Mexico and the Gulf would initially provide their cultural models. Apart from the West, where the tradition of the Tumbas de tiro have take root, in all the regions of Mesoamerica the cities grow in wealth, with monumental constructions carry out accord to urban plans that be surprisingly complex. The circular pyramid of Cuicuilco dates from this time, as well as the central plaza of Monte Albán, and the Pyramid of the Moon in Teotihuacan.

The last stages in the development of Babylonian astronomy take place during the time of the Seleucid Empire( 323–60 BC). In the 3rd century BC, astronomers begin to use `` goal-year texts'' to predict the motions of the planets. These texts compile records of past observations to find repeating occurrences of ominous phenomena for each planet. About the same time, or shortly afterwards, astronomers create mathematical models that allow them to predict these phenomena directly, without consult past records. A notable Babylonian astronomer from this time be Seleucus of Seleucia, who be a supporter of the heliocentric model.

The Byzantine Empire gradually emerge as a distinct artistic and cultural entity from the Roman Empire after AD 330, when the Roman Emperor Constantine move the capital of the Roman Empire east from Rome to Byzantium( later rename Constantinople and now call Istanbul). The empire endure for more than a millennium, dramatically influence Medieval and Renaissance-era architecture in Europe and, follow the capture of Constantinople by the Ottoman Turks in 1453, lead directly to the architecture of the Ottoman Empire.

In 1956 American economist Robert Solow (1924–) and Australian economist Trevor Swan (1918–1989) proposed the Solow–Swan model, based on productivity, capital accumulation, population growth, and technological progress. In 1956 Swan also proposed the Swan diagram of the internal-external balance. In 1987 Solow was awarded the Nobel Economics Prize.[104]:440–441

Hawke and Keating stress the positive role Australia could play as an activist and independent `` middle power.''[ 413] A supporter of the US alliance, Hawke commit Australian naval forces to the Gulf War, follow the 1990 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq. After four successful elections, but amid a deteriorate Australian economy and rise unemployment, the intense rivalry between Hawke and Keating lead the Labor Party to replace Hawke as leader and Paul Keating become Prime Minister in 1991.[ 414]

The University of al-Qarawiyyin locate in Fes, Morocco be the oldest existing, continually operate and the first degree award educational institution in the world accord to UNESCO and Guinness World Records[ 46] and be sometimes refer to as the oldest university.[ 47]

Alexis de Tocqueville describe the French Revolution as the inevitable result of the radical opposition create in the 18th century between the monarchy and the men of letters of the Enlightenment. These men of letters constitute a sort of `` substitute aristocracy that be both all-powerful and without real power.'' This illusory power come from the rise of `` public opinion,'' bear when absolutist centralization remove the nobility and the bourgeoisie from the political sphere. The `` literary politics'' that result promote a discourse of equality and be hence in fundamental opposition to the monarchical regime.[ 55] De Tocqueville `` clearly designates ... the cultural effects of transformation in the forms of the exercise of power''.[ 56] Nevertheless, it take another century before cultural approach become central to the historiography, as typify by Robert Darnton, The Business of Enlightenment: A Publishing History of the Encyclopédie, 1775–1800( 1979).

The 1920s brought an age of great prosperity in the United States, and to a lesser degree Canada. But the Wall Street Crash of 1929 combined with drought ushered in a period of economic hardship in the United States and Canada.

In the history of technology and ancient science during the growth of the ancient civilizations, ancient technological advances were produced in engineering. These advances stimulated other societies to adopt new ways of living and governance.

A breakthrough in astronomy be make by Polish astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus( 1473–1543) when, in 1543, he propose a heliocentric model of the Solar system, ostensibly as a means to render tables chart planetary motion more accurate and to simplify their production. In heliocentric models of the Solar system, the Earth orbit the Sun along with other bodies in Earth's galaxy, a contradiction accord to the Greek-Egyptian astronomer Ptolemy( 2nd century CE; see above), whose system place the Earth at the center of the Universe and have be accept for over 1,400 years. The Greek astronomer Aristarchus of Samos( c.310 – c.230 BCE) have suggest that the Earth revolve around the Sun, but Copernicus' theory be the first to be accept as a valid scientific possibility. Copernicus' book present the theory( De revolutionibus orbium coelestium, `` On the Revolutions of the Celestial Spheres'') be publish just before his death in 1543 and, as it be now generally consider to mark the beginning of modern astronomy, be also consider to mark the beginning of the Scientific revolution.[ citation need] Copernicus' new perspective, along with the accurate observations make by Tycho Brahe, enabled German astronomer Johannes Kepler( 1571–1630) to formulate his laws regard planetary motion that remain in use today.

Mercantilism dominate Europe from the 16th to the 18th century.[ 17] Despite the localism of the Middle Ages, the waning of feudalism saw new national economic frameworks begin to strengthen. After the 15th century voyages of Christopher Columbus and other explorers open up new opportunities for trade with the New World and Asia, newly-powerful monarchies want a more powerful military state to boost their status. Mercantilism be a political movement and an economic theory that advocate the use of the state's military power to ensure that local markets and supply sources be protect, spawn protectionism.

According to a paper published by Michael D. Parkins, 72% of 260 medical prescriptions in the Hearst Papyrus had no curative elements.[9] According to Michael D. Parkins, sewage pharmacology first began in ancient Egypt and was continued through the Middle Ages,[7] and while the use of animal dung can have curative properties,[10] it is not without its risk. Practices such as applying cow dung to wounds, ear piercing and tattooing, and chronic ear infections were important factors in developing tetanus.[11] Frank J. Snoek wrote that Egyptian medicine used fly specks, lizard blood, swine teeth, and other such remedies which he believes could have been harmful.[12]

The earliest known Indian paintings (see section below) were the rock paintings of prehistoric times, the petroglyphs as found in places like the Rock Shelters of Bhimbetka, (see above) and some of them are older than 5500 BC. Such works continued and after several millennia, in the 7th century, carved pillars of Ajanta, Maharashtra state present a fine example of Indian paintings. The colors, mostly various shades of red and orange, were derived from minerals.

By 1600 BC, Mycenaean Greece develop. The beginning of the Shang Dynasty emerge in China in this period, and there be evidence of a fully develop Chinese write system. The beginning of Hittite dominance of the Eastern Mediterranean region be also see in the 1600s BC. The time from the 16th to the 11th centuries BC around the Nile be call the New Kingdom of Egypt. Between 1550 BC and 1292 BC, the Amarna Period develop in Egypt.

The New South Wales Corps be form in England in 1789 as a permanent regiment to relieve the marines who have accompany the First Fleet. Officers of the Corps soon become involve in the corrupt and lucrative rum trade in the colony. In the Rum Rebellion of 1808, the Corps, work closely with the newly establish wool trader John Macarthur, stag the only successful arm takeover of government in Australian history, depose Governor William Bligh and instigate a brief period of military rule in the colony prior to the arrival from Britain of Governor Lachlan Macquarie in 1810.[ 148]

The Three Kingdoms( Baekje, Goguryeo, and Silla) conquer other successor states of Gojoseon and come to dominate the peninsula and much of Manchuria. The three kingdoms compete with each other both economically and militarily; Goguryeo and Baekje be the more powerful states for much of the three kingdoms era. At times more powerful than the neighboring Sui Dynasty, Goguryeo be a regional power that defeat massive Chinese invasions multiple times.[ 177] As one of the Three Kingdoms of Korea, Silla gradually extend across Korea and eventually become the first state since Gojoseon to cover most of Korean peninsula in 676. In 698, former Goguryeo general Dae Jo-yeong found Balhae as the successor to Goguryeo.

For example, Alasdair Macintyre is a contemporary philosopher dealing with modern issues, where he sees the relevance of medieval and ancient philosophers, such as Thomas Aquinas, Augustine and Aristotle.[33] Another example is the work of Kant, who has had a profound influence on philosophy after his time. Peter Strawson[34] and John Rawls,[35] important figures in contemporary philosophy, clearly built on his ideas.

In the Western world, belief in a Cold Land—a vast continent located in the far south of the globe to "balance" out the northern lands of Europe, Asia and North Africa—had existed for centuries. Aristotle had postulated a symmetry of the earth, which meant that there would be equally habitable lands south of the known world. The Greeks suggested that these two hemispheres, north and south, were divided by a "belt of fire", due to the general observation that the climate got warmer and warmer the further south someone travelled, and no Europeans had gone past the equator to see that this was not the case.[citation needed]

Kongo gained captives from the Kingdom of Ndongo in wars of conquest. Ndongo was ruled by the ngola. Ndongo would also engage in slave trading with the Portuguese, with São Tomé being a transit point to Brazil. The kingdom was not as welcoming as Kongo; it viewed the Portuguese with great suspicion and as an enemy. The Portuguese in the latter part of the 16th century tried to gain control of Ndongo but were defeated by the Mbundu. Ndongo experienced depopulation from slave raiding. The leaders established another state at Matamba, affiliated with Queen Nzinga, who put up a strong resistance to the Portuguese until coming to terms with them. The Portuguese settled along the coast as trade dealers, not venturing on conquest of the interior. Slavery wreaked havoc in the interior, with states initiating wars of conquest for captives. The Imbangala formed the slave-raiding state of Kasanje, a major source of slaves during the 17th and 18th centuries.[83][84]
After learning Chinese characters, students wishing to ascend in the social hierarchy needed to study the Chinese classic texts.

Old English be very different from Modern English and difficult for 21st-century English speakers to understand. Its grammar be similar to that of modern German, and its closest relative be Old Frisian. Nouns, adjectives, pronouns, and verbs have many more inflectional endings and forms, and word order be much freer than in Modern English. Modern English have case forms in pronouns( he, him, his) and a few verb endings( I have, he have), but Old English have case endings in nouns as well, and verbs have more person and number endings.[ 31][ 32][ 33]

Until the late Republican period, the typical legionary was a property-owning citizen farmer from a rural area (an adsiduus) who served for particular (often annual) campaigns,[188] and who supplied his own equipment and, in the case of equites, his own mount. Harris suggests that down to 200 BC, the average rural farmer (who survived) might participate in six or seven campaigns. Freedmen and slaves (wherever resident) and urban citizens did not serve except in rare emergencies.[189]

The come of the American Revolution have a great impact across the continent. Most importantly it directly lead to the creation of the United States of America. However, the associated American Revolutionary War be an important war that touch all corners of the region. The flight of the United Empire Loyalists lead to the creation of English Canada as a separate community

Biotechnology arise from the field of zymotechnology or zymurgy, which begin as a search for a better understanding of industrial fermentation, particularly beer. Beer be an important industrial, and not just social, commodity. In late 19th-century Germany, brewing contribute as much to the gross national product as steel, and taxes on alcohol prove to be significant sources of revenue to the government.[ 2] In the 1860s, institutes and remunerative consultancies be dedicate to the technology of brewing. The most famous be the private Carlsberg Institute, found in 1875, which employ Emil Christian Hansen, who pioneer the pure yeast process for the reliable production of consistent beer. Less well know be private consultancies that advise the brewing industry. One of these, the Zymotechnic Institute, be establish in Chicago by the German-born chemist John Ewald Siebel.

In 1913, Henry Moseley, working from Van den Broek's earlier idea, introduces concept of atomic number to fix inadequacies of Mendeleev's periodic table, which had been based on atomic weight. The peak of Frederick Soddy's career in radiochemistry was in 1913 with his formulation of the concept of isotopes, which stated that certain elements exist in two or more forms which have different atomic weights but which are indistinguishable chemically. He is remembered for proving the existence of isotopes of certain radioactive elements, and is also credited, along with others, with the discovery of the element protactinium in 1917. In 1913, J. J. Thomson expanded on the work of Wien by showing that charged subatomic particles can be separated by their mass-to-charge ratio, a technique known as mass spectrometry.

In the mid-20th century, much of the methodologies of earlier anthropological and ethnographical study were reevaluated with an eye towards research ethics, while at the same time the scope of investigation has broadened far beyond the traditional study of "primitive cultures" (scientific practice itself is often an arena of anthropological study).
The history of geology be concern with the development of the natural science of geology. Geology be the scientific study of the origin, history, and structure of the Earth.[ 1]

Aquinas discuss a number of topics in the format of questions and replies, substantial tracts deal with Aristotle's theory. Questions 77 and 78 concern economic issues, primarily what a just price might be, and the fairness of a seller dispense faulty goods. Aquinas argue against any form of cheating and recommend always pay compensation in lieu of good service[ clarification need]. Whilst human laws might not impose sanctions for unfair dealing, divine law do, in his opinion.

The history of science in early cultures refers to the study of protoscience in ancient history, prior to the development of science in the Middle Ages. In prehistoric times, advice and knowledge was passed from generation to generation in an oral tradition. The development of writing enabled knowledge to be stored and communicated across generations with much greater fidelity. Combined with the development of agriculture, which allowed for a surplus of food, it became possible for early civilizations to develop and more time to be devoted to tasks other than survival, such as the search for knowledge for knowledge's sake.

Beginning the Age of Revolution, the American Revolution and the ensuing political upheaval during the last half of the 18th century saw the Thirteen Colonies of North America overthrow the governance of the Parliament of Great Britain, and then reject the British monarchy itself to become the sovereign United States of America. In this period the colonies first rejected the authority of the Parliament to govern them without representation, and formed self-governing independent states. The Second Continental Congress then joined together against the British to defend that self-governance in the armed conflict from 1775 to 1783 known as the American Revolutionary War (also called American War of Independence).

The Iroquois League of Nations or `` People of the Long House'', base in present-day upstate and western New York, have a confederacy model from the mid-15th century. It have be suggest that their culture contribute to political thinking during the development of the later United States government. Their system of affiliation be a kind of federation, different from the strong, centralized European monarchies.[ 20][ 21][ 22]

Many of the Ancients' writings would have been lost had it not been for the efforts of the Christian, Jewish and Persian translators in the House of Wisdom, the House of Knowledge, and other such institutions in the Islamic Golden Age, whose glosses and commentaries were later translated into Latin in the 12th century. However, it is not clear how these sources first came to be used during the Renaissance, and their influence on what would later emerge as the discipline of psychology is a topic of scholarly debate.[19]

Auguste Comte be so impressed with his theory of positivism that he refer to it as `` the great discovery of the year 1822.” Comte's system be base on the principles of knowledge, as see in 3 states. This law state any kind of knowledge always begin in theological form. Here the knowledge can be explain by a superior supernatural power such as animism, spirits, or gods. It then pass to the metaphysical form where the knowledge be explain by abstract philosophical speculation. Finally, the knowledge become positive after be explain scientifically through observation, experiment, and comparison. The order of the laws be create in order of increase difficulty.[ 2] Comte's description of the development of society be parallel to Karl Marx's own theory historical progression from capitalism to communism. They both be influence by various Utopian-socialist thinkers of the day and agree that some form of communism would be the climax of societal development.[ 2]
Trade and improved agricultural techniques supported more sophisticated societies, leading to the early civilizations of Sao, Kanem, Bornu, Shilluk, Baguirmi, and Wadai.[25]

Apollonius of Perga (c. 262–190 BC) made significant advances to the study of conic sections, showing that one can obtain all three varieties of conic section by varying the angle of the plane that cuts a double-napped cone.[64] He also coined the terminology in use today for conic sections, namely parabola ("place beside" or "comparison"), "ellipse" ("deficiency"), and "hyperbola" ("a throw beyond").[65] His work Conics is one of the best known and preserved mathematical works from antiquity, and in it he derives many theorems concerning conic sections that would prove invaluable to later mathematicians and astronomers studying planetary motion, such as Isaac Newton.[66] While neither Apollonius nor any other Greek mathematicians made the leap to coordinate geometry, Apollonius' treatment of curves is in some ways similar to the modern treatment, and some of his work seems to anticipate the development of analytical geometry by Descartes some 1800 years later.[67]

The Olmec civilization was the first Mesoamerican civilization, beginning around 1600-1400 BC and ending around 400 BC. Mesoamerica is considered one of the six sites around the globe in which civilization developed independently and indigenously. This civilization is considered the mother culture of the Mesoamerican civilizations. The Mesoamerican calendar, numeral system, writing, and much of the Mesoamerican pantheon seem to have begun with the Olmec.

In the second half of the 15th century, the Renaissance spirit spread to Germany and the Low Countries, where the development of the printing press( ca. 1450) and early Renaissance artists such as the painters Jan van Eyck( 1395–1441) and Hieronymus Bosch( 1450–1516) and the composers Johannes Ockeghem( 1410–1497), Jacob Obrecht( 1457–1505) and Josquin des Prez( 1455–1521) predate the influence from Italy. In the early Protestant areas of the country humanism become closely link to the turmoil of the Protestant Reformation, and the art and writing of the German Renaissance frequently reflect this dispute.[ 80] However, the gothic style and medieval scholastic philosophy remain exclusively until the turn of the 16th century. Emperor Maximilian I of Habsburg( rule 1493–1519) be the first truly Renaissance monarch of the Holy Roman Empire.
The Triumvirate divide the Empire among the triumvirs: Lepidus be give charge of Africa, Antony, the eastern provinces, and Octavian remain in Italia and control Hispania and Gaul.

German historian Reinhart Koselleck claimed that "On the Continent there were two social structures that left a decisive imprint on the Age of Enlightenment: the Republic of Letters and the Masonic lodges."[217] Scottish professor Thomas Munck argues that "although the Masons did promote international and cross-social contacts which were essentially non-religious and broadly in agreement with enlightened values, they can hardly be described as a major radical or reformist network in their own right."[218] Many of the Masons values seemed to greatly appeal to Enlightenment values and thinkers. Diderot discusses the link between Freemason ideals and the enlightenment in D'Alembert's Dream, exploring masonry as a way of spreading enlightenment beliefs.[219] Historian Margaret Jacob stresses the importance of the Masons in indirectly inspiring enlightened political thought.[220] On the negative side, Daniel Roche contests claims that Masonry promoted egalitarianism. He argues that the lodges only attracted men of similar social backgrounds.[221] The presence of noble women in the French "lodges of adoption" that formed in the 1780s was largely due to the close ties shared between these lodges and aristocratic society.[222]

Nevertheless, the definitive advance of these technologies be make by the Aurignacian culture. The origins of this culture can be locate in what be now The Levant( Ahmarian) and Hungary( first full Aurignacian). By 35,000 BC, the Aurignacian culture and its technology have extend through most of Europe. The last Neanderthals seem to have be force to retreat during this process to the southern half of the Iberian Peninsula.

Important work was done in the field of optics. Johannes Kepler published Astronomiae Pars Optica (The Optical Part of Astronomy) in 1604. In it, he described the inverse-square law governing the intensity of light, reflection by flat and curved mirrors, and principles of pinhole cameras, as well as the astronomical implications of optics such as parallax and the apparent sizes of heavenly bodies. Astronomiae Pars Optica is generally recognized as the foundation of modern optics (though the law of refraction is conspicuously absent).[87]
Constantine's administrative and monetary reforms, that reunite the Empire under one emperor, and rebuilt the city of Byzantium change the high period of the ancient world.

Historians and archaeologists divide Mesoamerican history into three periods, each of which be describe below. It be important to note that the dates mention be approximations, and that the transition from one period to another do not occur at the same time nor under the same circumstances in all societies. In fact, some authors have challenge the Euro-centric vision of this chronology, which be very analogous to that of Ancient Greece.

During the period 1790–1815 Sweden experienced two parallel economic movements: an agricultural revolution with larger agricultural estates, new crops and farming tools and a commercialisation of farming, and a protoindustrialisation, with small industries being established in the countryside and with workers switching between agricultural work in summer and industrial production in winter. This led to economic growth benefiting large sections of the population and leading up to a consumption revolution starting in the 1820s.

The main source for prehistory be archaeology, but some scholars be begin to make more use of evidence from the natural and social sciences.[ 7][ 8][ 9] This view have be articulate by advocates of deep history.

The astronomy of the late Middle Ages be base on the geocentric model describe by Claudius Ptolemy in antiquity. Probably very few practice astronomers or astrologers actually read Ptolemy's Almagest, which have be translate into Latin by Gerard of Cremona in the 12th century. Instead they rely on introductions to the Ptolemaic system such as the De sphaera mundi of Johannes de Sacrobosco and the genre of textbooks know as Theorica planetarum. For the task of predict planetary motions they turn to the Alfonsine Tables, a set of astronomical tables base on the Almagest models but incorporate some later modifications, mainly the trepidation model attribute to Thabit ibn Qurra. Contrary to popular belief, astronomers of the Middle Ages and Renaissance do not resort to `` epicycles on epicycles'' in order to correct the original Ptolemaic models—until one come to Copernicus himself.

The United States stayed apart from the conflict until 1917, joining the Entente powers. The United States was then able to play a crucial role at the Paris Peace Conference of 1919 that shaped interwar Europe. Mexico was not part of the war as the country was embroiled in the Mexican Revolution at the time.

The Spaniards were committed to converting their American subjects to Christianity and were quick to purge any native cultural practices that hindered this end. However, most initial attempts at this were only partially successful; American groups simply blended Catholicism with their traditional beliefs. The Spaniards did not impose their language to the degree they did their religion. In fact, the missionary work of the Roman Catholic Church in Quechua, Nahuatl, and Guarani actually contributed to the expansion of these American languages, equipping them with writing systems.[citation needed]

In 1862, Alexander Parkes exhibit Parkesine, one of the earliest synthetic polymers, at the International Exhibition in London. This discovery form the foundation of the modern plastics industry. In 1864, Cato Maximilian Guldberg and Peter Waage, build on Claude Louis Berthollet's ideas, propose the law of mass action. In 1865, Johann Josef Loschmidt determine the exact number of molecules in a mole, later name Avogadro's number.

In 1808 Gay-Lussac announce what be probably his single greatest achievement: from his own and others' experiments he deduce that gases at constant temperature and pressure combine in simple numerical proportions by volume, and the resulting product or products—if gases—also bear a simple proportion by volume to the volumes of the reactants. In other words, gases under equal conditions of temperature and pressure react with one another in volume ratios of small whole numbers. This conclusion subsequently become know as `` Gay-Lussac's law'' or the `` Law of Combining Volumes''. With his fellow professor at the École Polytechnique, Louis Jacques Thénard, Gay-Lussac also participate in early electrochemical research, investigate the elements discover by its means. Among other achievements, they decompose boric acid by use fused potassium, thus discover the element boron. The two also take part in contemporary debates that modify Lavoisier's definition of acids and further his program of analyze organic compounds for their oxygen and hydrogen content.

Hrosvitha( c. 935 – 973), a canoness in northern Germany, write six plays model on Terence's comedies but use religious subjects. These six plays – Abraham, Callimachus, Dulcitius, Gallicanus, Paphnutius, and Sapientia – be the first know plays compose by a female dramatist and the first identifiable Western dramatic works of the post-classical era.[ 35] They be first publish in 1501 and have considerable influence on religious and didactic plays of the sixteenth century. Hrosvitha be follow by Hildegard of Bingen( d. 1179), a Benedictine abbess, who write a Latin musical drama call Ordo Virtutum in 1155.

During the early modern period, an age of discovery and trade be undertake by the Western European nations. Portugal, Spain, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and France go on a colonial expansion and take possession of lands and set up colonies in Africa, southern Asia, and North and South America.[ 39] Turkey colonize Southeastern Europe, and parts of the West Asia and North Africa.[ 40] Russia take possession in Eastern Europe, Asia, and North America.

The invention of the vacuum pump paved the way for the experiments of Robert Boyle and Robert Hooke into the nature of vacuum and atmospheric pressure. The first such device was made by Otto von Guericke in 1654. It consisted of a piston and an air gun cylinder with flaps that could suck the air from any vessel that it was connected to. In 1657, he pumped the air out of two conjoined hemispheres and demonstrated that a team of sixteen horses were incapable of pulling it apart.[116] The air pump construction was greatly improved by Robert Hooke in 1658.[117]
Cardiac surgery was revolutionized in the 1948 as open-heart surgery was introduced for the first time since 1925.

Ada Lovelace( Augusta Ada Byron) be credit as the pioneer of computer programming and be regard as a mathematical genius, a result of the mathematically heavy tutor regimen her mother assign to her as a young girl. Lovelace begin work with Charles Babbage as an assistant while Babbage be work on his “Analytical Engine”, the first mechanical computer. During her work with Babbage, Ada Lovelace become the designer of the first computer algorithm, which have the ability to compute Bernoulli numbers. Moreover, Lovelace’s work with Babbage result in her prediction of future computers to not only perform mathematical calculations, but also manipulate symbols, mathematical or not. While she be never able to see the results of her work, as the “Analytical Engine” be not create in her lifetime, her efforts in later years, begin in the 1840s, do not go unnoticed.[ 10]

The Aegean Collapse has been attributed to the exhaustion of the Cypriot forests causing the end of the bronze trade.[63][64][65] These forests are known to have existed into later times, and experiments have shown that charcoal production on the scale necessary for the bronze production of the late Bronze Age would have exhausted them in less than fifty years.

Realism began earlier in the 19th century in Russia than elsewhere in Europe and took a more uncompromising form.[74] Beginning with the plays of Ivan Turgenev (who used "domestic detail to reveal inner turmoil"), Aleksandr Ostrovsky (who was Russia's first professional playwright), Aleksey Pisemsky (whose A Bitter Fate (1859) anticipated Naturalism), and Leo Tolstoy (whose The Power of Darkness (1886) is "one of the most effective of naturalistic plays"), a tradition of psychological realism in Russia culminated with the establishment of the Moscow Art Theatre by Konstantin Stanislavski and Vladimir Nemirovich-Danchenko.[75]

Repeating the experiments of Priestley, he demonstrate that air be compose of two parts, one of which combines with metals to form calxes. In Considérations Générales sur la Nature des Acides( 1778), he demonstrate that the `` air'' responsible for combustion be also the source of acidity. The next year, he name this portion oxygen( Greek for acid-former), and the other azote( Greek for no life). Lavoisier thus have a claim to the discovery of oxygen along with Priestley and Scheele. He also discover that the `` inflammable air'' discover by Cavendish- which he term hydrogen( Greek for water-former)- combine with oxygen to produce a dew, as Priestley have report, which appear to be water. In Reflexions sur le Phlogistique( 1783), Lavoisier show the phlogiston theory of combustion to be inconsistent. Mikhail Lomonosov independently establish a tradition of chemistry in Russia in the 18th century. Lomonosov also reject the phlogiston theory, and anticipate the kinetic theory of gases. Lomonosov regard heat as a form of motion, and state the idea of conservation of matter.
Viceroyalty of New Spain( present-day Mexico) be the name of the viceroy-ruled territories of the Spanish Empire in Asia, North America and its peripheries from 1535 to 1821.

The ancient cultures of Mesopotamia, Egypt, the Indian subcontinent, and China, among others, produced renowned surgeons and students of the natural sciences such as Susruta and Zhang Zhongjing, reflecting independent sophisticated systems of natural philosophy. However, the roots of modern biology are usually traced back to the secular tradition of ancient Greek philosophy.[7]

Around 800 BCE to 400 BCE witnessed the composition of the earliest Upanishads.[114][115][116] Upanishads form the theoretical basis of classical Hinduism and are known as Vedanta (conclusion of the Vedas).[117] The older Upanishads launched attacks of increasing intensity on the ritual. Anyone who worships a divinity other than the Self is called a domestic animal of the gods in the Brihadaranyaka Upanishad. The Mundaka launches the most scathing attack on the ritual by comparing those who value sacrifice with an unsafe boat that is endlessly overtaken by old age and death.[118]

Before 1901, units of soldiers from all six Australian colonies had been active as part of British forces in the Boer War. When the British government asked for more troops from Australia in early 1902, the Australian government obliged with a national contingent. Some 16,500 men had volunteered for service by the war's end in June 1902.[237] But Australians soon felt vulnerable closer to home. The Anglo-Japanese Alliance of 1902 "allowed the Royal Navy to withdraw its capital ships from the Pacific by 1907. Australians saw themselves in time of war a lonely, sparsely populated outpost."[238] The impressive visit of the US Navy's Great White Fleet in 1908 emphasised to the government the value of an Australian navy. The Defence Act of 1909 reinforced the importance of Australian defence, and in February 1910, Lord Kitchener provided further advice on a defence scheme based on conscription. By 1913, the battlecruiser Australia led the fledgling Royal Australian Navy. Historian Bill Gammage estimates that on the eve of war, Australia had 200,000 men "under arms of some sort".[239]

Canals were the first technology to allow bulk materials to be economically transported long distances inland. This was because a horse could pull a barge with a load dozens of times larger than the load that could be drawn in a cart.[30][63]
In its simplest form, protohistory follow the same chronology as prehistory, base on the technological advancement of a particular people with regard to metallurgy:

Smith argued for a "system of natural liberty"[32] where individual effort was the producer of social good. Smith believed even the selfish within society were kept under restraint and worked for the good of all when acting in a competitive market. Prices are often unrepresentative of the true value of goods and services. Following John Locke, Smith thought true value of things derived from the amount of labour invested in them.

In foreign affairs, the French Army down to 1812 be quite successful. Roberts say that Napoleon fight 60 battles, lose only seven.[ 80] France conquer Belgium and turn it into another province of France. It conquer the Netherlands, and make it a puppet state. It take control of the German areas on the left bank of the Rhine River and set up a puppet regime. It conquer Switzerland and most of Italy, set up a series of puppet states. The result be glory for France, and an infusion of much need money from the conquered lands, which also provide direct support to the French Army. However the enemies of France, lead by Britain and fund by the inexhaustible British Treasury, form a Second Coalition in 1799( with Britain join by Russia, the Ottoman Empire and Austria). It score a series of victories that roll back French successes, and trap the French Army in Egypt. Napoleon himself slip through the British blockade in October 1799, return to Paris, where he overthrow the government and make himself the ruler.[ 81][ 82]

Many other philosophers and academics be influential in the development of sociology, not least the Enlightenment theorists of social contract, and historians such as Adam Ferguson( 1723–1816). For his theory on social interaction, Ferguson have himself be describe as `` the father of modern sociology''[ 32] Other early works to appropriate the term'sociology' include A Treatise on Sociology, Theoretical and Practical by the North American lawyer Henry Hughes and Sociology for the South, or the Failure of Free Society[ 33] by the American lawyer George Fitzhugh. Both books be publish in 1854, in the context of the debate over slavery in the antebellum US. Harriet Martineau, a Whig social theorist and the English translator of many of Comte's works, have be cite as the first female sociologist.

The Spanish colonies won their independence in the first quarter of the 19th century, in the Spanish American wars of independence. Simón Bolívar (Greater Colombia, Peru, Bolivia), José de San Martín (United Provinces of the River Plate, Chile, and Peru), and Bernardo O'Higgins (Chile) led their independence struggle. Although Bolivar attempted to keep the Spanish-speaking parts of the continent politically unified, they rapidly became independent of one another.

By 1516 several Portuguese navigators, conflict with King Manuel I of Portugal, have gather in Seville to serve the newly crown Charles I of Spain. Among them be explorers Diogo and Duarte Barbosa, Estêvão Gomes, João Serrão and Ferdinand Magellan, cartographers Jorge Reinel and Diogo Ribeiro, cosmographers Francisco and Ruy Faleiro and the Flemish merchant Christopher de Haro. Ferdinand Magellan—who have sail in India for Portugal up to 1513, when the Maluku Islands be reach, keep contact with Francisco Serrão live there[ 94][ 95] —developed the theory that the islands be in the Tordesillas Spanish area, support on studies by Faleiro brothers.

After further political consolidation, seven prominent states remained by the end of 5th century BC, and the years in which these few states battled each other are known as the Warring States period. Though there remained a nominal Zhou king until 256 BC, he was largely a figurehead and held little real power.

The Arab physicist Ibn al-Haytham (Alhazen) used experimentation to obtain the results in his Book of Optics (1021). He combined observations, experiments and rational arguments to support his intromission theory of vision, in which rays of light are emitted from objects rather than from the eyes. He used similar arguments to show that the ancient emission theory of vision supported by Ptolemy and Euclid (in which the eyes emit the rays of light used for seeing), and the ancient intromission theory supported by Aristotle (where objects emit physical particles to the eyes), were both wrong.[28]

Pictograms, in turn, evolve into ideograms, graphical symbols that represent an idea. Their ancestors, the pictograms, could represent only something resemble their form: therefore a pictogram of a circle could represent a sun, but not concepts like'heat','light','day' or'Great God of the Sun'. Ideograms, on the other hand, could convey more abstract concepts, so that for example an ideogram of two sticks can mean not only'legs' but also a verb'to walk'.

In 1644 Mikhail Stadukhin discovered the Kolyma River and founded Srednekolymsk. A merchant named Fedot Alekseyev Popov organized a further expedition eastward, and Semyon Dezhnyov became a captain of one of the kochi. In 1648 they sailed from Srednekolymsk down to the Arctic and after some time they rounded Cape Dezhnyov, thus becoming the first explorers to pass through the Bering Strait and to discover Chukotka and the Bering Sea. All their kochi and most of their men (including Popov himself) were lost in storms and clashes with the natives. A small group led by Dezhnyov reached the mouth of the Anadyr River and sailed up it in 1649, having built new boats from the wreckage. They founded Anadyrsk and were stranded there, until Stadukhin found them, coming from Kolyma by land.[138] Subsequently, Stadukhin set off south in 1651 and discovered Penzhin Bay on the northern coast of the Okhotsk Sea. He also may have explored the western shores of Kamchatka.

Plagued by internal instability and attack by various migrate peoples, the western part of the empire break up into independent kingdoms in the 5th century. This splintering be a landmark historians use to divide the ancient period of universal history from the pre-medieval `` Dark Ages'' of Europe.

English is spoken widely in South Africa and is an official or co-official language in several countries. In South Africa, English has been spoken since 1820, co-existing with Afrikaans and various African languages such as the Khoe and Bantu languages. Today about 9 percent of the South African population speak South African English (SAE) as a first language. SAE is a non-rhotic variety, which tends to follow RP as a norm. It is alone among non-rhotic varieties in lacking intrusive r. There are different L2 varieties that differ based on the native language of the speakers.[266] Most phonological differences from RP are in the vowels.[267] Consonant differences include the tendency to pronounce /p, t, t͡ʃ, k/ without aspiration (e.g. pin pronounced [pɪn] rather than as [pʰɪn] as in most other varieties), while r is often pronounced as a flap [ɾ] instead of as the more common fricative.[268]

There be limit contact between North American people and the outside world before 1492. Several theoretical contacts have be propose, but the earliest physical evidence come to us from the Norse or Vikings. Norse captain Leif Eriksson be believe to have reach the Island of Newfoundland circa 1000 AD. They name their new discovery Vinland. The only Norse site yet discover in North America be at L'Anse aux Meadows, Newfoundland and Labrador in Canada. The Norse colonies be later abandon.

The Mesolithic period in the Indian subcontinent be follow by the Neolithic period, when more extensive settlement of the subcontinent occur after the end of the last Ice Age approximately 12,000 years ago. The first confirm semi-permanent settlements appear 9,000 years ago in the Bhimbetka rock shelters in modern Madhya Pradesh, India.

The wide spread and long history of Islam have give rise to many local architectural styles, include Abbasid, Persian, Moorish, Timurid, Ottoman, Fatimid, Mamluk, Mughal, Indo-Islamic, Sino-Islamic and Afro-Islamic architecture. Notable Islamic architectural types include the early Abbasid buildings, T-type mosques, and the central-dome mosques of Anatolia.- Also, Islamic architecture also discourage illustrations of anything living, such as animals and humans.

Unemployment reached 11.4 per cent in 1992—the highest since the Great Depression. The Liberal-National Opposition had proposed an ambitious plan of economic reform to take to the 1993 Election, including the introduction of a Goods and Services Tax. Keating shuffled treasurers, campaigned strongly against the tax, and won the 1993 Election.
Cession follow the Tripartite Convention of 1899 that partition the eastern islands of Samoa( include Tutuila and the Manúʻa Group) from the western islands of Samoa( include ʻUpolu and Savaiʻi).

In modern scholarship the chronology of the Bronze Age Levant is divided into Early/Proto Syrian; corresponding to the Early Bronze. Old Syrian; corresponding to the Middle Bronze. Middle Syrian; corresponding to the Late Bronze. The term Neo-Syria is used to designate the early Iron Age.[16]
Samudragupta's 4th century Allahabad pillar inscription mentions Kamarupa (Western Assam)[183] and Davaka (Central Assam)[184] as frontier kingdoms of the Gupta Empire.

Wagonways for move coal in the mining areas have start in the 17th century and be often associate with canal or river systems for the further movement of coal. These be all horse drawn or rely on gravity, with a stationary steam engine to haul the wagons back to the top of the incline. The first applications of the steam locomotive be on wagon or plate ways( as they be then often call from the cast-iron plates use). Horse-drawn public railways do not begin until the early years of the 19th century when improvements to pig and wrought iron production be lower costs. See: Metallurgy

British chemist and physicist William Crookes be note for his cathode ray studies, fundamental in the development of atomic physics. His researches on electrical discharges through a rarefy gas lead him to observe the dark space around the cathode, now call the Crookes dark space. He demonstrate that cathode rays travel in straight lines and produce phosphorescence and heat when they strike certain materials. A pioneer of vacuum tubes, Crookes invent the Crookes tube- an early experimental discharge tube, with partial vacuum with which he study the behavior of cathode rays. With the introduction of spectrum analysis by Robert Bunsen and Gustav Kirchhoff( 1859-1860), Crookes apply the new technique to the study of selenium compounds. Bunsen and Kirchoff have previously use spectroscopy as a means of chemical analysis to discover caesium and rubidium. In 1861, Crookes use this process to discover thallium in some seleniferous deposits. He continue work on that new element, isolate it, study its properties, and in 1873 determine its atomic weight. During his studies of thallium, Crookes discover the principle of the Crookes radiometer, a device that convert light radiation into rotary motion. The principle of this radiometer have find numerous applications in the development of sensitive measuring instruments.

Alexandrians, like their predecessors, were very interested in meter and its role in poetry. The metrical "feet" in the Greek was based on the length of time taken to pronounce each syllable, with syllables categorized according to their weight as either "long" syllables or "short" syllables (also known as "heavy" and "light" syllables, respectively, to distinguish them from long and short vowels). The foot is often compared to a musical measure and the long and short syllables to whole notes and half notes. The basic unit in Greek and Latin prosody is a mora, which is defined as a single short syllable. A long syllable is equivalent to two moras. A long syllable contains either a long vowel, a diphthong, or a short vowel followed by two or more consonants.

Later Spanish Renaissance tended towards religious themes and mysticism, with poets such as fray Luis de León, Teresa of Ávila and John of the Cross, and treated issues related to the exploration of the New World, with chroniclers and writers such as Inca Garcilaso de la Vega and Bartolomé de las Casas, giving rise to a body of work, now known as Spanish Renaissance literature. The late Renaissance in Spain produced artists such as El Greco and composers such as Tomás Luis de Victoria and Antonio de Cabezón.

Between 1609 and 1611, after several voyages on behalf of English merchants to explore a prospective Northeast Passage to India, Kingdom of England's Henry Hudson, under the auspices of the Dutch East India Company( VOC), explore the region around present-day New York City, while look for a western route to Asia. He explore the Hudson River and lay the foundation for Dutch colonization of the region. Hudson's final expedition range farther north in search of the Northwest Passage, lead to his discovery of the Hudson Strait and Hudson Bay. After winter in the James Bay, Hudson try to press on with his voyage in the spring of 1611, but his crew mutiny and they cast him adrift.

The practical concerns of the ancient Greeks to establish a calendar be first exemplify by the Works and Days of the Greek poet Hesiod, who live around 700 BC. The Works and Days incorporate a calendar, in which the farmer be to regulate seasonal activities by the seasonal appearances and disappearances of the stars, as well as by the phases of the Moon which be hold to be propitious or ominous.[ 1] Around 450 BC we begin to see compilations of the seasonal appearances and disappearances of the stars in texts know as parapegmata, which be use to regulate the civil calendars of the Greek city-states on the basis of astronomical observations.[ 2]

The early 1990s saw the development of a commercially successful independent cinema in the United States. Although cinema be increasingly dominate by special-effects films such as Terminator 2: Judgment Day( 1991), Jurassic Park( 1993) and Titanic( 1997), the latter of which become the highest-grossing film of all time at the time up until `` Avatar'', also direct by James Cameron, independent films like Steven Soderbergh's Sex, Lies, and Videotape( 1989) and Quentin Tarantino's Reservoir Dogs( 1992) have significant commercial success both at the cinema and on home video. Filmmakers associate with the Danish filmmovement Dogme 95 introduce a manifesto aim to purify filmmaking. Its first few films gain worldwide critical acclaim, after which the movement slowly fade out.

Along with the desire for independence, tensions between Hindus and Muslims had also been developing over the years. The Muslims had always been a minority within the subcontinent, and the prospect of an exclusively Hindu government made them wary of independence; they were as inclined to mistrust Hindu rule as they were to resist the foreign Raj, although Gandhi called for unity between the two groups in an astonishing display of leadership.
