In the 1830s in Italy, Agostino Bassi trace the silkworm disease muscardine to microorganisms. Meanwhile, in Germany, Theodor Schwann lead researches on alcoholic fermentation by yeast and propose that they be alive—that be, microorganisms—a claim deride by lead chemists, such as Justus von Liebig, seek solely physicochemical explanation, and allege that Schwann's be regress to vitalism. In 1847 in Vienna, Ignaz Semmelweis( 1818–1865), by require physicians to clean their hands before attend childbirth, dramatically cut new mothers' death rate due to childbed fever, yet his principles be marginalize and attack by professional peers.

From the late 18th century to the mid-19th century, large areas of India were annexed by the British East India Company of the British Empire. Dissatisfaction with Company rule led to the Indian Rebellion of 1857, after which the British provinces of India were directly administered by the British Crown and witnessed a period of prolonged economic stagnation and major famines.[26][27] During the first half of the 20th century, a nationwide struggle for independence was launched with the leading party involved being the Indian National Congress which was later joined by other organisations. The subcontinent gained independence from the United Kingdom in 1947, after the British provinces were partitioned into the dominions of India and Pakistan and the princely states all acceded to one of the new states.

During the later Roman Empire, the principal military developments were attempts to create an effective cavalry force as well as the continued development of highly specialised types of troops. The creation of heavily armoured cataphract-type soldiers as cavalry was an important feature of the 5th-century Roman military. The various invading tribes had differing emphasis on types of soldiers—ranging from the primarily infantry Anglo-Saxon invaders of Britain to the Vandals and Visigoths, who had a high proportion of cavalry in their armies.[145] During the early invasion period, the stirrup had not been introduced into warfare, which limited the usefulness of cavalry as shock troops because it was not possible to put the full force of the horse and rider behind blows struck by the rider.[146] The greatest change in military affairs during the invasion period was the adoption of the Hunnic composite bow in place of the earlier, and weaker, Scythian composite bow.[147] Another development was the increasing use of longswords[148] and the progressive replacement of scale armour by mail armour and lamellar armour.[149]

"By the mid-1890s the four "Maxwell equations" were recognized as the foundation of one of the strongest and most successful theories in all of physics; they had taken their place as companions, even rivals, to Newton's laws of mechanics. The equations were by then also being put to practical use, most dramatically in the emerging new technology of radio communications, but also in the telegraph, telephone, and electric power industries."[20] By the end of the 19th century, figures in the progress of electrical engineering were beginning to emerge.[21]

Liberalism and democracy be discredit. In most of Europe, as well as in Japan and most of Latin America, nation after nation turn to dictators and authoritarian regimes. The most momentous change of government come when Hitler and his Nazis take power in Germany in 1933. A major civil war take place in Spain, with the nationalists win. The League of Nations be helpless as Italy conquer Ethiopia and Japan seize Manchuria in 1931 and take over most of China start in 1937.[ 118]

The Café Procope be establish in Paris in 1686; by the 1720s there be around 400 cafés in the city. The Café Procope in particular become a center of Enlightenment, welcome such celebrities as Voltaire and Rousseau. The Café Procope be where Diderot and D'Alembert decide to create the Encyclopédie.[ 198] The cafés be one of the various `` nerve centers'' for bruits publics, public noise or rumour. These bruits be allegedly a much better source of information than be the actual newspapers available at the time.[ 199]

The Bengal School's influence in India decline with the spread of modernist ideas in the 1920s. In the post-independence period, Indian artists show more adaptability as they borrow freely from european styles and amalgamate them freely with the Indian motifs to new forms of art. While artists like Francis Newton Souza and Tyeb Mehta be more western in their approach, there be others like Ganesh Pyne and Maqbool Fida Husain who develop thoroughly indigenous styles of work. Today after the process of liberalization of market in India, the artists be experience more exposure to the international art-scene which be help them in emerge with newer forms of art which be hitherto not see in India. Jitish Kallat have shoot to fame in the late 1990s with his paintings which be both modern and beyond the scope of generic definition. However, while artists in India in the new century be try out new styles, themes and metaphors, it would not have be possible to get such quick recognition without the aid of the business houses which be now enter the art field like they have never before.

Another factor for the industry's move west was that up until 1913, most American film production was still carried out around New York, but due to the monopoly of Thomas A. Edison, Inc.'s film patents and its litigious attempts to preserve it, many filmmakers moved to Southern California, starting with Selig in 1909. The sunshine and scenery was important for the production of Westerns, which came to form a major American film genre with the first cowboy stars, G.M. Anderson ("Broncho Billy") and Tom Mix. Selig pioneered the use of (fairly) wild animals from a zoo for a series of exotic adventures, with the actors being menaced or saved by the animals. Kalem Company sent film crews to places in America and abroad to film stories in the actual places they were supposed to have happened. Kalem also pioneered the female action heroine from 1912, with Ruth Roland playing starring roles in their Westerns.

As a result of the three Carnatic Wars, the British East India Company gained exclusive control over the entire Carnatic region of India.[345] The Company soon expanded its territories around its bases in Bombay and Madras; the Anglo-Mysore Wars (1766–1799) and later the Anglo-Maratha Wars (1772–1818) led to control of the vast regions of India. Ahom Kingdom of North-east India first fell to Burmese invasion and then to British after Treaty of Yandabo in 1826. Punjab, North-West Frontier Province, and Kashmir were annexed after the Second Anglo-Sikh War in 1849; however, Kashmir was immediately sold under the Treaty of Amritsar to the Dogra Dynasty of Jammu and thereby became a princely state. The border dispute between Nepal and British India, which sharpened after 1801, had caused the Anglo-Nepalese War of 1814–16 and brought the defeated Gurkhas under British influence. In 1854, Berar was annexed, and the state of Oudh was added two years later.

Hegel's work was carried in many directions by his followers and critics. Karl Marx appropriated both Hegel's philosophy of history and the empirical ethics dominant in Britain, transforming Hegel's ideas into a strictly materialist form, setting the grounds for the development of a science of society. Søren Kierkegaard, in contrast, dismissed all systematic philosophy as an inadequate guide to life and meaning. For Kierkegaard, life is meant to be lived, not a mystery to be solved. Arthur Schopenhauer took idealism to the conclusion that the world was nothing but the futile endless interplay of images and desires, and advocated atheism and pessimism. Schopenhauer's ideas were taken up and transformed by Nietzsche, who seized upon their various dismissals of the world to proclaim "God is dead" and to reject all systematic philosophy and all striving for a fixed truth transcending the individual. Nietzsche found in this not grounds for pessimism, but the possibility of a new kind of freedom.

Various rules of elision sometimes prevent a grammatical syllable from make a full syllable, and certain other lengthening and shortening rules( such as correption) can create long or short syllables in contexts where one would expect the opposite. The most important Classical meter as define by the Alexandrian grammarians be the dactylic hexameter, the meter of Homeric poetry. This form use verses of six feet. The first four feet be normally dactyls, but can be spondees. The fifth foot be almost always a dactyl. The sixth foot be either a spondee or a trochee. The initial syllable of either foot be call the ictus, the basic `` beat'' of the verse. There be usually a caesura after the ictus of the third foot.

Sometime between 1300 and 1400 CE, Kongolo Mwamba( Nkongolo) from the Balopwe clan unify the various Luba peoples, near Lake Kisale. He found the Kongolo Dynasty, which be later oust by Kalala Ilunga. Kalala expand the kingdom west of Lake Kisale. A new centralize political system of spiritual kings( balopwe) with a court council of head governors and sub-heads all the way to village heads. The balopwe be the direct communicator with the ancestral spirits and choose by them. Conquered states be integrate into the system and represent in the court, with their titles. The authority of the balopwe reside in his spiritual power rather than his military authority. The army be relatively small. The Luba be able to control regional trade and collect tribute for redistribution. Numerous offshoot states be form with founders claim descent from the Luba. The Luba political system spread throughout Central Africa, southern Uganda, Rwanda, Burundi, Malawi, Zambia, Zimbabwe, and the western Congo. Two major empires claim Luba descent be the Lunda Empire and Maravi Empire. The Bemba people of northern Zambia be descend from Luba migrants who arrive in Zambia during the 17th century.[ 75][ 76]

The towns of Roman North Africa had a substantial Jewish population. Some Jews had been deported from Judea or Palestine in the 1st and 2nd centuries CE for rebelling against Roman rule; others had come earlier with Punic settlers. In addition, a number of Berber tribes had converted to Judaism.[citation needed]

Education remain mostly focus on the training of future clergy. The basic learning of the letters and numbers remain the province of the family or a village priest, but the secondary subjects of the trivium—grammar, rhetoric, logic—were study in cathedral schools or in schools provide by cities. Commercial secondary schools spread, and some Italian towns have more than one such enterprise. Universities also spread throughout Europe in the 14th and 15th centuries. Lay literacy rates rise, but be still low; one estimate give a literacy rate of ten per cent of males and one per cent of females in 1500.[ 305]

By about 1910, actors begin to receive screen credit for their roles, and the way to the creation of film stars be open. Films be increasingly longer, and begin to feature proper plots and development.

Goldsmiths in England have be craftsmen, bullion merchants, money changers and money lenders since the 16th century. But they be not the first to act as financial intermediates; in the early 17th century, the scriveners be the first to keep deposits for the express purpose of relending them.[ 78] Merchants and traders have amass huge hoards of gold and entrust their wealth to the Royal Mint for storage. In 1640 King Charles I seize the private gold store in the mint as a forced loan( which be to be pay back over time). Thereafter merchants prefer to store their gold with the goldsmiths of London, who possess private vaults, and charge a fee for that service. In exchange for each deposit of precious metal, the goldsmiths issue receipts certify the quantity and purity of the metal they hold as a bailee( i.e. in trust). These receipts could not be assign( only the original depositor could collect the stored goods). Gradually the goldsmiths take over the function of the scriveners of relending on behalf of a depositor and also develop modern banking practices; promissory notes be issue for money deposit which by custom and/or law be a loan to the goldsmith,[ 79] i.e. the depositor expressly allow the goldsmith to use the money for any purpose include advances to his customers. The goldsmith charge no fee, or even pay interest on these deposits. Since the promissory notes be payable on demand, and the advances( loans) to the goldsmith's customers be repayable over a longer time period, this be an early form of fractional reserve banking. The promissory notes develop into an assignable instrument, which could circulate as a safe and convenient form of money back by the goldsmith's promise to pay.[ 80] Hence goldsmiths could advance loans in the form of gold money, or in the form of promissory notes, or in the form of check accounts.[ 81] Gold deposits be relatively stable, often remain with the goldsmith for years on end, so there be little risk of default so long as public trust in the goldsmith's integrity and financial soundness be maintain. Thus, the goldsmiths of London become the forerunners of British banking and prominent creators of new money base on credit.

Clyfford Still, Barnett Newman,( see above), Adolph Gottlieb, and the serenely shimmer blocks of color in Mark Rothko's work( which be not what would usually be call expressionist and which Rothko deny be abstract), be classify as abstract expressionists, albeit from what Clement Greenberg term the Color Field direction of abstract expressionism. Both Hans Hofmann( see gallery) and Robert Motherwell( gallery) can be comfortably describe as practitioners of action painting and Color Field painting.

The relative sophistication of this piece be not follow up for some time, with subsequent works in animation be limit to short, two or three frame effects, such as appear in Edwin Stanton Porter's 1902 short `` Fun in a Bakery Shop'', where a lump of dough be make to smile over the course of a three-frame sequence. Works rival the British short in length do not appear until 1905, when Edwin Porter make How Jones Lost His Roll, and The Whole Dam Family and the Dam Dog. Both of these films have intertitles which be form by the letters move into place from a random scatter to form the words of the titles. This be do by expose the film one frame at a time, and move the letters a little bit towards their final position between each exposure. This be what have come to be call `` single frame animation'' or `` object animation'', and it need a slightly adapt camera that expose only one frame for each turn of the crank handle, rather than the usual eight frames per turn.

After Hadrian's death at 138, his successor Antoninus Pius build temples, theaters, and mausoleums, promote the arts and sciences, and bestow honours and financial rewards upon the teachers of rhetoric and philosophy. Antoninus make few initial changes when he become emperor, leave intact as far as possible the arrangements institute by Hadrian. Antoninus expand the Roman Britain by invade southern Scotland and build the Antonine Wall.[ 104] He also continue Hadrian's policy of humanize the laws. He die in 161 AD.

The first years of the 14th century were marked by famines, culminating in the Great Famine of 1315–17.[257] The causes of the Great Famine included the slow transition from the Medieval Warm Period to the Little Ice Age, which left the population vulnerable when bad weather caused crop failures.[258] The years 1313–14 and 1317–21 were excessively rainy throughout Europe, resulting in widespread crop failures.[259] The climate change—which resulted in a declining average annual temperature for Europe during the 14th century—was accompanied by an economic downturn.[260]

The prediction that light represent a transmission of energy in wave form through a `` luminiferous ether'', and the seem confirmation of that prediction with Helmholtz student Heinrich Hertz's 1888 detection of electromagnetic radiation, be a major triumph for physical theory and raise the possibility that even more fundamental theories base on the field could soon be develop.[ 37][ 38][ 39][ 40] Experimental confirmation of Maxwell's theory be provide by Hertz, who generate and detect electric waves in 1886 and verify their properties, at the same time foreshadow their application in radio, television, and other devices. In 1887, Heinrich Hertz discover the photoelectric effect. Research on the electromagnetic waves begin soon after, with many scientists and inventors conduct experiments on their properties. In the mid to late 1890s Guglielmo Marconi develop a radio wave base wireless telegraphy system[ 41]( see invention of radio).

Although not educate as a physician, Descartes do extensive anatomical studies of bulls' hearts and be consider important enough that William Harvey respond to him. Descartes be one of the first to endorse Harvey's model of the circulation of the blood, but disagree with his metaphysical framework to explain it. Descartes dissected animals and human cadavers and as a result be familiar with the research on the flow of blood lead to the conclusion that the body be a complex device that be capable of move without the soul, thus contradict the `` Doctrine of the Soul''. The emergence of psychology as a medical discipline be give a major boost by Thomas Willis, not only in his reference to psychology( the `` Doctrine of the Soul'') in terms of brain function, but through his detailed 1672 anatomical work, and his treatise De anima brutorum quae hominis vitalis ac sentitiva est: exercitationes duae( `` Two Discourses on the Souls of Brutes'' —meaning `` beasts''). However, Willis acknowledge the influence of Descartes's rival, Pierre Gassendi, as an inspiration for his work.

Agile software development guides software development projects that evolve rapidly with change expectations and competitive markets. Proponents of this method believe that heavy, document-driven processes( like TickIT, CMM and ISO 9000) be fade in importance[ citation need]. Some people believe that companies and agencies export many of the jobs that can be guide by heavy-weight processes[ citation need]. Related concepts include extreme programming, scrum, and lean software development.

From the 1820s, increasing numbers of squatters[164] occupied land beyond the fringes of European settlement. Often running sheep on large stations with relatively few overheads, squatters could make considerable profits. By 1834, nearly 2 million kilograms of wool were being exported to Britain from Australia.[165] By 1850, barely 2,000 squatters had gained 30 million hectares of land, and they formed a powerful and "respectable" interest group in several colonies.[166]

By the late 19th and early 20th century English statisticians lead by Francis Galton, Karl Pearson and Ronald Fisher develop the mathematical tools such as correlations and hypothesis tests that make possible much more sophisticated analysis of statistical data.[ 118]

This period was also marked by systematic genocide. In 1942–45, separately from the war-related deaths, the Nazis killed an additional number of over 11 million civilians identified through IBM-enabled censuses, including the majority of the Jews and Gypsies of Europe, millions of Polish and Soviet Slavs, and also homosexuals, Jehovah's Witnesses, misfits, disabled, and political enemies. Meanwhile, in the 1930s the Soviet system of forced labour, expulsions and allegedly engineered famine had a similar death toll. During and after the war millions of civilians were affected by forced population transfers.[123]

Modern philosophy traditionally begin with René Descartes and his dictum `` I think, therefore I be''. In the early seventeenth century the bulk of philosophy be dominate by Scholasticism, write by theologians and draw upon Plato, Aristotle, and early Church writings. Descartes argue that many predominant Scholastic metaphysical doctrines be meaningless or false. In short, he propose to begin philosophy from scratch. In his most important work, Meditations on First Philosophy, he attempt just this, over six brief essays. He try to set aside as much as he possibly can of all his beliefs, to determine what if anything he know for certain. He find that he can doubt nearly everything: the reality of physical objects, God, his memories, history, science, even mathematics, but he can not doubt that he be, in fact, doubt. He know what he be think about, even if it be not true, and he know that he be there think about it. From this basis he build his knowledge back up again. He find that some of the ideas he have could not have originate from him alone, but only from God; he prove that God exist. He then demonstrate that God would not allow him to be systematically deceive about everything; in essence, he vindicate ordinary methods of science and reasoning, as fallible but not false.

The great housing boom of the post war period saw rapid growth in the suburbs of the major Australian cities. By the 1966 census, only 14 per cent lived in rural Australia, down from 31 per cent in 1933 and only 8 per cent lived on farms.[358] Virtual full employment meant high standards of living and dramatic increases in home ownership, and by the Sixties, Australia had the most equitable spread of income in the world.[359] By the beginning of the Sixties, an Australia-wide McNair survey estimated that 94% of homes had a fridge, 50% a telephone, 55% a television, 60% a washing machine, and 73% a vacuum cleaner. In addition, most households now acquired a car.[360] According to one study, “In 1946, there was one car for every 14 Australians; by 1960, it was one to 3.5. The vast majority of families had access to a car.”[361]

Tracing back minute differences in the genomes of modern humans by methods of genetic genealogy, can and have been used to produce models of historical migration. Though these give indications of the routes taken by ancestral humans, the dating of the various genetic markers is improving. The earliest migrations (dated c. 75.000 BP) from the Red Sea shores have been most likely along southern coast of Asia. After this, tracking and timing genetical markers gets increasingly difficult. What is known, is that on areas, of what is now Iraq, Iran, Pakistan and Afghanistan, genetic markers diversify (from about 60000 BCE), and subsequent migrations emerge to all directions (even back to the Levant) and North Africs. From the foothills of the Zagros, big game hunting cultures developed which spread across the Eurasian steppe. Crossing the Caucasas and the Ural Mountains were the ancestors of Samoyeds and the ancestors of Uralic peoples, developing sleds, skis and canoes. Through Khazakhstan moved the ancestors of the Indigenous Americans (dated 50000 - 40000 BCE). Eastbound (maybe through Dzungaria and the Tarim Basin went the ancestors of the northern Chinese and Koreans. It is possible that the routes taken by the Indo-European ancestors travelled across the Bosphorus. Genetic evidence suggests a number of separate migrations (1.Anatoleans 2.Tocharians, 3 Celto-Illyrians, 4.Germanic and Slav, - possibly in this order). Archaeological evidence has not been identified for a number of different groups. On historical linguistic evidence, see f.e. classification of Thracian. The traditional view of associating early Celts with the Hallstatt culture, and the Nordic Bronze Age with Germanic peoples. The Roman Empire spread after the first widespread use of iron outside Central Europe from the Villanovan culture area. Most likely there has been trade also in these periods f.e. with amber and salt being major products.

The dominant position of the maritime Athenian Empire threaten Sparta and the Peloponnesian League of mainland Greek cities. Inevitably, this lead to conflict, result in the Peloponnesian War( 431–404 BC). Though effectively a stalemate for much of the war, Athens suffer a number of setbacks. The Plague of Athens in 430 BC follow by a disastrous military campaign know as the Sicilian Expedition severely weaken Athens. Around thirty per cent of the population die in a typhoid epidemic in 430–426 BC.[ 19]

One theory that has been advanced is that the devastation in Florence caused by the Black Death, which hit Europe between 1348 and 1350, resulted in a shift in the world view of people in 14th-century Italy. Italy was particularly badly hit by the plague, and it has been speculated that the resulting familiarity with death caused thinkers to dwell more on their lives on Earth, rather than on spirituality and the afterlife.[36] It has also been argued that the Black Death prompted a new wave of piety, manifested in the sponsorship of religious works of art.[37] However, this does not fully explain why the Renaissance occurred specifically in Italy in the 14th century. The Black Death was a pandemic that affected all of Europe in the ways described, not only Italy. The Renaissance's emergence in Italy was most likely the result of the complex interaction of the above factors.[10]

Assyrian inscriptions of Shalmaneser I( c. 1270 BC) first mention Uruartri as one of the states of Nairi – a loose confederation of small kingdoms and tribal states in the Armenian Highland from the 13th to 11th centuries BC. Uruartri itself be in the region around Lake Van. The Nairi states be repeatedly subject to attacks by the Assyrians, especially under Tukulti-Ninurta I( c. 1240 BC), Tiglath-Pileser I( c. 1100 BC), Ashur-bel-kala( c. 1070 BC), Adad-nirari II( c. 900), Tukulti-Ninurta II( c. 890), and Ashurnasirpal II( 883-859 BC).

British cinema was given a boost during the early 1980s by the arrival of David Puttnam's company Goldcrest Films. The films Chariots of Fire, Gandhi, The Killing Fields and A Room with a View appealed to a "middlebrow" audience which was increasingly being ignored by the major Hollywood studios. While the films of the 1970s had helped to define modern blockbuster motion pictures, the way "Hollywood" released its films would now change. Films, for the most part, would premiere in a wider number of theatres, although, to this day, some films still premiere using the route of the limited/roadshow release system. Against some expectations, the rise of the multiplex cinema did not allow less mainstream films to be shown, but simply allowed the major blockbusters to be given an even greater number of screenings. However, films that had been overlooked in cinemas were increasingly being given a second chance on home video.

The specifics of Paleo-Indian migration to and throughout the Americas, include the exact dates and routes travel, be subject to ongoing research and discussion.[ 1] The traditional theory have be that these early migrants move into the Beringia land bridge between eastern Siberia and present-day Alaska around 40,000 – 17,000 years ago, when sea levels be significantly lower due to the Quaternary glaciation.[ 1][ 2] These people be believe to have follow herds of now-extinct pleistocene megafauna along ice-free corridors that stretch between the Laurentide and Cordilleran ice sheets.[ 3] Another route propose be that, either on foot or use primitive boats, they migrate down the Pacific Northwest coast to South America.[ 4] Evidence of the latter would since have be cover by a sea level rise of a hundred meters follow the last ice age.[ 5]

In the latter part of the second revolution, Thomas Alva Edison developed many devices that greatly influenced life around the world and is often credited with the creation of the first industrial research laboratory. In 1882, Edison switched on the world's first large-scale electrical supply network that provided 110 volts direct current to fifty-nine customers in lower Manhattan. Also toward the end of the second industrial revolution, Nikola Tesla made many contributions in the field of electricity and magnetism in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

In its final form, Guernica be an immense black and white, 3.5 metres( 11 feet) tall and 7.8 metres( 26 feet) wide mural paint in oil. The mural presents a scene of death, violence, brutality, suffering, and helplessness without portray their immediate causes. The choice to paint in black and white contrasts with the intensity of the scene depict and invoke the immediacy of a newspaper photograph.[ 57] Picasso paint the mural sized painting call Guernica in protest of the bombing. The painting be first exhibit in Paris in 1937, then Scandinavia, then London in 1938 and finally in 1939 at Picasso's request the painting be send to the United States in an extended loan( for safekeeping) at MoMA. The paint go on a tour of museums throughout the USA until its final return to the Museum of Modern Art in New York City where it be exhibit for nearly thirty years. Finally in accord with Pablo Picasso's wish to give the painting to the people of Spain as a gift, it be send to Spain in 1981.

Carson’s concept of ecology was very much that of Gene Odum.[78] As a result, ecosystem science dominated the International Biological Program of the 1960s and 1970s, bringing both money and prestige to ecology.[79][80] Silent Spring was also the impetus for the environmental protection programs that were started in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations and passed into law just before the first Earth Day. Ecologists’ input was welcomed. Former ESA President Stanley Cain, for example, was appointed an Assistant Secretary in the Department of the Interior.

Idealism refers to the group of philosophies which assert that reality, or reality as we can know it, is fundamentally a construct of the mind or otherwise immaterial. Epistemologically, idealism manifests as a skepticism about the possibility of knowing any mind-independent thing. In a sociological sense, idealism emphasizes how human ideas—especially beliefs and values—shape society.[4] As an ontological doctrine, idealism goes further, asserting that all entities are composed of mind or spirit.[5] Idealism thus rejects physicalist and dualist theories that fail to ascribe priority to the mind. An extreme version of this idealism can exist in the philosophical notion of solipsism.

Critics of Popper, chiefly Thomas Kuhn, Paul Feyerabend and Imre Lakatos, reject the idea that there exist a single method that apply to all science and could account for its progress. In 1962 Kuhn publish the influential book The Structure of Scientific Revolutions which suggest that scientists work within a series of paradigms, and argue there be little evidence of scientists actually follow a falsificationist methodology. Kuhn quote Max Planck who have say in his autobiography, `` a new scientific truth do not triumph by convince its opponents and make them see the light, but rather because its opponents eventually die, and a new generation grow up that be familiar with it. ``[ 93]

Although the existence of dictionaries and encyclopedias span into ancient times, the texts change from simply define words in a long running list to far more detailed discussions of those words in 18th-century encyclopedic dictionaries.[ 161] The works be part of an Enlightenment movement to systematize knowledge and provide education to a wider audience than the elite. As the 18th century progress, the content of encyclopedias also change accord to readers' tastes. Volumes tend to focus more strongly on secular affairs, particularly science and technology, rather than matters of theology.

Teotihuacan refine the Mesoamerican pantheon of deities, whose origins date from the time of the Olmec. Of special importance be the worship of Quetzalcoatl and Tláloc, agricultural deities. Trade links promote the spread of these cults to other Mesoamerican societies, who take and transform them. It be think that Teotihuacan society have no knowledge of writing, but as Duverger demonstrate, the write system of Teotihuacan be extremely pictographic, to the point that writing be confuse with drawing.

Israel and Judah be relate Iron Age kingdoms of the ancient Levant and have exist during the Iron Ages and the Neo-Babylonian, Persian and Hellenistic periods. The name Israel first appear in the stele of the Egyptian pharaoh Merneptah c. 1209 BC, `` Israel be lay waste and his seed be no more. ``[ 151] This `` Israel'' be a cultural and probably political entity of the central highlands, well enough establish to be perceive by the Egyptians as a possible challenge to their hegemony, but an ethnic group rather than an organised state;[ 152] Archaeologist Paula McNutt say: `` It be probably ... during Iron Age I[ that] a population begin to identify itself as'Israelite','' differentiate itself from its neighbours via prohibitions on intermarriage, an emphasis on family history and genealogy, and religion.[ 153]

Pierre and Marie further explore radioactivity by work to separate the substances in uranium ores and then use the electrometer to make radiation measurements to ‘trace’ the minute amount of unknown radioactive element among the fractions that result. Working with the mineral pitchblende, the pair discover a new radioactive element in 1898. They name the element polonium, after Marie's native country of Poland. On December 21, 1898, the Curies detect the presence of another radioactive material in the pitchblende. They present this finding to the French Academy of Sciences on December 26, propose that the new element be call radium. The Curies then go to work isolate polonium and radium from naturally occur compounds to prove that they be new elements. In 1902, the Curies announce that they have produce a decigram of pure radium, demonstrate its existence as a unique chemical element. While it take three years for them to isolate radium, they be never able to isolate polonium. Along with the discovery of two new elements and find techniques for isolate radioactive isotopes, Curie oversee the world's first studies into the treatment of neoplasms, use radioactive isotopes. With Henri Becquerel and her husband, Pierre Curie, she be award the 1903 Nobel Prize for Physics. She be the sole winner of the 1911 Nobel Prize for Chemistry. She be the first woman to win a Nobel Prize, and she be the only woman to win the award in two different fields.

By 1916, Einstein be able to generalize this further, to deal with all states of motion include non-uniform acceleration, which become the general theory of relativity. In this theory Einstein also specify a new concept, the curvature of space-time, which describe the gravitational effect at every point in space. In fact, the curvature of space-time completely replace Newton's universal law of gravitation. According to Einstein, gravitational force in the normal sense be a kind of illusion cause by the geometry of space. The presence of a mass cause a curvature of space-time in the vicinity of the mass, and this curvature dictate the space-time path that all freely-moving objects must follow. It be also predict from this theory that light should be subject to gravity- all of which be verify experimentally. This aspect of relativity explain the phenomena of light bend around the sun, predict black holes as well as properties of the Cosmic microwave background radiation — a discovery render fundamental anomalies in the classic Steady-State hypothesis. For his work on relativity, the photoelectric effect and blackbody radiation, Einstein receive the Nobel Prize in 1921.

The economy of the early Republic be largely base on smallholding and pay labor. However, foreign wars and conquests make slaves increasingly cheap and plentiful, and by the late Republic, the economy be largely dependent on slave labor for both skilled and unskilled work. Slaves be estimate to have constitute around 20% of the Roman Empire's population at this time and 40% in the city of Rome. Only in the Roman Empire, when the conquests stop and the prices of slaves increase, do hire labor become more economical than slave ownership.

Sumerian farmers grow the cereals barley and wheat, start to live in villages from about 8,000 BC. Given the low rainfall of the region, agriculture rely on the Tigris and Euphrates rivers. Irrigation canals lead from the rivers permit the growth of cereals in large enough quantities to support cities. The first ploughs appear in pictographs from Uruk around 3,000 BC; seed-ploughs that funnel seed into the ploughed furrow appear on seals around 2300 BC. Vegetable crops include chickpeas, lentils, peas, beans, onions, garlic, lettuce, leeks and mustard. They grow fruits include dates, grapes, apples, melons, and figs. Alongside their farming, Sumerians also catch fish and hunted fowl and gazelle. The meat of sheep, goats, cows and poultry be eat, mainly by the elite. Fish be preserve by dry, salt and smoking.[ 35][ 36]

According to Robert Hughes in The Fatal Shore, the population of England and Wales, which had remained steady at six million from 1700 to 1740, rose dramatically after 1740. The population of England had more than doubled from 8.3 million in 1801 to 16.8 million in 1850 and, by 1901, had nearly doubled again to 30.5 million.[92] Improved conditions led to the population of Britain increasing from 10 million to 40 million in the 1800s.[93][94] Europe's population increased from about 100 million in 1700 to 400 million by 1900.[95]

The 20th century was indeed a period of breaking away from everything that ballet stood for. It was a time of unprecedented creative growth, for dancers and choreographers. It was also a time of shock, surprise and broadening of minds for the public, in terms of their definitions of what dance was. It was a revolution in the truest sense.

Later designs implemented a steam release valve to keep the machine from exploding. By watching the valve rhythmically move up and down, Papin conceived of the idea of a piston and cylinder engine. He did not however follow through with his design. Nevertheless, in 1697, based on Papin's designs, engineer Thomas Savery built the first engine. Although these early engines were crude and inefficient, they attracted the attention of the leading scientists of the time. Hence, prior to 1698 and the invention of the Savery Engine, horses were used to power pulleys, attached to buckets, which lifted water out of flooded salt mines in England. In the years to follow, more variations of steam engines were built, such as the Newcomen Engine, and later the Watt Engine. In time, these early engines would eventually be utilized in place of horses. Thus, each engine began to be associated with a certain amount of "horse power" depending upon how many horses it had replaced. The main problem with these first engines was that they were slow and clumsy, converting less than 2% of the input fuel into useful work. In other words, large quantities of coal (or wood) had to be burned to yield only a small fraction of work output. Hence the need for a new science of engine dynamics was born.

Adam Smith( 1723–1790) be popularly see as the father of modern political economy. His 1776 publication An Inquiry Into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations happen to coincide not only with the American Revolution, shortly before the Europe-wide upheavals of the French Revolution, but also the dawn of a new industrial revolution that allow more wealth to be create on a larger scale than ever before.

The massive work was arranged according to a "tree of knowledge." The tree reflected the marked division between the arts and sciences, which was largely a result of the rise of empiricism. Both areas of knowledge were united by philosophy, or the trunk of the tree of knowledge. The Enlightenment's desacrilization of religion was pronounced in the tree's design, particularly where theology accounted for a peripheral branch, with black magic as a close neighbour.[168] As the Encyclopédie gained popularity, it was published in quarto and octavo editions after 1777. The quarto and octavo editions were much less expensive than previous editions, making the Encyclopédie more accessible to the non-elite. Robert Darnton estimates that there were approximately 25 000 copies of the Encyclopédie in circulation throughout France and Europe before the French Revolution.[169] The extensive, yet affordable encyclopedia came to represent the transmission of Enlightenment and scientific education to an expanding audience.[170]

The earliest evidence of human civilization in South Asia be from the Mehrgarh region( 7000 BC to 3200 BC) of Pakistan. Located near the Bolan Pass, to the west of the Indus River valley and between the present-day Pakistani cities of Quetta, Kalat and Sibi, Mehrgarh be discover in 1974 by an archaeological team direct by French archaeologist Jean-François Jarrige, and be excavate continuously between 1974 and 1986. The earliest settlement at Mehrgarh—in the northeast corner of the 495 acres( 2.00 km2) site—was a small farming village date between 7000 BC–5500 BC. Early Mehrgarh residents live in mud brick houses, store their grain in granaries, fashion tools with local copper ore, and line their large basket containers with bitumen. They cultivate six-row barley, einkorn and emmer wheat, jujubes and dates, and herd sheep, goats and cattle. Residents of the later period( 5500 BC to 2600 BC) put much effort into crafts, include flint knapping, tan, bead production, and metal work. The site be occupy continuously until about 2600 BC.[ 2]

Environmental science be an interdisciplinary field. It draw upon the disciplines of biology, chemistry, earth sciences, ecology, geography, mathematics, and physics.

The characteristics of Ancient Egyptian technology are indicated by a set of artifacts and customs that lasted for thousands of years. The Egyptians invented and used many basic machines, such as the ramp and the lever, to aid construction processes. The Egyptians also played an important role in developing Mediterranean maritime technology including ships and lighthouses.

In the 1960s, as evolutionary theorists explore the possibility of multiple units of selection, ecologists turn to evolutionary approaches. In population ecology, debate over group selection be brief but vigorous; by 1970, most biologists agree that natural selection be rarely effective above the level of individual organisms. The evolution of ecosystems, however, become a lasting research focus. Ecology expand rapidly with the rise of the environmental movement; the International Biological Program attempt to apply the methods of big science( which have be so successful in the physical sciences) to ecosystem ecology and press environmental issues, while smaller-scale independent efforts such as island biogeography and the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest help redefine the scope of an increasingly diverse discipline.[ 54]

"Total theatre" also developed in Nigeria in the 1950s. It utilised non-Naturalistic techniques, surrealistic physical imagery, and exercised a flexibile use of language. A course entitle `` sociology'' be teach for the first time in the United States in 1875 by William Graham Sumner, draw upon the thought of Comte and Herbert Spencer rather than the work of Durkheim.[ 34] In 1890, the oldest continue sociology course in the United States begin at the University of Kansas, lecture by Frank Blackmar. The Department of History and Sociology at the University of Kansas be establish in 1891[ 35][ 36] and the first full-fledged independent university department of sociology be establish in 1892 at the University of Chicago by Albion W. Small( 1854–1926), who in 1895 found the American Journal of Sociology.[ 37] American sociology arise on a broadly independent trajectory to European sociology. George Herbert Mead and Charles H. Cooley be influential in the development of symbolic interactionism and social psychology at the University of Chicago, while Lester Ward emphasize the central importance of the scientific method with the publication of Dynamic Sociology in 1883.

After public stage performances have be ban for 18 years by the Puritan regime, the re-opening of the theatres in 1660 signal a renaissance of English drama. With the restoration of the monarch in 1660 come the restoration of and the reopening of the theatre. English comedies write and perform in the Restoration period from 1660 to 1710 be collectively call `` Restoration comedy''. Restoration comedy be notorious for its sexual explicitness, a quality encourage by Charles II( 1660–1685) personally and by the rakish aristocratic ethos of his court. At this point in history, women be allow the play the parts of women and not men as be the case. socially diverse audiences include both aristocrats, their servants and hangers-on, and a substantial middle-class segment. Restoration audiences like to see good triumph in their tragedies and rightful government restore. In comedy they like to see the love-lives of the young and fashionable, with a central couple bring their courtship to a successful conclusion( often overcome the opposition of the elders to do so). Heroines have to be chaste, but be independent-minded and outspoken; now that they be play by women, there be more mileage for the playwright in disguise them in men's clothes or give them narrow escape from rape. These playgoers be attract to the comedies by up-to-the-minute topical writing, by crowd and bustle plots, by the introduction of the first professional actresses, and by the rise of the first celebrity actors. To non-theatre-goers these comedies be widely see as licentious and morally suspect, hold up the antics of a small, privileged, and decadent class for admiration. This same class dominate the audiences of the Restoration theatre. This period saw the first professional woman playwright, Aphra Behn.

The date mark the end of prehistory in a particular culture or region, that be, the date when relevant write historical records become a useful academic resource, varies enormously from region to region. For example, in Egypt it be generally accept that prehistory end around 3200 BC, whereas in New Guinea the end of the prehistoric era be set much more recently, at around 1900 AD. In Europe the relatively well-documented classical cultures of Ancient Greece and Ancient Rome have neighbouring cultures, include the Celts and to a lesser extent the Etruscans, with little or no writing, and historians must decide how much weight to give to the often highly prejudiced accounts of these `` prehistoric'' cultures in Greek and Roman literature.

During 1850–1890, Sweden experienced a veritable explosion in export, dominated by crops, wood and steel. Sweden abolished most tariffs and other barriers to free trade in the 1850s and joined the gold standard in 1873.

The earliest Indian paintings were the rock paintings of prehistoric times, the petroglyphs as found in places like the Rock Shelters of Bhimbetka, and some of them are older than 5500 BC. Such works continued and after several millennia, in the 7th century, carved pillars of Ajanta, Maharashtra state present a fine example of Indian paintings, and the colors, mostly various shades of red and orange, were derived from minerals.

The Bronze Age is a period characterized by the use of bronze, proto-writing, and other early features of urban civilization. During the 1920s and the 1930s and the Great Depression, Surrealism, late Cubism, the Bauhaus, De Stijl, Dada, German Expressionism, Expressionism, and modernist and masterful color painters like Henri Matisse and Pierre Bonnard characterize the European art scene. One question of active interest to historians be why the Industrial Revolution occur in Europe and not in other parts of the world in the 18th century, particularly China, India, and the Middle East, or at other times like in Classical Antiquity[ 149] or the Middle Ages.[ 150] Numerous factors have be suggest, include education, technological changes[ 151]( see Scientific Revolution in Europe), `` modern'' government, `` modern'' work attitudes, ecology, and culture.[ 152] However, most historians contest the assertion that Europe and China be roughly equal because modern estimates of per capita income on Western Europe in the late 18th century be of roughly 1,500 dollars in purchase power parity( and Britain have a per capita income of nearly 2,000 dollars[ 153]) whereas China, by comparison, have only 450 dollars.

Bernard Mandeville,( 15 November 1670 – 21 January 1733), be an Anglo-Dutch philosopher, political economist and satirist. His main thesis be that the actions of men can not be divide into lower and higher. The higher life of man be a mere fiction introduce by philosophers and rulers to simplify government and the relations of society. In fact, virtue( which he define as `` every performance by which man, contrary to the impulse of nature, should endeavour the benefit of others, or the conquest of his own passions, out of a rational ambition of be good'') be actually detrimental to the state in its commercial and intellectual progress. This be because it be the vices( i.e., the self-regarding actions of men) which alone, by means of inventions and the circulation of capital( economics) in connection with luxurious living, stimulate society into action and progress.

English has also borrowed many words directly from Latin, the ancestor of the Romance languages, during all stages of its development.[203][201] Many of these words were earlier borrowed into Latin from Greek. A growing population and a shortage of land also seem to have created internal strife between the poor and the rich in many city-states. In Sparta, the Messenian Wars resulted in the conquest of Messenia and enserfment of the Messenians, beginning in the latter half of the 8th century BC, an act without precedent in ancient Greece. This practice allowed a social revolution to occur.[15] The subjugated population, thenceforth known as helots, farmed and labored for Sparta, whilst every Spartan male citizen became a soldier of the Spartan Army in a permanently militarized state. Even the elite were obliged to live and train as soldiers; this commonality between rich and poor citizens served to defuse the social conflict. These reforms, attributed to Lycurgus of Sparta, were probably complete by 650 BC.

Dr. Richard E. Tressler was an international leader in the development of high temperature materials. He pioneered high temperature fiber testing and use, advanced instrumentation and test methodologies for thermostructural materials, and design and performance verification of ceramics and composites in high temperature aerospace, industrial and energy applications. He was founding director of the Center for Advanced Materials (CAM) which supported many faculty and students from the College of Earth and Mineral Science, the Eberly College of Science, the College of Engineering, the Materials Research Laboratory and the Applied Research Laboratories at Penn State on high temperature materials. His vision for interdisciplinary research played a key role in the creation of the Materials Research Institute. Tressler's contribution to materials science is celebrated with a Penn State lecture named in his honor.[4]

In 1565, Spanish navigator Andrés de Urdaneta find a wind system that would allow ships to sail eastward from Asia, back to the Americas. From then until 1815 the annual Manila Galleons cross the Pacific from Mexico to the Philippines and back, in the first transpacific trade route in history. Combined with the Spanish Atlantic or West Indies Fleet, the Manila Galleons form one of the first global maritime exchange in human history, link Seville in Spain with Manila in the Philippines, via Mexico.

The occasionally violent Donatist controversy has been characterized[by whom?] as a struggle between opponents and supporters of the Roman system. The most articulate North African critic of the Donatist position, which came to be called a heresy, was Augustine, bishop of Hippo Regius. Augustine maintained that the unworthiness of a minister did not affect the validity of the sacraments because their true minister was Jesus Christ. In his sermons and books Augustine, who is considered a leading exponent of Christian dogma, evolved a theory of the right of orthodox Christian rulers to use force against schismatics and heretics. Although the dispute was resolved by a decision of an imperial commission in Carthage in 411, Donatist communities continued to exist as late as the 6th century.[citation needed]

Another play of significance is The Marriage of Anansewa, written in 1975 by Efua Sutherland. The entire play is based upon an Akan oral tradition called Anansesem(folk tales). The main character of the play is Ananse (the spider). The qualities of Ananse are one of the most prevalent parts of the play. Ananse is cunning, selfish, has great insight into human and animal nature, is ambitious, eloquent, and resourceful. By putting too much of himself into everything that he does Ananse ruins each of his schemes and ends up poor.[84] Ananse is used in the play as a kind of Everyman. He is written in an exaggerated sense in order to force the process of self-examination. Ananse is used as a way to spark a conversation for change in the society of anyone reading. The play tells of Ananse attempting to marry off his daughter Anansewa off to any of a selection of rich chiefs, or another sort of wealthy suitor simultaneously, in order to raise money. Eventually all the suitors come to his house at once, and he has to use all of his cunning to defuse the situation.[84] The storyteller not only narrates but also enacts, reacts to, and comments on the action of the tale. Along with this, Mbuguous is used, Mbuguous is the name given to very specialized sect of Ghanaian theatre technique that allows for audience participation. The Mbuguous of this tale are songs that embellish the tale or comment on it. Spontaneity through this technique as well as improvisation are used enough to meet any standard of modern theatre.[84]

The Arawak live along the eastern coast of South America, from present-day Guayana to as far south as what be now Brazil. Explorer Christopher Columbus describe them at first encounter as a peaceful people, although the Arawak have already dominate other local groups such as the Ciboney. The Arawak have, however, come under increase military pressure from the Carib, who be believe to have leave the Orinoco river area to settle on islands and the coast of the Caribbean Sea. Although the Palaeologi emperors recapture Constantinople from the Western Europeans in 1261, they be never able to regain control of much of the former imperial lands. The power of the Byzantine emperors be threaten by a new Turkish tribe, the Ottomans, who establish themselves in Anatolia in the 13th century and steadily expand throughout the 14th century. Mesoamerican chronology divide the history of pre-Columbian Mesoamerica into several periods: the Paleo-Indian( first human habitation–3500 BCE), the Archaic( 3500–2000), the Preclassic or Formative( 2000 BCE–200 CE), the Classic( 200 CE–1000CE), and the Postclassic( 1000 CE–1697 CE). Some of the period divisions be take from the history of the Maya: The Preclassic-Classic boundary marks the first Maya `` collapse'', the Classic-Postclassic boundary marks the second, and the end date of 1697 marks the conquest of the last independent Maya city-state, Tayasal. However, this chronology applies to other pre-Columbian Mesoamerican civilizations as well.

Women in the Middle Ages were officially required to be subordinate to some male, whether their father, husband, or other kinsman. Widows, who were often allowed much control over their own lives, were still restricted legally. Women's work generally consisted of household or other domestically inclined tasks. Peasant women were usually responsible for taking care of the household, child-care, as well as gardening and animal husbandry near the house. They could supplement the household income by spinning or brewing at home. At harvest-time, they were also expected to help with field-work.[173] Townswomen, like peasant women, were responsible for the household, and could also engage in trade. What trades were open to women varied by country and period.[174] Noblewomen were responsible for running a household, and could occasionally be expected to handle estates in the absence of male relatives, but they were usually restricted from participation in military or government affairs. The only role open to women in the Church was that of nuns, as they were unable to become priests.[173]

Beliefs in the divine and in the afterlife be ingrain in ancient Egyptian civilization from its inception; pharaonic rule be base on the divine right of kings. The Egyptian pantheon be populate by gods who have supernatural powers and be call on for help or protection. However, the gods be not always view as benevolent, and Egyptians believe they have to be appease with offerings and prayers. The structure of this pantheon change continually as new deities be promote in the hierarchy, but priests make no effort to organize the diverse and sometimes conflict myths and stories into a coherent system.[ 166] These various conceptions of divinity be not consider contradictory but rather layers in the multiple facets of reality.[ 167]

Regional geography was coined by a group of geographers known as possibilists and represented a reaffirmation that the proper topic of geography was study of places (regions). Regional geographers focused on the collection of descriptive information about places, as well as the proper methods for dividing the earth up into regions. Well-known names from these period are Alfred Hettner in Germany and Paul Vidal de la Blache in France. The philosophical basis of this field in United States was laid out by Richard Hartshorne, who defined geography as a study of areal differentiation, which later led to criticism of this approach as overly descriptive and unscientific.

In both RP and GA, vowels are phonetically shortened before fortis consonants in the same syllable, like /t tʃ f/, but not before lenis consonants like /d dʒ v/ or in open syllables: thus, the vowels of rich [rɪ̆tʃ], neat [niˑt], and safe [sĕɪ̆f] are noticeably shorter than the vowels of ridge [rɪdʒ], need [niːd], and save [seɪv], and the vowel of light [lăɪ̆t] is shorter than that of lie [laɪ]. Because lenis consonants are frequently voiceless at the end of a syllable, vowel length is an important cue as to whether the following consonant is lenis or fortis.[144]

The difference between prehistoric warfare and ancient warfare is less one of technology than of organization. The development of first city-states, and then empires, allowed warfare to change dramatically. Beginning in Mesopotamia, states produced sufficient agricultural surplus that full-time ruling elites and military commanders could emerge. While the bulk of military forces were still farmers, the society could support having them campaigning rather than working the land for a portion of each year. Thus, organized armies developed for the first time.

Archaeological research in Northern Vietnam indicates an increase in rates of infectious disease following the advent of metallurgy; skeletal fragments in sites dating to the early and mid-Bronze Age evidence a greater proportion of lesions than in sites of earlier periods.[56] There are a few possible implications of this. One is the increase contact with bacterial and/or fungal pathogens due to increased population density and land clearing/ cultivation. The other one is decreased levels of immunocompetence in the Metal age due to changes in diet caused by agriculture. The last is that there may have been an emergence of infectious disease in the Da But period that evolved into a more virulent form in the metal period.[56] Archaeology also suggests that Bronze Age metallurgy may not have been as significant a catalyst in social stratification and warfare in Southeast Asia as in other regions, social distribution shifting away from chiefdom-states to a heterarchical network.[57] Data analyses of sites such as Ban Lum Khao, Ban Na Di, Non Nok Tha, Khok Phanom Di, and Nong Nor have consistently led researchers to conclude that there was no forentrenched hierarchy.[58]

North Africa and the Nile Valley imported its iron technology from the Near East and followed the Near Eastern course of Bronze Age and Iron Age development. The earliest dating of iron in Sub-Saharan Africa is 2500 BCE at Egaro, west of Termit, making it contemporary to the Middle East.[14] The Egaro date is debatable with archaeologists, due to the method used to attain it.[15] The Termit date of 1500 BCE is widely accepted.

The Nine rank system be a civil service nomination system during the Three Kingdoms( 220-280 AD) and the Southern and Northern Dynasties( 420-589 AD) in China. Theoretically, local government authorities be give the task of select talented candidates, then categorize them into nine grades depend on their abilities. Modern English has little inflection compared with many other languages, and relies more on auxiliary verbs and word order for the expression of complex tenses, aspect and mood, as well as passive constructions, interrogatives and some negation. Despite noticeable variation among the accents and dialects of English used in different countries and regions – in terms of phonetics and phonology, and sometimes also vocabulary, grammar and spelling – English-speakers from around the world are able to communicate with one another with relative ease.

Aristotle, and nearly all Western scholars after him until the 18th century, believe that creatures be arrange in a graded scale of perfection rise from plants on up to humans: the scala naturae or Great Chain of Being.[ 15] Aristotle's successor at the Lyceum, Theophrastus, write a series of books on botany—the History of Plants—which survive as the most important contribution of antiquity to botany, even into the Middle Ages. Many of Theophrastus' names survive into modern times, such as carpos for fruit, and pericarpion for seed vessel. Dioscorides write a pioneering and encyclopaedic pharmacopoeia, De Materia Medica, incorporate descriptions of some 600 plants and their uses in medicine. Pliny the Elder, in his Natural History, assemble a similarly encyclopaedic account of things in nature, include accounts of many plants and animals.[ 16]

Astronomy is the oldest of the natural sciences, dating back to antiquity, with its origins in the religious, mythological, cosmological, calendrical, and astrological beliefs and practices of prehistory: vestiges of these are still found in astrology, a discipline long interwoven with public and governmental astronomy, and not completely disentangled from it until a few centuries ago in the Western World (see astrology and astronomy). In some cultures, astronomical data was used for astrological prognostication.

Early Neolithic farming was limited to a narrow range of plants, both wild and domesticated, which included einkorn wheat, millet and spelt, and the keeping of dogs, sheep and goats. By about 6,900–6,400 BC, it included domesticated cattle and pigs, the establishment of permanently or seasonally inhabited settlements, and the use of pottery. The Neolithic period saw the development of early villages, agriculture, animal domestication, tools and the onset of the earliest recorded incidents of warfare.[17] The Neolithic era commenced with the beginning of farming, which produced the "Neolithic Revolution". It ended when metal tools became widespread (in the Copper Age or Bronze Age; or, in some geographical regions, in the Iron Age).The term Neolithic is commonly used in the Old World, as its application to cultures in the Americas and Oceania that did not fully develop metal-working technology raises problems.

There be many renowned Ming Dynasty artists; Qiu Ying be an excellent example of a paramount Ming era painter( famous even in his own day), utilize in his artwork domestic scenes, bustle palatial scenes, and nature scenes of river valleys and steep mountains shroud in mist and swirl clouds. During the Ming Dynasty there be also different and rival schools of art associate with painting, such as the Wu School and the Zhe School.

Hannu travelled along the Red Sea to Punt, and sailed to what is now part of eastern Ethiopia and Somalia. He returned to Egypt with great treasures, including precious myrrh, metal and wood.

In 1773, Swedish chemist Carl Wilhelm Scheele discovered oxygen, which he called "fire air", but did not immediately publish his achievement.[46] In 1774, English chemist Joseph Priestley independently isolated oxygen in its gaseous state, calling it "dephlogisticated air", and published his work before Scheele.[47][48] During his lifetime, Priestley's considerable scientific reputation rested on his invention of soda water, his writings on electricity, and his discovery of several "airs" (gases), the most famous being what Priestley dubbed "dephlogisticated air" (oxygen). However, Priestley's determination to defend phlogiston theory and to reject what would become the chemical revolution eventually left him isolated within the scientific community.

Near the end of the Wisconsin glaciation, 15,000 to 9,000 years ago, mass extinction of Megafauna such as the Wooly mammoth occur in Asia, Europe, North America and Australia. This be the first Holocene extinction event. It possibly force modification in the dietary habits of the humans of that age and with the emergence of agricultural practices, plant-based foods also become a regular part of the diet. Geology do not undergo systematic restructuring during the Scientific Revolution, but individual theorists make important contributions. Robert Hooke, for example, formulate a theory of earthquakes, and Nicholas Steno develop the theory of superposition and argue that fossils be the remains of once-living creatures. Beginning with Thomas Burnet's Sacred Theory of the Earth in 1681, natural philosophers begin to explore the idea that the Earth have change over time. Burnet and his contemporaries interpret Earth's past in terms of events describe in the Bible, but their work lay the intellectual foundations for secular interpretations of Earth history.

Prehistoric artifacts discover in Africa, date 20,000 years old or more suggest early attempts to quantify time.[ 12] The Ishango bone, find near the headwaters of the Nile river( northeastern Congo), may be more than 20,000 years old and consist of a series of tally marks carve in three columns run the length of the bone. Common interpretations be that the Ishango bone show either the earliest known demonstration of sequences of prime numbers[ 13] or a six-month lunar calendar.[ 14] Peter Rudman argue that the development of the concept of prime numbers could only have come about after the concept of division, which he date to after 10,000 BC, with prime numbers probably not be understand until about 500 BC. He also write that `` no attempt have be make to explain why a tally of something should exhibit multiples of two, prime numbers between 10 and 20, and some numbers that be almost multiples of 10. ``[ 15] The Ishango bone, accord to scholar Alexander Marshack, may have influence the later development of mathematics in Egypt as, like some entries on the Ishango bone, Egyptian arithmetic also make use of multiplication by 2; this, however, be dispute.[ 16]

By 1500 CE, most of southern Africa had established states. In northwestern Namibia, the Ovambo engaged in farming and the Herero engaged in herding. As cattle numbers increased, the Herero moved southward to central Namibia for grazing land. A related group, the Ovambanderu, expanded to Ghanzi in northwestern Botswana. The Nama, a Khoi-speaking, sheep-raising group, moved northward and came into contact with the Herero; this would set the stage for much conflict between the two groups. The expanding Lozi states pushed the Mbukushu, Subiya, and Yei to Botei, Okavango, and Chobe in northern Botswana.[131]

The history of economic thought deals with different thinkers and theories in the subject that become political economy and economics, from the ancient world to the present day. It encompass many disparate schools of economic thought. Ancient Greek writers such as the philosopher Aristotle examine ideas about the art of wealth acquisition, and question whether property be best leave in private or public hands. In the Middle Ages, scholasticists such as Thomas Aquinas argue that it be a moral obligation of businesses to sell goods at a just price.

During the British Raj, famines in India, often attribute to failed policies of British colonial government, be some of the worst ever record, include the Great Famine of 1876–78 in which 6.1 million to 10.3 million people die[ 363] and the Indian famine of 1899–1900 in which 1.25 to 10 million people die.[ 364] The Third Plague Pandemic in the mid-19th century kill 10 million people in India.[ 365] Despite persistent diseases and famines, the population of the Indian subcontinent, which stand at about 125 million in 1750, have reach 389 million by 1941.[ 366]

Ethiopian architecture (including modern-day Eritrea) expanded from the Aksumite style and incorporated new traditions with the expansion of the Ethiopian state. Styles incorporated more wood and rounder structures in commoner's architecture in the center of the country and the south, and these stylistic influences were manifested in the construction of churches and monasteries. Throughout the medieval period, Aksumite architecture and influences and its monolithic tradition persisted, with its influence strongest in the early medieval (Late Aksumite) and Zagwe periods (when the churches of Lalibela were carved). Throughout the medieval period, and especially from the 10th to 12th centuries, churches were hewn out of rock throughout Ethiopia, especially during the northernmost region of Tigray, which was the heart of the Aksumite Empire. However, rock-hewn churches have been found as far south as Adadi Maryam (15th century), about 100 km south of Addis Abeba. The most famous example of Ethiopian rock-hewn architecture are the 11 monolithic churches of Lalibela, carved out of the red volcanic tuff found around the town. Though later medieval hagiographies attribute all 11 structures to the eponymous King Lalibela (the town was called Roha and Adefa before his reign), new evidence indicates that they may have been built separately over a period of a few centuries, with only a few of the more recent churches having been built under his reign. Archaeologist and Ethiopisant David Phillipson postulates, for instance, that Bete Gebriel-Rufa'el was actually built in the very early medieval period, some time between 600 and 800 A.D., originally as a fortress but was later turned into a church.[11]

Since Vedic times,[ 91][ note 2] `` people from many strata of society throughout the subcontinent tend to adapt their religious and social life to Brahmanic norms'', a process sometimes call Sanskritisation.[ 91] It be reflect in the tendency to identify local deities with the gods of the Sanskrit texts.[ 91]

After Lin destroyed more than 20,000 chests of opium in the summer of 1839, Europeans demanded compensation for what they saw as unwarranted Chinese interference in their affairs. When it was not paid, the British declared war later the same year, starting what became known as the First Opium War. The outdated Chinese junks were no match for the advanced British gunboats, and soon the Yangzi River region came under threat of British bombardment and invasion. The emperor had no choice but to sue for peace, resulting in the exile of Lin and the Treaty of Nanking, which ceded the British control of Hong Kong and opened up trade and diplomacy with other European countries, including Germany, France, and the USA.

Slavery have have a significant role in the economic development the New World after the colonization of the Americas by the Europeans. The cotton, tobacco, and sugar cane harvest by slaves become important exports for the United States and the Caribbean countries.

The Muslim conquest of Hispania begin when the Moors( Berbers and Arabs) invade the Christian Visigothic kingdom of Hispania in the year 711, under the Berber general Tariq ibn Ziyad. They land at Gibraltar on 30 April and work their way northward. Tariq's forces be join the next year by those of his Arab superior, Musa ibn Nusair. During the eight-year campaign most of the Iberian Peninsula be bring under Muslim rule – save for small areas in the northwest( Asturias) and largely Basque regions in the Pyrenees. In 711, Visigothic Hispania be very weakened because it be immerse in a serious internal crisis cause by a war of succession to the throne involve two Visigoth suitors. The Muslims take advantage of the crisis that cross the Hispano-Visigothic society to carry out their conquests. This territory, under the Arab name Al-Andalus, become part of the expand Umayyad empire.

European colonization of the Americas lead to the rise of new cultures, civilizations and eventually states, which result from the fusion of Native American and European traditions, peoples and institutions. The transformation of American cultures through colonization be evident in architecture, religion, gastronomy, the arts and particularly languages, the most widespread be Spanish( 376 million speakers), English( 348 million) and Portuguese( 201 million). The colonial period last approximately three centuries, from the early 16th to the early 19th centuries, when Brazil and the larger Hispanic American nations declare independence. The United States obtain independence from England much earlier, in 1776, while Canada form a federal dominion in 1867. Others remain attach to their European parent state until the end of the 19th century, such as Cuba and Puerto Rico which be link to Spain until 1898. Smaller territories such as Guyana obtain independence in the mid-20th century, while certain Caribbean islands remain part of a European power to this day.

Interest in studying, and even idealizing, ancient Rome became prevalent during the Italian Renaissance, and continues until the present day. Charles Montesquieu wrote a work Reflections on the Causes of the Grandeur and Declension of the Romans. The first major work was The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire by Edward Gibbon, which encompassed the period from the end of the 2nd century to the fall of the Byzantine Empire in 1453.[237] Like Montesquieu, Gibbon paid tribute to the virtue of Roman citizens. Barthold Georg Niebuhr was a founder of the examination of ancient Roman history and wrote The Roman History, tracing the period until the First Punic war. Niebuhr tried to determine the way the Roman tradition evolved. According to him, Romans, like other people, had an historical ethos preserved mainly in the noble families.

Berzelius develop the radical theory of chemical combination, which hold that reactions occur as stable groups of atoms call radicals be exchange between molecules. He believe that salts be compounds of an acid and bases, and discover that the anions in acids would be attract to a positive electrode( the anode), whereas the cations in a base would be attract to a negative electrode( the cathode). Berzelius do not believe in the Vitalism Theory, but instead in a regulative force which produce organization of tissues in an organism. Berzelius be also credit with originate the chemical terms `` catalysis'', `` polymer'', `` isomer'', and `` allotrope'', although his original definitions differ dramatically from modern usage. For example, he coin the term `` polymer'' in 1833 to describe organic compounds which share identical empirical formulas but which differ in overall molecular weight, the larger of the compounds be describe as `` polymers'' of the smallest. By this long supersede, pre-structural definition, glucose( C6H12O6) be view as a polymer of formaldehyde( CH2O).

The greatest population density for Aborigines develop in the southern and eastern regions, the River Murray valley in particular. Aborigines live and used resources on the continent sustainably, agree to cease hunting and gathering at particular times to give populations and resources the chance to replenish. The arrival of Australia's first people nevertheless affect the continent significantly, and, along with climate change, may have contribute to the extinction of Australia's megafauna.[ 20] The practice of firestick farming amongst northern Aborigines to increase the abundance of plants that attract animals, transform dry rainforest into savanna.[ 21] The introduction of the dingo by Aboriginal people around 3,000–4,000 years ago may, along with human hunting, have contribute to the extinction of the thylacine, Tasmanian devil, and Tasmanian native-hen from mainland Australia.[ 22][ 23]

The Second Sino-Japanese War have see tensions rise between Imperial Japan and the United States; events such as the Panay incident and the Nanking Massacre turn American public opinion against Japan. With the occupation of French Indochina in the years of 1940–41, and with the continue war in China, the United States place embargoes on Japan of strategic materials such as scrap metal and oil, which be vitally need for the war effort. The Japanese be face with the option of either withdraw from China and lose face or seizing and secure new sources of raw materials in the resource-rich, European-controlled colonies of South East Asia—specifically British Malaya and the Dutch East Indies( modern-day Indonesia). In 1940, Imperial Japan sign the Tripartite Pact with Nazi Germany and Fascist Italy.
