The more southern cultural groups of North America be responsible for the domestication of many common crops now use around the world, such as tomatoes and squash. Perhaps most importantly they domesticate one of the world's major staples, maize( corn).

Some scientists say that Easter Island was not inhabited until 700-800 CE. This date range is based on glottochronological calculations and on three radiocarbon dates from charcoal that appears to have been produced during forest clearance activities.[25]

Pierre Janet became the leading psychiatrist in France, being appointed to the Salpêtrière (1890–1894), the Sorbonne (1895–1920), and the Collège de France (1902–1936). In 1904, he co-founded the Journale de Psychologie Normale et Pathologique with fellow Sorbonne professor Georges Dumas (1866–1946), a student and faithful follower of Ribot. Whereas Janet's teacher, Charcot, had focused on the neurologial bases of hysteria, Janet was concerned to develop a scientific approach to psychopathology as a mental disorder. His theory that mental pathology results from conflict between unconscious and conscious parts of the mind, and that unconscious mental contents may emerge as symptoms with symbolic meanings led to a public priority dispute with Sigmund Freud.

Transactions which use precious metals as currency be carry out by divide( clip; Greek κέρδος) the material into an amount correspond to the perceive value of the item be purchase. From this one might understand how coinage be imagine from the small metallic clippings( of silver[ 53][ 54][ 55]) result from trade exchanges.[ 56] The word use in Thucydides writings History for money be χρήματα( `` chremata''), translate in some contexts as `` goods'' or `` property'', although with a wider range possible applicable usage, have a definite meaning `` valuable things''.[ 57][ 58][ 59][ 60]

The Egyptians work deposits of the lead ore galena at Gebel Rosas to make net sinkers, plumb bobs, and small figurines. Copper be the most important metal for toolmaking in ancient Egypt and be smelt in furnaces from malachite ore mine in the Sinai.[ 114] Workers collect gold by wash the nuggets out of sediment in alluvial deposits, or by the more labor-intensive process of grind and wash gold-bearing quartzite. Iron deposit find in upper Egypt be utilize in the Late Period.[ 115] High-quality building stones be abundant in Egypt; the ancient Egyptians quarry limestone all along the Nile valley, granite from Aswan, and basalt and sandstone from the wadis of the eastern desert. Deposits of decorative stones such as porphyry, greywacke, alabaster, and carnelian dot the eastern desert and be collect even before the First Dynasty. In the Ptolemaic and Roman Periods, miners work deposits of emeralds in Wadi Sikait and amethyst in Wadi el-Hudi.[ 116]

With barter, an individual possessing any surplus of value, such as a measure of grain or a quantity of livestock could directly exchange that for something perceive to have similar or greater value or utility, such as a clay pot or a tool. The capacity to carry out barter transactions be limit in that it depend on a coincidence of want. The seller of food grain have to find the buyer who want to buy grain and who also could offer in return something the seller want to buy. There be no agreed standard measure into which both seller and buyer could exchange commodities accord to their relative value of all the various goods and services offer by other potential barter partners.

Tools of the Oldowan tradition first come to archaeological attention in Europe, where, be intrusive and not well define, compare to the Acheulean, they be puzzle to archaeologists. The mystery would be elucidate by African archaeology at Olduvai, but meanwhile, in the early 20th century, the term `` Pre-Acheulean'' come into use in climatology. C.E.P, Brooks, a British climatologist work in the United States, use the term to describe a `` chalky boulder clay'' underlie a layer of gravel at Hoxne, central England, where Acheulean tools have be find.[ 37] Whether any tools would be find in it and what type be not know. Indian music is one of the oldest musical traditions in the world.[15] The Indus Valley civilization left sculptures which show dance[16] and musical instruments (some no longer in use), like the seven holed flute. Various types of stringed instruments and drums have been recovered from Harrappa and Mohenjo Daro by excavations carried out by Sir Mortimer Wheeler.[17] The Rigveda has elements of present Indian music, with a musical notation to denote the metre and the mode of chanting.[18] Early Indian musical tradition also speaks of three accents and vocal music known as "Samagan" (Sama meaning melody and Gan meaning to sing).[19] The classical music of India includes two major traditions: the southern Carnatic music and the northern Hindustani classical music. India's classical music tradition is millennia long and remains important to the lives of Indians today as a source of religious inspiration, cultural expression, and entertainment.
The Zapotec emerged around 1500 years BCE. Their writing system influenced the later Olmec. They left behind the great city Monte Alban.

Trajan be greet by the people of Rome with enthusiasm, which he justify by govern well and without the bloodiness that have mark Domitian's reign. He free many people who have be unjustly imprison by Domitian and return private property that Domitian have confiscate; a process begin by Nerva before his death.[ 97]

Culture in the Netherlands at the end of the 15th century be influence by the Italian Renaissance through trade via Bruges, which make Flanders wealthy. Its nobles commission artists who become know across Europe.[ 81] In science, the anatomist Andreas Vesalius lead the way; in cartography, Gerardus Mercator's map assist explorers and navigators. In art, Dutch and Flemish Renaissance paint range from the strange work of Hieronymus Bosch[ 82] to the everyday life depictions of Pieter Brueghel the Elder.[ 81]

In the 1970s Stephen Jay Gould and Niles Eldredge propose the theory of punctuated equilibrium which hold that stasis be the most prominent feature of the fossil record, and that most evolutionary changes occur rapidly over relatively short periods of time.[ 60] In 1980 Luis Alvarez and Walter Alvarez propose the hypothesis that an impact event be responsible for the Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event.[ 61] Also in the early 1980s, statistical analysis of the fossil record of marine organisms publish by Jack Sepkoski and David M. Raup lead to a better appreciation of the importance of mass extinction events to the history of life on earth.[ 62]

The Arabs lost sight of Aristotle's political science but continued to study Plato's Republic which became the basic text of Judeo-Islamic political philosophy as in the works of Alfarabi and Averroes; this did not happen in the Christian world, where Aristotle's Politics was translated in the 13th century and became the basic text as in the works of Saint Thomas Aquinas.[2]

The initial impetus for the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration be a lecture give by Dr. John Murray entitle `` The Renewal of Antarctic Exploration'', give to the Royal geographical Society in London, November 27, 1893.[ 15] Murray advocate that research into the Antarctic should be organise to `` resolve the outstanding geographical questions still pose in the south''.[ 16] Furthermore, the Royal Geographic Society instated an Antarctic Committee shortly prior to this, in 1887, which successfully encourage many whalers to explore the Southern regions of the world and lay the groundwork for the lecture give by Murray.[ 17]

Meanwhile, there be an increase academic interest in education and the first attempts to create what might be consider academic rationales for teach methods. This lead, in the 1770s, to the establishment of the first chair of pedagogy at the University of Halle in Germany. Contributions to the study of education elsewhere in Europe include the work of Johann Heinrich Pestalozzi in Switzerland and Joseph Lancaster in Britain.

The historical period of ancient Greece be unique in world history as the first period attest directly in proper historiography, while earlier ancient history or proto-history be know by much more circumstantial evidence, such as annals or king lists, and pragmatic epigraphy.

Located in Sardinia and Corsica, the Nuragic civilization last from the early Bronze Age( 18th century BC) to the 2nd century AD, when the islands be already Romanized. They take their name from the characteristic nuragic towers, which evolve from the pre-existing megalithic culture, which build dolmens and menhirs. The nuraghe towers be unanimously consider the best preserved and largest megalithic remain in Europe. Their effective use be still debate: some scholars consider them as monumental tombs, others as Houses of the Giants, other as fortresses, ovens for metal fusion, prisons or, finally, temples for a solar cult. Around the end of the third millennium BC, Sardinia export towards Sicily a Culture that build small dolmens, trilithic or polygonal shaped, that serve as tombs as it have be ascertain in the Sicilian dolmen of “Cava dei Servi”. From this region they reach Malta island and other countries of Mediterranean basin.[ 67]

Building on earlier work by many predecessors, Isaac Newton discovered the laws of physics explaining Kepler's Laws, and brought together the concepts now known as calculus. Independently, Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, who is arguably one of the most important mathematicians of the 17th century, developed calculus and much of the calculus notation still in use today. Science and mathematics had become an international endeavor, which would soon spread over the entire world.[141]

Medieval philosophy be characteristically theological. With the possible exceptions of Avicenna and Averroes, medieval thinkers do not consider themselves philosophers at all: for them, the philosophers be the ancient pagan writers such as Plato and Aristotle.[ 3] :1 However, their theology use the methods and logical techniques of the ancient philosophers to address difficult theological questions and points of doctrine. Thomas Aquinas, follow Peter Damian, argue that philosophy be the handmaiden of theology( ancilla theologiae).[ 3] :35
In pre-Columbian times, several large, centralized ancient civilizations develop in the Western Hemisphere,[ 182] both in Mesoamerica and western South America.

From the time of British colonization of Australia in 1788, Indigenous Australians be characterise as nomadic hunter-gatherers who do not engage in agriculture, despite evidence to the contrary. 1n 1969, the archaeologist Rhys Jones propose that Indigenous Australians engage in systematic burning as a way of enhance natural productivity, what have be term fire-stick farming.[ 81] In the 1970s and 1980s archaeological research in south west Victoria establish that the Gunditjmara and other groups have develop sophisticated eel farming and fish trap systems over a period of nearly 5,000 years.[ 82] The archaeologist Harry Lourandos suggest in the 1980s that there be evidence of'intensification' in progress across Australia,[ 83] a process that appear to have continue through the precede 5,000 years. These concepts lead the historian Bill Gammage to argue that in effect the whole continent be a managed landscape.[ 7]

Churchmen such as Erasmus and Luther proposed reform to the Church, often based on humanist textual criticism of the New Testament.[18] In October 1517 Luther published the 95 Theses, challenging papal authority and criticizing its perceived corruption, particularly with regard to instances of sold indulgences.[note 1] The 95 Theses led to the Reformation, a break with the Roman Catholic Church that previously claimed hegemony in Western Europe. Humanism and the Renaissance therefore played a direct role in sparking the Reformation, as well as in many other contemporaneous religious debates and conflicts.

Industrial age reform movements began the gradual change of society rather than with episodes of rapid fundamental changes. The reformists' ideas were often grounded in liberalism, although they also possessed aspects of utopian, socialist or religious concepts. The Radical movement campaigned for electoral reform, a reform of the Poor Laws, free trade, educational reform, postal reform, prison reform, and public sanitation.

Vespasian was a general under Claudius and Nero. He fought as a commander in the First Jewish-Roman War along with his son Titus. Following the turmoil of the Year of the Four Emperors, in 69 AD, four emperors were enthroned: Galba, Otho, Vitellius, and, lastly, Vespasian, who crushed Vitellius' forces and became emperor.[88]

During the Renaissance, architects aimed to use columns, pilasters, and entablatures as an integrated system. The Roman orders types of columns are used: Tuscan, Doric, Ionic, Corinthian and Composite. These can either be structural, supporting an arcade or architrave, or purely decorative, set against a wall in the form of pilasters. One of the first buildings to use pilasters as an integrated system was in the Old Sacristy (1421–1440) by Brunelleschi.[54] Arches, semi-circular or (in the Mannerist style) segmental, are often used in arcades, supported on piers or columns with capitals. There may be a section of entablature between the capital and the springing of the arch. Alberti was one of the first to use the arch on a monumental. Renaissance vaults do not have ribs; they are semi-circular or segmental and on a square plan, unlike the Gothic vault, which is frequently rectangular.

Despite Holt's sentiments and his government's electoral success in 1966, the war become unpopular in Australia, as it do in the United States. The movements to end Australia's involvement gather strength after the Tet Offensive of early 1968 and compulsory national service( select by ballot) become increasingly unpopular. In the 1969 elections, the government hung on despite a significant decline in popularity. Moratorium marches hold across Australia in mid-1970 attracted large crowds- the Melbourne march of 100,000 be lead by Labor MP Jim Cairns. As the Nixon administration proceed with Vietnamization of the war and begin the withdrawal of troops, so do the Australian Government. In November 1970 1st Australian Task Force be reduce to two battalions and in November 1971, 1ATF be withdraw from Vietnam. The last military advisors of the AATTV be withdraw by the Whitlam Labor Government in mid December 1972.[ 381]
Britain's canal network, together with its surviving mill buildings, is one of the most enduring features of the early Industrial Revolution to be seen in Britain.

D. W. Griffith have the highest standing among American directors in the industry, because of the dramatic excitement he convey to the audience through his films. The American film industry, or `` Hollywood'', as it be become know after its new geographical center in Hollywood, a neighborhood in Los Angeles, California, gain the position it have hold, more or less, ever since: film factory for the world and export its product to most countries. By the 1920s, the United States reach what be still its era of greatest-ever output, produce an average of 800 feature films annually,[ 1] or 82% of the global total( Eyman, 1997). During late 1927, Warner's release The Jazz Singer, with the first synchronize dialogue( and sing) in a feature film. By the end of 1929, Hollywood be almost all-talkie, with several compete sound systems( soon to be standardize). Sound save the Hollywood studio system in the face of the Great Depression( Parkinson, 1995).

Basically home-grown and with roots in the early 17th-century court masque, though never ashamed of borrow ideas and stage technology from French opera, the spectaculars be sometimes call `` English opera''. However, the variety of them be so untidy that most theatre historians despair of define them as a genre at all.[ 69] Only a handful of works of this period be usually accord the term `` opera'', as the musical dimension of most of them be subordinate to the visual. It be spectacle and scenery that draw in the crowds, as show by many comments in the diary of the theatre-lover Samuel Pepys.[ 70] The expense of mount ever more elaborate scenic productions drive the two compete theatre companies into a dangerous spiral of huge expenditure and correspondingly huge losses or profits. A fiasco such as John Dryden's Albion and Albanius would leave a company in serious debt, while blockbusters like Thomas Shadwell's Psyche or Dryden's King Arthur would put it comfortably in the black for a long time.[ 71]

Bold Jack Donahue is recorded as the last convict bushranger.[199] He was reported in newspapers around 1827 as being responsible for an outbreak of bushranging on the road between Sydney and Windsor. Throughout the 1820s he was regarded as the most notorious bushranger in the colony.[200] Leading a band of escaped convicts, Donahue became central to Australian folklore as the Wild Colonial Boy.[199]

The Renaissance began in Florence, in the 14th century.[4] Various theories have been proposed to account for its origins and characteristics, focusing on a variety of factors including the social and civic peculiarities of Florence at the time: its political structure; the patronage of its dominant family, the Medici;[5][6] and the migration of Greek scholars and texts to Italy following the Fall of Constantinople to the Ottoman Turks.[7][8][9] Other major centres were northern Italian city-states such as Venice, Genoa, Milan, Bologna, and finally Rome during the Renaissance Papacy.
Anthropologists were recruited from England and the USA, setting the foundation for the unique Canadian style of anthropology. Scholars include the linguist and Boasian Edward Sapir.

The use of different camera speeds also appear around 1900 in the films of Robert W. Paul and Hepworth. Paul shot scenes from On a Runaway Motor Car through Piccadilly Circus( 1899) with the camera turn very slowly. When the film be project at the usual 16 frames per second, the scenery appear to be pass at great speed. Hepworth use the opposite effect in The Indian Chief and the Seidlitz Powder( 1901). The Chief's movements be speed up by crank the camera much faster than 16 frames per second. This give what we would call a “slow motion” effect.

The Romantic Movement of the early 19th century reshape science by open up new pursuits unexpected in the classical approaches of the Enlightenment. Major breakthroughs come in biology, especially in Darwin's theory of evolution, as well as physics( electromagnetism), mathematics( non-Euclidean geometry, group theory) and chemistry( organic chemistry). The decline of Romanticism occur because a new movement, Positivism, begin to take hold of the ideals of the intellectuals after 1840 and last until about 1880.

In the 10th century the establishment of churches and monasteries led to the development of stone architecture that elaborated vernacular Roman forms, from which the term "Romanesque" is derived. Where available, Roman brick and stone buildings were recycled for their materials. From the tentative beginnings known as the First Romanesque, the style flourished and spread across Europe in a remarkably homogeneous form. Just before 1000 there was a great wave of building stone churches all over Europe.[238] Romanesque buildings have massive stone walls, openings topped by semi-circular arches, small windows, and, particularly in France, arched stone vaults.[239] The large portal with coloured sculpture in high relief became a central feature of façades, especially in France, and the capitals of columns were often carved with narrative scenes of imaginative monsters and animals.[240] According to art historian C. R. Dodwell, "virtually all the churches in the West were decorated with wall-paintings", of which few survive.[241] Simultaneous with the development in church architecture, the distinctive European form of the castle was developed, and became crucial to politics and warfare.[242]

Jobs traditionally associated with the middle class (assembly line workers, data processors, foremen and supervisors) are beginning to disappear, either through outsourcing or automation. Individuals who lose their jobs must either move up, joining a group of "mind workers" (engineers, doctors, attorneys, teachers, scientists, professors, executives, journalists, consultants), or settle for low-skill, low-wage service jobs.

The tension between pure ecology, seeking to understand and explain, and applied ecology, seeking to describe and repair, came to a head after World War II. Adams again tried to push the ESA into applied areas by having it raise an endowment to promote ecology. He predicted that "a great expansion of ecology" was imminent "because of its integrating tendency."[73] Ecologists, however, were sensitive to the perception that ecology was still not considered a rigorous, quantitative science. Those who pushed for applied studies and active involvement in conservation were once more discreetly rebuffed. Human ecology became subsumed by sociology. It was sociologist Lewis Mumford who brought the ideas of George Perkins Marsh to modern attention in the 1955 conference, "Man’s Role in Changing the Face of the Earth." That prestigious conclave was dominated by social scientists. At it, ecology was accused of "lacking experimental methods" and neglecting "man as an ecological agent." One participant dismissed ecology as "archaic and sterile."[74] Within the ESA, a frustrated Shelford started the Ecologists’ Union when his Committee on Preservation of Natural Conditions ceased to function due to the political infighting over the ESA stance on conservation.[67] In 1950, the fledgling organization was renamed and incorporated as the Nature Conservancy, a name borrowed from the British government agency for the same purpose.

In 1991 a convention among member nations of the Antarctic Treaty on how to regulate mining and drilling be propose. Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke and French Prime Minister Michel Rocard lead a response to this convention that result in the adoption of the Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty, now know as the Madrid Protocol. All mineral extraction be ban for 50 years and the Antarctic be set aside as a `` natural reserve, devote to peace and science''.[ 85]
Amundsen succeed in reach the Pole on 14 December 1911 use a route from the Bay of Whales to the polar plateau via the Axel Heiberg Glacier.[ 45][ 46][ 47]

On 15 April 1928, only a year after Charles Lindbergh's flight across the Atlantic, Wilkins and Eielson made a trans-Arctic crossing from Point Barrow, Alaska, to Spitsbergen, arriving about 20 hours later on 16 April, touching along the way at Grant Land on Ellesmere Island.[54] For this feat and his prior work, Wilkins was knighted.

Although a theory of Portuguese discovery in the 1520s exists, it lack definitive evidence.[ 74][ 75][ 76][ 77] The Dutch ship, Duyfken, lead by Willem Janszoon, make the first documented European landing in Australia in 1606.[ 78] That same year, a Spanish expedition sailing in nearby waters and lead by Portuguese navigator Pedro Fernandes de Queirós have land in the New Hebrides and, believe them to be the fabled southern continent, name the land `` Austrialia del Espiritu Santo''( Southern Land of the Holy Spirit), in honour of his queen Margaret of Austria, the wife of Philip III of Spain.[ 79][ 80][ 81] Later that year, Queirós' deputy Luís Vaz de Torres sail to the north of Australia through Torres Strait, along New Guinea's southern coast.[ 82]

Since the aforementioned V-2 rocket flight was undertaken in secrecy, it was not public knowledge for many years afterward. Further, the German launches, as well as the subsequent sounding rocket tests performed in both the United States and the Soviet Union during the late 1940s and early 1950s, were not considered significant enough to start a new age because they did not reach orbit. Having a rocket powerful enough to reach orbit meant that a nation had the ability to place a payload anywhere on the planet, or to use another term, possessed an inter-continental ballistic missile. The fact that after such a development nowhere on the planet was safe from a nuclear warhead is why the orbit standard is used to define when the space age started.[15]

Greek mathematics refers to the mathematics write in the Greek language from the time of Thales of Miletus( ~600 BC) to the closure of the Academy of Athens in 529 AD.[ 34] Greek mathematicians live in cities spread over the entire Eastern Mediterranean, from Italy to North Africa, but be unite by culture and language. New information about the world be discover via empirical observation,[ 15] versus the historic use of reason and innate knowledge.

In 1884, Hermann Emil Fischer propose the structure of purine, a key structure in many biomolecules, which he later synthesize in 1898. He also begin work on the chemistry of glucose and related sugars.[ 85] In 1885, Eugene Goldstein name the cathode ray, later discover to be compose of electrons, and the canal ray, later discover to be positive hydrogen ions that have be strip of their electrons in a cathode ray tube; these would later be name protons.[ 86] The year 1885 also saw the publishing of J. H. van't Hoff's L'Équilibre chimique dans les Systèmes gazeux ou dissous à I'État dilué( Chemical equilibria in gaseous systems or strongly diluted solutions), which deal with this theory of dilute solutions. Here he demonstrate that the `` osmotic pressure'' in solutions which be sufficiently dilute be proportionate to the concentration and the absolute temperature so that this pressure can be represent by a formula which only deviate from the formula for gas pressure by a coefficient i. He also determine the value of i by various methods, for example by means of the vapor pressure and François-Marie Raoult's results on the lowering of the freezing point. Thus van't Hoff be able to prove that thermodynamic laws be not only valid for gases, but also for dilute solutions. His pressure laws, give general validity by the electrolytic dissociation theory of Arrhenius( 1884-1887)- the first foreigner who come to work with him in Amsterdam( 1888)- be consider the most comprehensive and important in the realm of natural sciences. In 1893, Alfred Werner discover the octahedral structure of cobalt complexes, thus establish the field of coordination chemistry.[ 87]

Following Antony's Donations of Alexandria, which gave to Cleopatra the title of "Queen of Kings", and to Antony's and Cleopatra's children the regal titles to the newly conquered Eastern territories, war between Octavian and Antony broke out. Octavian annihilated Egyptian forces in the Battle of Actium in 31 BC. Antony and Cleopatra committed suicide. Now Egypt was conquered by the Roman Empire, and for the Romans, a new era had begun.

Ajanta Caves in Maharashtra, India be rock-cut cave monuments date back to the 2nd century BCE and contain paintings and sculpture consider to be masterpieces of both Buddhist religious art[ 23] and universal pictorial art.[ 24]

Paracelsus (1493–1541), was an erratic and abusive innovator who rejected Galen and bookish knowledge, calling for experimental research, with heavy doses of mysticism, alchemy and magic mixed in. The point is that he rejected sacred magic (miracles) under Church auspisces and looked for cures in nature.[60] He preached but he also pioneered the use of chemicals and minerals in medicine. His hermetical views were that sickness and health in the body relied on the harmony of man (microcosm) and Nature (macrocosm). He took an approach different from those before him, using this analogy not in the manner of soul-purification but in the manner that humans must have certain balances of minerals in their bodies, and that certain illnesses of the body had chemical remedies that could cure them.[61] Most of his influence came after his death. Paracelsus is a highly controversial figure in the history of medicine, with most experts hailing him as a Father of Modern Medicine for shaking off religious orthodoxy and inspiring many researchers; others say he was a mystic more than a scientist and downplay his importance.[62][63]

Bal Gangadhar Tilak, an Indian nationalist leader, declare Swaraj as the destiny of the nation. His popular sentence `` Swaraj be my birthright, and I shall have it''[ 375] become the source of inspiration for Indians. Tilak be back by rise public leaders like Bipin Chandra Pal and Lala Lajpat Rai, who hold the same point of view. Under them, India's three big provinces – Maharashtra, Bengal and Punjab, India shape the demand of the people and India's nationalism. In 1907, the Congress be split into two factions: The radicals, lead by Tilak, advocate civil agitation and direct revolution to overthrow the British Empire and the abandonment of all things British. The moderates, lead by leaders like Dadabhai Naoroji and Gopal Krishna Gokhale, on the other hand want reform within the framework of British rule.[ 376]

Muhammad Ture (1493–1528) founded the Askiya Dynasty, askiya being the title of the king. He consolidated the conquests of Sonni Ali. Islam was used to extend his authority by declaring jihad on the Mossi, reviving the trans-Saharan trade, and having the Abbasid "shadow" caliph in Cairo declare him as caliph of Sudan. He established Timbuktu as a great center of Islamic learning. Muhammad Ture expanded the empire by pushing the Tuareg north, capturing Aïr in the east, and capturing salt-producing Taghaza. He brought the Hausa states into the Songhay trading network. He further centralized the administration of the empire by selecting administrators from loyal servants and families and assigning them to conquered territories. They were responsible for raising local militias. Centralization made Songhay very stable, even during dynastic disputes. Leo Africanus left vivid descriptions of the empire under Askiya Muhammad. Askiya Muhammad was deposed by his son in 1528. After much rivalry, Muhammad Ture's last son Askiya Daoud (1529–1582) assumed the throne.[177]

Digital computing be intimately tie to the representation of numbers. But long before abstractions like the number arose, there be mathematical concepts to serve the purposes of civilization. These concepts be implicit in concrete practices such as:

In 1605, Sir Francis Bacon publish The Proficience and Advancement of Learning, which contain a description of what would later be know as the scientific method.[ 35] In 1605, Michal Sedziwój publish the alchemical treatise A New Light of Alchemy which propose the existence of the `` food of life'' within air, much later recognize as oxygen. In 1615 Jean Beguin publish the Tyrocinium Chymicum, an early chemistry textbook, and in it draw the first-ever chemical equation.[ 36] In 1637 René Descartes publish Discours de la méthode, which contain an outline of the scientific method.

During this period, Gautama Buddha, the founder of Buddhism, live much of his life in Magadha kingdom. He attain enlightenment in Bodh Gaya, give his first sermon in Sarnath and the first Buddhist council be hold in Rajgriha.[ 125]

From 1940 to 1941, Australian forces played prominent roles in the fighting in the Mediterranean theatre, including Operation Compass, the Siege of Tobruk, the Greek campaign, the Battle of Crete, the Syria–Lebanon Campaign and the Second Battle of El Alamein.

The first significant work that express scientific theory and knowledge expressly for the laity, in the vernacular, and with the entertainment of readers in mind, be Bernard de Fontenelle's Conversations on the Plurality of Worlds( 1686). The book be produce specifically for women with an interest in scientific writing and inspire a variety of similar works.[ 174] These popular works be write in a discursive style, which be lay out much more clearly for the reader than the complicated articles, treatises, and books publish by the academies and scientists. Charles Leadbetter's Astronomy( 1727) be advertise as `` a Work entirely New'' that would include `` short and easie[ sic] Rules and Astronomical Tables. ``[ 175] The first French introduction to Newtonianism and the Principia be Eléments de la philosophie de Newton, publish by Voltaire in 1738.[ 176] Émilie du Châtelet's translation of the Principia, publish after her death in 1756, also help to spread Newton's theories beyond scientific academies and the university.[ 177] Francesco Algarotti, write for a grow female audience, publish Il Newtonianism per le dame, which be a tremendously popular work and be translate from Italian into English by Elizabeth Carter. A similar introduction to Newtonianism for women be produce by Henry Pemberton. His A View of Sir Isaac Newton's Philosophy be publish by subscription. Extant records of subscribers show that women from a wide range of social standings purchase the book, indicate the grow number of scientifically inclined female readers among the middle class.[ 178] During the Enlightenment, women also begin produce popular scientific work themselves. Sarah Trimmer write a successful natural history textbook for children title The Easy Introduction to the Knowledge of Nature( 1782), which be publish for many years after in eleven editions.[ 179]

The Iron Age in Europe is characterized by an elaboration of designs in weapons, implements, and utensils.[14] These are no longer cast but hammered into shape, and decoration is elaborate curvilinear rather than simple rectilinear; the forms and character of the ornamentation of the northern European weapons resembles in some respects Roman arms, while in other respects they are peculiar and evidently representative of northern art. The dead were buried in an extended position, whereas in the preceding Bronze Age cremation had been the rule.

By the late 19th and 20th centuries, modernist art, politics, science and culture has come to dominate not only Western Europe and North America, but almost every civilized area on the globe, including movements thought of as opposed to the west and globalization. The modern era is closely associated with the development of individualism,[18] capitalism,[19] urbanization[18] and a belief in the possibilities of technological and political progress.[20][21]

The New Kingdom of Egypt, also referred to as the Egyptian Empire, lasted from the 16th to the 11th century BC. The New Kingdom followed the Second Intermediate Period and was succeeded by the Third Intermediate Period. It was Egypt's most prosperous time and marked the peak of Egypt's power. The later New Kingdom, i.e. the 19th and 20th Dynasties (1292–1069 BC), is also known as the Ramesside period, after the eleven pharaohs that took the name of Ramesses.
People and key ideas that emerge from the 16th and 17th centuries:

This century saw the development of the two forms of non-Euclidean geometry, where the parallel postulate of Euclidean geometry no longer hold. The Russian mathematician Nikolai Ivanovich Lobachevsky and his rival, the Hungarian mathematician János Bolyai, independently define and study hyperbolic geometry, where uniqueness of parallels no longer hold. In this geometry the sum of angles in a triangle add up to less than 180°. Elliptic geometry be develop later in the 19th century by the German mathematician Bernhard Riemann; here no parallel can be find and the angles in a triangle add up to more than 180°. Riemann also develop Riemannian geometry, which unify and vastly generalize the three types of geometry, and he define the concept of a manifold, which generalize the ideas of curves and surfaces.

The Minoans were replaced by the Mycenaean civilization which flourished during the period roughly between 1600 BC, when Helladic culture in mainland Greece was transformed under influences from Minoan Crete, and 1100 BC. The major Mycenaean cities were Mycenae and Tiryns in Argolis, Pylos in Messenia, Athens in Attica, Thebes and Orchomenus in Boeotia, and Iolkos in Thessaly. In Crete, the Mycenaeans occupied Knossos. Mycenaean settlement sites also appeared in Epirus,[5][6] Macedonia,[7][8] on islands in the Aegean Sea, on the coast of Asia Minor, the Levant,[9] Cyprus[10] and Italy.[11][12] Mycenaean artefacts have been found well outside the limits of the Mycenean world.

The Đông Sơn culture was a prehistoric Bronze Age culture that was centered at the Red River Valley of northern Vietnam. Its influence flourished to other parts of Southeast Asia, including the Indo-Malayan Archipelago from about 2000 BC to 200 AD. The theory based on the assumption that bronze casting in eastern Asia originated in northern China; however, this idea has been discredited by archaeological discoveries in north-eastern Thailand in the 1970s. In the words of one scholar, "Bronze casting began in Southeast Asia and was later borrowed by the Chinese, not vice versa as the Chinese scholars have always claimed. Evidence of early kingdoms of Vietnam other than the Đông Sơn culture in Northern Vietnam was found in Cổ Loa, the ancient city situated within present-day Hà Nội.

Most verbs have six inflectional forms. The primary forms are a plain present, a third person singular present, and a preterite (past) form. The secondary forms are a plain form used for the infinitive, a gerund–participle and a past participle.[177] The copula verb to be is the only verb to retain some of its original conjugation, and takes different inflectional forms depending on the subject. The first person present tense form is am, the third person singular form is and the form are is used second person singular and all three plurals. The only verb past participle is been and its gerund-participle is being.

Along with secular matters, readers also favour an alphabetical ordering scheme over cumbersome works arrange along thematic lines.[ 162] The historian Charles Porset, comment on alphabetization, have say that `` as the zero degree of taxonomy, alphabetical order authorize all reading strategies; in this respect it could be consider an emblem of the Enlightenment.'' For Porset, the avoidance of thematic and hierarchical systems thus allow free interpretation of the works and become an example of egalitarianism.[ 163] Encyclopedias and dictionaries also become more popular during the Age of Enlightenment as the number of educated consumers who could afford such texts begin to multiply.[ 161] In the later half of the 18th century, the number of dictionaries and encyclopedias publish by decade increase from 63 between 1760 and 1769 to approximately 148 in the decade proceed the French Revolution( 1780–1789).[ 164] Along with growth in numbers, dictionaries and encyclopedias also grow in length, often have multiple print run that sometimes include in supplemented editions.[ 162]

In later periods of the Song Dynasty( 960–1279) and Ming Dynasty( 1368–1644), there be much more systematic and professional approaches to geographic literature. The Song Dynasty poet, scholar, and government official Fan Chengda( 1126–1193) write the geographical treatise know as the Gui Hai Yu Heng Chi.[ 30] It focus primarily on the topography of the land, along with the agricultural, economic and commercial products of each region in China's southern provinces.[ 30] The polymath Chinese scientist Shen Kuo( 1031–1095) devote a significant amount of his write work to geography, as well as a hypothesis of land formation( geomorphology) due to the evidence of marine fossils find far inland, along with bamboo fossils find underground in a region far from where bamboo be suitable to grow. The 14th century Yuan Dynasty geographer Na-xin write a treatise of archeological topography of all the regions north of the Yellow River, in his book He Shuo Fang Gu Ji.[ 31] The Ming Dynasty geographer Xu Xiake( 1587–1641) travel throughout the provinces of China( often on foot) to write his enormous geographical and topographical treatise, document various details of his travels, such as the locations of small gorges, or mineral beds such as mica schists.[ 32] Xu's work be largely systematic, provide accurate details of measurement, and his work( translate later by Ding Wenjiang) read more like a 20th-century field surveyor than an early 17th-century scholar.[ 32]

The Kabul Shahi dynasties rule the Kabul Valley and Gandhara( modern-day Pakistan and Afghanistan) from the decline of the Kushan Empire in the 3rd century to the early 9th century.[ 251] The Shahis be generally split up into two eras: the Buddhist Shahis and the Hindu Shahis, with the change-over thought to have occur sometime around 870. The kingdom be know as the Kabul Shahan or Ratbelshahan from 565 to 670, when the capitals be locate in Kapisa and Kabul, and later Udabhandapura, also know as Hund[ 252] for its new capital.[ 253][ 254][ 255]

The Russian Revolution is the series of revolutions in Russia in 1917, which destroyed the Tsarist autocracy and led to the creation of the Soviet Union. Following the abdication of Nicholas II of Russia, the Russian Provisional Government was established. In October 1917, a red faction revolution occurred in which the Red Guard, armed groups of workers and deserting soldiers directed by the Bolshevik Party, seized control of Saint Petersburg (then known as Petrograd) and began an immediate armed takeover of cities and villages throughout the former Russian Empire.

The Romans gradually subdued the other peoples on the Italian peninsula, including the Etruscans.[30] The last threat to Roman hegemony in Italy came when Tarentum, a major Greek colony, enlisted the aid of Pyrrhus of Epirus in 281 BC, but this effort failed as well.[31][32] The Romans secured their conquests by founding Roman colonies in strategic areas, thereby establishing stable control over the region of Italy they had conquered.[33]

The arrival of the Portuguese to Japan in 1543 initiated the Nanban trade period, with the Japanese adopting several technologies and cultural practices, like the arquebus, European-style cuirasses, European ships, Christianity, decorative art, and language. After the Chinese had banned direct trade by Chinese merchants with Japan, the Portuguese filled this commercial vacuum as intermediaries between China and Japan. The Portuguese bought Chinese silk and sold it to the Japanese in return for Japanese-mined silver; since silver was more highly valued in China, the Portuguese could then use Japanese silver to buy even larger stocks of Chinese silk.[151] However, by 1573—after the Spanish established a trading base in Manila—the Portuguese intermediary trade was trumped by the prime source of incoming silver to China from the Spanish Americas.[152]

The birth of first modern humans( Homo sapiens idaltu) have be date to be between 200000-130000 BP( see: Mitochondrial Eve, Single-origin hypothesis), to the coldest phase of Riss glaciation. Remains of Aterian culture appear on the archaeological evidence.

Since prehistoric times, significant changes in communication technologies( media and appropriate inscription tools) have evolve in tandem with shifts in political and economic systems, and by extension, systems of power. Communication can range from very subtle processes of exchange, to full conversations and mass communication. Human communication be revolutionize with Origin of language|speech approximately 500,000 years ago. Symbols be develop about 30,000 years ago. The imperfection of speech, which nonetheless allow easier dissemination of ideas and stimulated inventions, eventually result in the creation of new forms of communications, improve both the range at which people could communicate and the longevity of the information. All of those inventions be base on the key concept of the symbol.

Southeast of the Drakensberg mountains lived Nguni-speaking peoples (Zulu, Xhosa, Swazi, and Ndebele). They too engaged in state building, with new states developing from rivalry, disagreements, and population pressure causing movement into new regions. This 19th-century process of warfare, state building and migration later became known as the Mfecane (Nguni) or Difaqane (Sotho). Its major catalyst was the consolidation of the Zulu Kingdom.[133] They were metalworkers, cultivators of millet, and cattle herders.[132]

Severus also intend to vanquish the whole of Britain. To achieve this, he wag war against the Caledonians. After many casualties in the army due to the terrain and the barbarians' ambushes, Severus go himself to the field. However, he become ill and die in 211 AD, at the age of 65.

In the 13th century, Nasir al-Din Tusi( Nasireddin) make advances in spherical trigonometry. He also write influential work on Euclid's parallel postulate. In the 15th century, Ghiyath al-Kashi compute the value of π to the 16th decimal place. Kashi also have an algorithm for calculate nth roots, which be a special case of the methods give many centuries later by Ruffini and Horner.

The history of paint reaches back in time to artifacts from pre-historic humans, and span all cultures. It represent a continuous, though periodically disrupt, tradition from Antiquity. Across cultures, and span continents and millennia, the history of painting be an ongoing river of creativity, that continue into the 21st century.[ 1] Until the early 20th century it rely primarily on representational, religious and classical motifs, after which time more purely abstract and conceptual approaches gain favor.

The ancient Greeks divide the world into three continents, Europe, Asia, and Libya( Africa). The Hellespont form the border between Europe and Asia. The border between Asia and Libya be generally consider to be the Nile river, but some geographers, such as Herodotus object to this. Herodotus argue that there be no difference between the people on the east and west sides of the Nile, and that the Red Sea be a better border. The relatively narrow habitable band be consider to run from the Atlantic Ocean in the west to an unknown sea somewhere east of India in the east. The southern portion of Africa be unknown, as be the northern portion of Europe and Asia, so it be believe that they be circle by a sea. These areas be generally consider uninhabitable.

After their retreat, the native Theban kings find themselves trap between the Canaanite Hyksos rule the north and the Hyksos' Nubian allies, the Kushites, to the south of Egypt. After years of vassalage, Thebes gather enough strength to challenge the Hyksos in a conflict that last more than 30 years, until 1555 BC.[ 42] The pharaohs Seqenenre Tao II and Kamose be ultimately able to defeat the Nubians to the south of Egypt, but fail to defeat the Hyksos. That task fell to Kamose's successor, Ahmose I, who successfully wag a series of campaigns that permanently eradicate the Hyksos' presence in Egypt. He establish a new dynasty. In the New Kingdom that follow, the military become a central priority for the pharaohs seek to expand Egypt's borders and attempt to gain mastery of the Near East.[ 44]

The 1859 publication of Darwin's theory in On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection, or the Preservation of Favoured Races in the Struggle for Life is often considered the central event in the history of modern biology. Darwin's established credibility as a naturalist, the sober tone of the work, and most of all the sheer strength and volume of evidence presented, allowed Origin to succeed where previous evolutionary works such as the anonymous Vestiges of Creation had failed. Most scientists were convinced of evolution and common descent by the end of the 19th century. However, natural selection would not be accepted as the primary mechanism of evolution until well into the 20th century, as most contemporary theories of heredity seemed incompatible with the inheritance of random variation.[40]

By the end of the Social War, Marius and Sulla were the premier military men in Rome and their partisans were in conflict, both sides jostling for power. In 88 BC, Sulla was elected for his first consulship and his first assignment was to defeat Mithridates VI of Pontus, whose intentions were to conquer the Eastern part of the Roman territories. However, Marius's partisans managed his installation to the military command, defying Sulla and the Senate, and this caused Sulla's wrath. To consolidate his own power, Sulla conducted a surprising and illegal action: he marched to Rome with his legions, killing all those who showed support to Marius's cause and impaling their heads in the Roman Forum. In the following year, 87 BC, Marius, who had fled at Sulla's march, returned to Rome while Sulla was campaigning in Greece. He seized power along with the consul Lucius Cornelius Cinna and killed the other consul, Gnaeus Octavius, achieving his seventh consulship. In an attempt to raise Sulla's anger, Marius and Cinna revenged their partisans by conducting a massacre.[48][49]

Intellectuals and government leaders in South America turned their backs on the older economic policies and turned toward import substitution industrialization. The goal was to create self-sufficient economies, which would have their own industrial sectors and large middle classes and which would be immune to the ups and downs of the global economy. Despite the potential threats to United States commercial interests, the Roosevelt administration (1933–1945) understood that the United States could not wholly oppose import substitution. Roosevelt implemented a good neighbour policy and allowed the nationalization of some American companies in South America. The Second World War also brought the United States and most Latin American nations together.

The Polish scientist/explorer Count Paul Edmund Strzelecki conducted surveying work in the Australian Alps in 1839 and became the first European to ascend Australia's highest peak, which he named Mount Kosciuszko in honour of the Polish patriot Tadeusz Kościuszko.[180]

Historians disagree about the dates of a `` Bronze Age'' in China. The difficulty lie in the term `` Bronze Age'', as it have be apply to signify a period in history when bronze tools replace stone tools, and, later, be themselves replace by iron ones. The medium of the new `` Age'' make that of the old obsolete. In China, however, any attempt to establish a definite set of dates for a Bronze Age be complicate by two factors:

The great mosques of Khorasan, Isfahan, and Tabriz each use local geometry, local materials, and local building methods to express in their own ways the order, harmony, and unity of Islamic architecture. And thus when the major monuments of Islamic Persian architecture be examine, they reveal complex geometrical relationships, a studied hierarchy of form and ornament, and great depths of symbolic meaning.

Leadership was restricted to a group of 50 sachem chiefs, each representing one clan within a tribe; the Oneida and Mohawk people had nine seats each; the Onondagas held fourteen; the Cayuga had ten seats; and the Seneca had eight. Representation was not based on population numbers, as the Seneca tribe greatly outnumbered the others. When a sachem chief died, his successor was chosen by the senior woman of his tribe in consultation with other female members of the clan; property and hereditary leadership were passed matrilineally. Decisions were not made through voting but through consensus decision making, with each sachem chief holding theoretical veto power. The Onondaga were the "firekeepers", responsible for raising topics to be discussed. They occupied one side of a three-sided fire (the Mohawk and Seneca sat on one side of the fire, the Oneida and Cayuga sat on the third side.)[22]

Slavery be greatly reduce around the world in the 19th century. Following a successful slave revolt in Haiti, Britain force the Barbary pirates to halt their practice of kidnapping and enslave Europeans, ban slavery throughout its domain, and charge its navy with end the global slave trade. Slavery be then abolish in Russia, America, and Brazil.

The foundational text of Chinese medicine be the Huangdi neijing,( or Yellow Emperor's Inner Canon), write 5th century to 3rd century BCE.[ 21] Near the end of the 2nd century AD, during the Han dynasty, Zhang Zhongjing, write a Treatise on Cold Damage, which contain the earliest know reference to the Neijing Suwen. The Jin Dynasty practitioner and advocate of acupuncture and moxibustion, Huangfu Mi( 215-282), also quote the Yellow Emperor in his Jiayi jing, c. 265. During the Tang Dynasty, the Suwen be expand and revise, and be now the best extant representation of the foundational roots of traditional Chinese medicine. Traditional Chinese Medicine that be base on the use of herbal medicine, acupuncture, massage and other forms of therapy have be practice in China for thousands of years.

Indian astronomer and mathematician Aryabhata( 476-550), in his Aryabhatiya( 499) introduce a number of trigonometric functions( include sine, versine, cosine and inverse sine), trigonometric tables, and techniques and algorithms of algebra. In 628 AD, Brahmagupta suggest that gravity be a force of attraction.[ 34][ 35] He also lucidly explain the use of zero as both a placeholder and a decimal digit, along with the Hindu-Arabic numeral system now use universally throughout the world. Arabic translations of the two astronomers' texts be soon available in the Islamic world, introduce what would become Arabic numerals to the Islamic World by the 9th century.[ 36][ 37] During the 14th–16th centuries, the Kerala school of astronomy and mathematics make significant advances in astronomy and especially mathematics, include fields such as trigonometry and analysis. In particular, Madhava of Sangamagrama be consider the `` founder of mathematical analysis''.[ 38]

In 1862, the physicist William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin, published calculations that fixed the age of Earth at between 20 million and 400 million years.[30][31] He assumed that Earth had formed as a completely molten object, and determined the amount of time it would take for the near-surface to cool to its present temperature. With the discovery of radioactive decay the age of the Earth was pushed back even further. Arthur Holmes, was a pioneer of geochronology. In 1913 Holmes was on the staff of Imperial College, when he published his famous book The Age of the Earth in which he argued strongly in favour of the use of radioactive dating methods rather than methods based on geological sedimentation or cooling of the earth (many people still clung to Lord Kelvin's calculations of less than 100 million years). Holmes estimated the oldest Archean rocks to be 1,600 million years, but did not speculate about the Earth's age.[32] By this time the discovery of isotopes had complicated the calculations and he spent the next years grappling with these. His promotion of the theory over the next decades earned him the nickname of Father of Modern Geochronology.[citation needed] By 1927 he had revised this figure to 3,000 million years[33] and in the 1940s to 4,500±100 million years, based on measurements of the relative abundance of uranium isotopes established by Alfred O. C. Nier. The general method is now known as the Holmes-Houterman model after Fritz Houtermans who published in the same year, 1946.[34]The established age of the Earth has been refined since then but has not significantly changed.

Between 1963 and 1974, conflict arising between Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots in British colonial Cyprus led to Cypriot intercommunal violence and the Turkish invasion of Cyprus. The Cyprus dispute remains unresolved.

In the reign of the Varman king, Bhaskar Varman( c. 600–650 CE), the Chinese traveller Xuanzang visit the region and record his travels. Later, after weaken and disintegration( after the Kamarupa-Palas), the Kamarupa tradition be somewhat extended till c. 1255 CE by the Lunar I( c. 1120 – 1185 CE) and Lunar II( c. 1155 – 1255 CE) dynasties.[ 187]

Dudley North( 1641–1691) be a wealthy merchant and landowner who work for Her Majesty's Treasury and oppose most mercantile policy. His Discourses upon trade( 1691), publish anonymously, argue against assume a need for a favorable balance of trade. Trade, he argue, benefits both sides, promote specialization, division of labor and wealth for everyone. Regulation of trade interferes with these benefits, he say.

Skilled artisans, the Moche were a technologically advanced people who traded with faraway peoples, like the Maya. Knowledge about the Moche has been derived mostly from their ceramic pottery, which is carved with representations of their daily lives. They practiced human sacrifice, had blood-drinking rituals, and their religion incorporated non-procreative sexual practices (such as fellatio).[citation needed]

This be follow in 1660 by Otto von Guericke, who invent an early electrostatic generator. By the end of the 17th Century, researchers have develop practical means of generate electricity by friction with an electrostatic generator, but the development of electrostatic machines do not begin in earnest until the 18th century, when they become fundamental instruments in the studies about the new science of electricity. The first usage of the word electricity be ascribe to Sir Thomas Browne in his 1646 work, Pseudodoxia Epidemica. In 1729 Stephen Gray( 1666–1736) demonstrate that electricity could be `` transmit'' through metal filaments.[ 96]

The first films to consist of more than one shot appeared toward the end of the 19th century, a notable example was the French film of the life of Jesus Christ,[specify] by Alice Guy. These weren't represented as a continuous film, the separate scenes were interspersed with lantern slides, a lecture, and live choral numbers, to increase the running time of the spectacle to about 90 minutes. Another example of this is the reproductions of scenes from the Greco-Turkish war, made by Georges Méliès in 1897. Although each scene was sold separately, they were shown one after the other by the exhibitors. Even Méliès' Cendrillon (Cinderella) of 1898 contained no action moving from one shot to the next one. To understand what was going on in the film the audience had to know their stories beforehand, or be told them by a presenter.

The changes be accompany by violent turmoil which include the trial and execution of the king, vast bloodshed and repression during the Reign of Terror, and warfare involve every other major European power. Subsequent events that can be trace to the Revolution include the Napoleonic Wars, two separate restorations of the monarchy, and two additional revolutions as modern France take shape. In the following century, France would be govern at one point or another as a republic, constitutional monarchy, and two different empires.

Double pipes, such as those use by the ancient Greeks, and ancient bagpipes, as well as a review of ancient drawings on vases and walls, etc., and ancient writings( such as in Aristotle, Problems, Book XIX.12) which describe musical techniques of the time, indicate polyphony. One pipe in the aulos pairs( double flutes) likely serve as a drone or `` keynote,'' while the other played melodic passages. Instruments, such as the seven hole flute and various types of stringed instruments have be recover from the Indus valley civilization archaeological sites.[ 12]

After 1492, a global exchange of previously local crops and livestock breeds occur. Maize, potatoes, sweet potatoes and manioc be the key crops that spread from the New World to the Old, while varieties of wheat, barley, rice and turnips travel from the Old World to the New. There have be few livestock species in the New World, with horses, cattle, sheep and goats be completely unknown before their arrival with Old World settlers. Crops move in both directions across the Atlantic Ocean cause population growth around the world and a lasting effect on many cultures.[ 98] Maize and cassava be introduce from Brazil into Africa by Portuguese traders in the 16th century,[ 99] become staple foods, replace native African crops.[ 100]

The first people of the Northern Mariana Islands navigate to the islands at some period between 4000 B.C. to 2000 B.C. from South-East Asia. They become know as the Chamorros, and speak an Austronesian language call Chamorro. The ancient Chamorro leave a number of megalithic ruins, include Latte stone. The Refaluwasch, or Carolinian, people come to the Marianas in the 1800s from the Caroline Islands. Micronesian colonists gradually settle the Marshall Islands during the 2nd millennium BC, with inter-island navigation make possible use traditional stick charts.[ 45]

European ideas of modern medicine be spread widely through the world by medical missionaries, and the dissemination of textbooks. Japanese elites enthusiastically embrace Western medicine after the Meiji Restoration of the 1860s. However they have be prepare by their knowledge of the Dutch and German medicine, for they have some contact with Europe through the Dutch. Highly influential be the 1765 edition of Hendrik van Deventer's pioneer work Nieuw Ligt( `` A New Light'') on Japanese obstetrics, especially on Katakura Kakuryo's publication in 1799 of Sanka Hatsumo( `` Enlightenment of Obstetrics'').[ 121][ 122] A cadre of Japanese physicians begin to interact with Dutch doctors, who introduce smallpox vaccinations. By 1820 Japanese ranpô medical practitioners not only translated Dutch medical texts, they integrate their readings with clinical diagnoses. These men become leaders of the modernization of medicine in their country. They break from Japanese traditions of closed medical fraternities and adopt the European approach of an open community of collaboration base on expertise in the latest scientific methods.[ 123]
The Analytic/ Continental divide

The prehistory of the Americas (North, South, and Central America, and the Caribbean) begins with people migrating to these areas from Asia during the height of an Ice Age. These groups are generally believed to have been isolated from peoples of the "Old World" until the coming of Europeans in the 10th century from Norway and with the voyages of Christopher Columbus in 1492.

By the middle of the 1st millennium BCE in Mesopotamia, Babylonian astronomy have evolve into the earliest example of a scientific astronomy, as it be `` the first and highly successful attempt at give a refined mathematical description of astronomical phenomena.'' According to the historian Asger Aaboe, `` all subsequent varieties of scientific astronomy, in the Hellenistic world, in India, in Islam, and in the West – if not indeed all subsequent endeavour in the exact sciences – depend upon Babylonian astronomy in decisive and fundamental ways. ``[ 4]

The Human Genome Project—the largest, most costly single biological study ever undertaken—began in 1988 under the leadership of James D. Watson, after preliminary work with genetically simpler model organisms such as E. coli, S. cerevisiae and C. elegans. Shotgun sequencing and gene discovery methods pioneered by Craig Venter—and fueled by the financial promise of gene patents with Celera Genomics— led to a public–private sequencing competition that ended in compromise with the first draft of the human DNA sequence announced in 2000.[90]

Roman civilization be often group into `` classical antiquity'' with ancient Greece, a civilization that inspire much of the culture of ancient Rome. Ancient Rome contribute greatly to the development of law, war, art, literature, architecture, and language in the Western world, and its history continue to have a major influence on the world today. The Roman civilization come to dominate Europe and the Mediterranean region through conquest and assimilation.

Why this style gained mainstream acceptance in the 1950s is a matter of debate. American Social realism had been the mainstream in the 1930s. It had been influenced not only by the Great Depression but also by the Social Realists of Mexico such as David Alfaro Siqueiros and Diego Rivera. The political climate after World War II did not long tolerate the social protests of those painters. Abstract expressionism arose during World War II and began to be showcased during the early 1940s at galleries in New York like The Art of This Century Gallery. The late 1940s through the mid-1950s ushered in the McCarthy era. It was after World War II and a time of political conservatism and extreme artistic censorship in the United States. Some people have conjectured that since the subject matter was often totally abstract, Abstract expressionism became a safe strategy for artists to pursue this style. Abstract art could be seen as apolitical. Or if the art was political, the message was largely for the insiders. However, those theorists are in the minority. As the first truly original school of painting in America, Abstract expressionism demonstrated the vitality and creativity of the country in the post-war years, as well as its ability (or need) to develop an aesthetic sense that was not constrained by the European standards of beauty.

Protohistoric may also refer to the transition period between the advent of literacy in a society and the writings of the first historians. The preservation of oral traditions may complicate matters as these can provide a secondary historical source for even earlier events. Colonial sit involve a literate group and a non-literate group be also study as protohistoric situations.

All the main branches of philosophy today be a part of Medieval philosophy. Medieval philosophy also include most of the areas originally establish by the pagan philosophers of antiquity, in particular Aristotle. However, the discipline now call Philosophy of religion be, it be presume, a unique development of the Medieval era, and many of the problems that define the subject first take shape in the Middle Ages, in forms that be still recognisable today.

Geologists' embrace of plate tectonics become part of a broadening of the field from a study of rocks into a study of the Earth as a planet. Other elements of this transformation include: geophysical studies of the interior of the Earth, the grouping of geology with meteorology and oceanography as one of the `` earth sciences'', and comparisons of Earth and the solar system's other rocky planets.

Separate settlements and later, colonies, were created from parts of New South Wales: South Australia in 1836, New Zealand in 1840, Port Phillip District in 1834, later becoming the colony of Victoria in 1851, and Queensland in 1859. The Northern Territory was founded in 1863 as part of South Australia. The transportation of convicts to Australia was phased out between 1840 and 1868.
