The expanding French and British colonies were contending for control of the western, or interior, territories. Whenever the European countries went to war, there were actions within and by these colonies although the dates of the conflict did not necessarily exactly coincide with those of the larger conflicts.

In Southern American English, the largest American `` accent group'' outside of GA,[ 249] rhoticity now strongly prevail, replace the region's historical non-rhotic prestige,[ 250] though social variation may still apply.[ 251][ 252] Southern accents be colloquially describe as a `` drawl'' or `` twang,''[ 253] be recognise most readily by the Southern Vowel Shift that begin with glide-deleting in the /aɪ/ vowel( e.g. pronounce spy almost like spa), the `` Southern breaking'' of several front pure vowels into a gliding vowel or even two syllables( e.g. pronounce the word `` press'' almost like `` pray-us''),[ 254] the pin–pen merger, and other distinctive phonologial, grammatical, and lexical features, many of which be actually recent developments of the 19th century or later.[ 255]

Friction between Britain and the Latin American states continued into the post war period. Royal Navy warships were despatched in 1948 to prevent naval incursions and in 1952, an Argentine shore party at Hope Bay (the British Base "D", established there in 1945, came up against the Argentine Esperanza Base, est. 1952) fired a machine gun over the heads of a British Antarctic Survey team unloading supplies from the John Biscoe. The Argentines later extended a diplomatic apology, saying that there had been a misunderstanding and that the Argentine military commander on the ground had exceeded his authority.

Romanesque art, especially metalwork, be at its most sophisticated in Mosan art, in which distinct artistic personalities include Nicholas of Verdun( d. 1205) become apparent, and an almost classical style be see in works such as a font at Liège,[ 243] contrast with the writhe animals of the exactly contemporary Gloucester Candlestick. Large illuminate bibles and psalters be the typical forms of luxury manuscripts, and wall-painting flourish in churches, often follow a scheme with a Last Judgement on the west wall, a Christ in Majesty at the east end, and narrative biblical scenes down the nave, or in the best surviving example, at Saint-Savin-sur-Gartempe, on the barrel-vaulted roof.[ 244]

There be certain architectural features that be reserve solely for buildings build for the Emperor of China. One example be the use of yellow roof tiles; yellow have be the Imperial color, yellow roof tiles still adorn most of the buildings within the Forbidden City. The Temple of Heaven, however, use blue roof tiles to symbolize the sky. The roofs be almost invariably support by brackets, a feature share only with the largest of religious buildings. The wooden columns of the buildings, as well as the surface of the walls, tend to be red in colour.

The dynasty continue to flourish under the rule of Empress Wu Zetian, the only empress regnant in Chinese history, and reach its zenith during the long reign of Emperor Xuanzong, who oversee an empire that stretch from the Pacific to the Aral Sea with at least 50 million people. There be vibrant artistic and cultural creations, include works of the greatest Chinese poets, Li Bai, and Du Fu.

Marie Skłodowska-Curie be a Polish-born French physicist and chemist who be famous for her pioneering research on radioactivity. She and her husband be consider to have lay the cornerstone of the nuclear age with their research on radioactivity. Marie be fascinate with the work of Henri Becquerel, a French physicist who discover in 1896 that uranium casts off rays similar to the X-rays discover by Wilhelm Röntgen. Marie Curie begin study uranium in late 1897 and theorize, accord to a 1904 article she write for Century magazine, `` that the emission of rays by the compounds of uranium be a property of the metal itself—that it be an atomic property of the element uranium independent of its chemical or physical state.'' Curie take Becquerel's work a few steps further, conduct her own experiments on uranium rays. She discover that the rays remain constant, no matter the condition or form of the uranium. The rays, she theorize, come from the element's atomic structure. This revolutionary idea create the field of atomic physics and the Curies coin the word radioactivity to describe the phenomena.

The continent become a battlefield of the Cold War in the late 20th century. Some democratically elect governments of Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Uruguay and Paraguay be overthrow or displace by military dictatorships in the 1960s and 1970s. To curtail opposition, their governments detain tens of thousands of political prisoners, many of whom be torture and/or kill on inter-state collaboration. Economically, they begin a transition to neoliberal economic policies. They place their own actions within the US Cold War doctrine of `` National Security'' against internal subversion. Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, Peru suffer from an internal conflict. South America, like many other continents, become a battlefield for the superpowers during the Cold War in the late 20th century. In the postwar period, the expansion of communism become the greatest political issue for both the United States and governments in the region. The start of the Cold War force governments to choose between the United States and the Soviet Union.

Many of the leading universities associated with Enlightenment progressive principles were located in northern Europe, with the most renowned being the universities of Leiden, Göttingen, Halle, Montpellier, Uppsala and Edinburgh. These universities, especially Edinburgh, produced professors whose ideas had a significant impact on Britain's North American colonies and, later, the American Republic. Within the natural sciences, Edinburgh's medical also led the way in chemistry, anatomy and pharmacology.[182] In other parts of Europe, the universities and schools of France and most of Europe were bastions of traditionalism and were not hospitable to the Enlightenment. In France, the major exception was the medical university at Montpellier.[183]

The first medieval institutions generally considered to be universities were established in Italy, France, and England in the late 11th and the 12th centuries for the study of arts, law, medicine, and theology.[1] These universities evolved from much older Christian cathedral schools and monastic schools, and it is difficult to define the date on which they became true universities, although the lists of studia generalia for higher education in Europe held by the Vatican are a useful guide.

English pronouns conserve many traits of case and gender inflection. The personal pronouns retain a difference between subjective and objective case in most persons( I/me, he/him, she/her, we/us, they/them) as well as a gender and animateness distinction in the third person singular( distinguish he/she/it). The subjective case correspond to the Old English nominative case, and the objective case be use both in the sense of the previous accusative case( in the role of patient, or direct object of a transitive verb), and in the sense of the Old English dative case( in the role of a recipient or indirect object of a transitive verb).[ 168][ 169] Subjective case be use when the pronoun be the subject of a finite clause, and otherwise the objective case be use.[ 170] While grammarians such as Henry Sweet[ 171] and Otto Jespersen[ 172] note that the English cases do not correspond to the traditional Latin base system, some contemporary grammars, for example Huddleston& Pullum( 2002), retain traditional labels for the cases, call them nominative and accusative cases respectively.

Until the nineteenth century, the care of the insane be largely a communal and family responsibility rather than a medical one. The vast majority of the mentally ill be treat in domestic contexts with only the most unmanageable or burdensome likely to be institutionally confine.[ 129] This situation be transform radically from the late eighteenth century as, amid change cultural conceptions of madness, a new-found optimism in the curability of insanity within the asylum set emerge.[ 130] Increasingly, lunacy be perceive less as a physiological condition than as a mental and moral one[ 131] to which the correct response be persuasion, aim at inculcate internal restraint, rather than external coercion.[ 132] This new therapeutic sensibility, refer to as moral treatment, be epitomise in French physician Philippe Pinel's quasi-mythological unchaining of the lunatics of the Bicêtre Hospital in Paris[ 133] and realise in an institutional setting with the foundation in 1796 of the Quaker-run York Retreat in England.[ 9]

Dark Ages is a term of historical periodisation used to refer to a period of supposed cultural and economic deterioration, and scarcity of written record, usually being contrasted with the more recent times of the writer and with classical antiquity. Its original use referred to the Western European Middle Ages (roughly the 6th to 14th centuries), emphasising the perceived decline following the fall of the Roman Empire.[1][2][3]

Gold and silver be use as the most common form of money throughout history. In many languages, such as Spanish, French, and Italian, the word for silver be still directly relate to the word for money. Although gold and silver be commonly use to mint coins, other metals be use. For instance, Ancient Sparta mint coins from iron to discourage its citizens from engage in foreign trade.[ 71] In the early seventeenth century Sweden lack more precious metal and so produced `` plate money'', which be large slabs of copper approximately 50 cm or more in length and width, appropriately stamp with indications of their value.

The demographic decline due to the plague had economic consequences: the prices of food dropped and land values declined by 30 to 40% in most parts of Europe between 1350 and 1400.[39] Landholders faced a great loss, but for ordinary men and women it was a windfall. The survivors of the plague found not only that the prices of food were cheaper but also that lands were more abundant, and many of them inherited property from their dead relatives.

In 1933, Sir Ernest Scott, state the traditional view of the reasons for colonisation: `` It be clear that the only consideration which weigh seriously with the Pitt Government be the immediately pressing and practical one of find a suitable place for a convict settlement ``.[ 114] In the early 1960s, historian Geoffrey Blainey question the traditional view of foundation purely as a convict dump ground. His book The Tyranny of Distance[ 115] suggest ensure supplies of flax and timber after the loss of the American colonies may have also be motivations, and Norfolk Island be the key to the British decision. A number of historians respond and debate bring to light a large amount of additional source material on the reasons for settlement.[ 116] This have most recently be set out and discuss by Professor Alan Frost.[ 117]

Political science be a late arrival in terms of social sciences[ citation need]. However, the discipline have a clear set of antecedents such as moral philosophy, political philosophy, political economy, history, and other fields concern with normative determinations of what ought to be and with deduce the characteristics and functions of the ideal form of government. The roots of politics be in prehistory. In each historic period and in almost every geographic area, we can find someone study politics and increase political understanding.

First, the waves of Norse colonisation of northern parts of the British Isles in the 8th and 9th centuries put Old English into intense contact with Old Norse, a North Germanic language. Norse influence be strongest in the Northeastern varieties of Old English spoken in the Danelaw area around York, which be the centre of Norse colonisation; today these features be still particularly present in Scots and Northern English. However the centre of norsified English seem to have be in the Midlands around Lindsey, and after 920 CE when Lindsey be reincorporated into the Anglo-Saxon polity, Norse feature spread from there into English varieties that have not be in intense contact with Norse speakers. Some elements of Norse influence that persist in all English varieties today be the pronouns begin with th-( they, them, their) which replace the Anglo-Saxon pronouns with h-( hie, him, hera).[ 36]

Analytic philosophy come to dominate English-speaking countries in the 20th century. In the United States, United Kingdom, Canada, Scandinavia, Australia, and New Zealand, the overwhelming majority of university philosophy departments identify themselves as `` analytic'' departments.[ 12] The term generally refer to a broad philosophical tradition[ 13][ 14] characterize by an emphasis on clarity and argument( often achieve via modern formal logic and analysis of language) and a respect for the natural sciences.[ 15][ 16][ 17]

By contrast, the Dominican order, founded by St Dominic in 1215 placed more emphasis on the use of reason and made extensive use of the new Aristotelian sources derived from the East, and Moorish Spain. The great representatives of Dominican thinking in this period were Albertus Magnus and (especially) Thomas Aquinas, whose artful synthesis of Greek rationalism and Christian doctrine eventually came to define Catholic philosophy. Aquinas placed more emphasis on reason and argumentation, and was one of the first to use the new translation of Aristotle's metaphysical and epistemological writing. This was a significant departure from the Neoplatonic and Augustinian thinking that had dominated much of early Scholasticism. Aquinas showed how it was possible to incorporate much of the philosophy of Aristotle without falling into the "errors" of the Commentator Averroes.

The history of rail transportation dates back nearly 500 years, and include systems with man or horse power and rails of wood( or occasionally stone). This be usually for move coal from the mine down to a river, from where it could continue by boat, with a flanged wheel run on a rail. The use of cast iron plat as rails begin in the 1760s, and be follow by systems( plateways) where the flange be part of the rail. However, with the introduction of rolled wrought iron rails, these become obsolete.

The early part of the Palaeolithic is called the Lower Palaeolithic, which predates Homo sapiens, beginning with Homo habilis (and related species) and with the earliest stone tools, dated to around 2.5 million years ago.[10] Evidence of control of fire by early humans during the Lower Palaeolithic Era is uncertain and has at best limited scholarly support. The most widely accepted claim is that H. erectus or H. ergaster made fires between 790,000 and 690,000 BP (before the present period) in a site at Bnot Ya'akov Bridge, Israel. The use of fire enabled early humans to cook food, provide warmth, and have a light source at night.

The Roman Empire have its centre in the Mediterranean, control all the countries on its shores; the northern border be mark by the Rhine and Danube rivers. Under emperor Trajan( 2nd century AD) the empire reach its maximum expansion, control approximately 5,900,000 km2( 2,300,000 sq mi) of land surface, include Britain, Romania and parts of Mesopotamia. Pax Romana, a period of peace, civilisation and an efficient centralised government in the subject territories end in the 3rd century, when a series of civil wars undermine Rome's economic and social strength.

The oldest extant mathematical records from India be the Sulba Sutras( date variously between the 8th century BC and the 2nd century AD),[ 89] appendices to religious texts which give simple rules for construct altars of various shapes, such as squares, rectangles, parallelograms, and others.[ 90] As with Egypt, the preoccupation with temple functions points to an origin of mathematics in religious ritual.[ 89] The Sulba Sutras give methods for construct a circle with approximately the same area as a give square, which imply several different approximations of the value of π.[ 91][ 92] In addition, they compute the square root of 2 to several decimal places, list Pythagorean triples, and give a statement of the Pythagorean theorem.[ 93] All of these results be present in Babylonian mathematics, indicate Mesopotamian influence.[ 89] It be not know to what extent the Sulba Sutras influence later Indian mathematicians. As in China, there be a lack of continuity in Indian mathematics; significant advances be separate by long periods of inactivity.[ 89]

Juan Fernandez, sailing from Chile in 1576, claimed he had discovered the Southern Continent.[132] Luis Váez de Torres, a Galician navigator working for the Spanish Crown, proved the existence of a passage south of New Guinea, now known as Torres Strait. Pedro Fernandes de Queirós, a Portuguese navigator sailing for the Spanish Crown, saw a large island south of New Guinea in 1606, which he named La Australia del Espiritu Santo. He represented this to the King of Spain as the Terra Australis incognita. In fact, it was not Australia but an island in present-day Vanuatu.

The oldest known paintings are approximately 40,000 years old. José Luis Sanchidrián at the University of Cordoba, Spain, believes the paintings are more likely to have been painted by Neanderthals than early modern humans.[11][12][13] Images at the Chauvet cave in France are thought to be about 32,000 years old. They are engraved and painted using red ochre and black pigment and show horses, rhinoceros, lions, buffalo, mammoth or humans often hunting. There are examples of cave paintings all over the world—in France, India, Spain, Portugal, China, Australia etc.

Christian embassies be send as far as Karakorum during the Mongol invasions of Syria, from which they gain a greater understanding of the world.[ citation need] The first of these travelers be Giovanni da Pian del Carpine, dispatch by Pope Innocent IV to the Great Khan, who journey to Mongolia and back from 1241 to 1247.[ 18] About the same time, Russian prince Yaroslav of Vladimir, and subsequently his sons Alexander Nevsky and Andrey II of Vladimir, travel to the Mongolian capital. Though have strong political implications, their journeys leave no detailed accounts. Other travelers follow, like French André de Longjumeau and Flemish William of Rubruck, who reach China through Central Asia.[ 20] Marco Polo, a Venetian merchant, dictate an account of journeys throughout Asia from 1271 to 1295, describe be a guest at the Yuan Dynasty court of Kublai Khan in Travels, and it be read throughout Europe.[ 21]
Around 28,000 BC a new technology/culture appear in the western region of Europe: the Gravettian. This technology/culture have be theorise to have come with migrations of people from the Balkans.

Ancient Greek mathematics contributed many important developments to the field of mathematics, including the basic rules of geometry, the idea of formal mathematical proof, and discoveries in number theory, mathematical analysis, applied mathematics, and approached close to establishing integral calculus. The discoveries of several Greek mathematicians, including Pythagoras, Euclid, and Archimedes, are still used in mathematical teaching today.

Pictograms were used by various ancient cultures all over the world since around 9000 BC, when tokens marked with simple pictures began to be used to label basic farm produce, and become increasingly popular around 6000-5000 BC.

In China, the earliest known geographical Chinese write dates back to the 5th century BC, during the beginning of the Warring States period( 481 BC – 221 BC).[ 20] This work be the Yu Gong('Tribute of Yu') chapter of the Shu Jing or Book of Documents, which describe the traditional nine provinces of ancient China, their kinds of soil, their characteristic products and economic goods, their tributary goods, their trades and vocations, their state revenues and agricultural systems, and the various rivers and lakes list and place accordingly.[ 20] The nine provinces at the time of this geographical work be relatively small in size compare to those of modern China with the book's descriptions pertain to areas of the Yellow River, the lower valleys of the Yangtze and the plain between them as well as the Shandong peninsula and to the west the most northern parts of the Wei and Han Rivers along with the southern parts of modern-day Shanxi province.[ 20]

The role of seafood in the Norte Chico diet has been a subject of scholarly debate. In 1973, examining the Aspero region of Norte Chico, Michael E. Moseley contended that a maritime subsistence (seafood) economy had been the basis of society and its early flourishing. This theory, later termed "maritime foundation of Andean Civilization" was at odds with the general scholarly consensus that civilization arose as a result of intensive grain-based agriculture, as had been the case in the emergence of civilizations in northeast Africa (Egypt) and southwest Asia (Mesopotamia).

Mesoamerican architecture is the set of architectural traditions produced by pre-Columbian cultures and civilizations of Mesoamerica, (such as the Olmec, Maya, and Aztec) traditions which are best known in the form of public, ceremonial and urban monumental buildings and structures. The distinctive features of Mesoamerican architecture encompass a number of different regional and historical styles, which however are significantly interrelated. These styles developed throughout the different phases of Mesoamerican history as a result of the intensive cultural exchange between the different cultures of the Mesoamerican culture area through thousands of years. Mesoamerican architecture is mostly noted for its pyramids which are the largest such structures outside of Ancient Egypt.

Between 2001 and 2007 Australia's Pacific Solution policy transfer asylum seekers to several Pacific nations, include the Nauru detention centre. Australia, New Zealand and other nations take part in the Regional Assistance Mission to Solomon Islands from 2003 after a request for aid.

The transition out of the Stone Age occurred between 6000 BCE and 2500 BCE for much of humanity living in North Africa and Eurasia. The first evidence of human metallurgy dates to between the 5th and 6th millennium BCE in the archaeological sites of Majdanpek, Yarmovac, and Pločnik in modern-day Serbia (a copper axe from 5500 BCE belonging to the Vinca culture), though not conventionally considered part of the Chalcolithic or "Copper Age", this provides the earliest known example of copper metallurgy.[12] Note the Rudna Glava mine in Serbia. Ötzi the Iceman, a mummy from about 3300 BCE carried with him a copper axe and a flint knife.

The principles of homeopathy were first formulated in 1796, by German physician Samuel Hahnemann. At the time, mainstream medicine was a primitive affair and still made use of techniques such as bloodletting. Homeopathic medicine by contrast consisted of extremely diluted substances, which meant that patients basically received water. Compared to the damage often caused by conventional medicine, this was an improvement.[14] During the 1830s homeopathic institutions and schools spread across the USA and Europe.[15] Despite these early successes, homeopathy was not without its critics.[16] Its popularity was on the decline before the end of the 19th century, though it has been revived in the 20th century.

In agriculture, the increased usage of sheep with long-fibred wool allowed a stronger thread to be spun. In addition, the spinning wheel replaced the traditional distaff for spinning wool, tripling production.[315][AH] A less technological refinement that still greatly affected daily life was the use of buttons as closures for garments, which allowed for better fitting without having to lace clothing on the wearer.[317] Windmills were refined with the creation of the tower mill, allowing the upper part of the windmill to be spun around to face the direction from which the wind was blowing.[318] The blast furnace appeared around 1350 in Sweden, increasing the quantity of iron produced and improving its quality.[319] The first patent law in 1447 in Venice protected the rights of inventors to their inventions.[320]
In 1852, French Polynesia was granted partial internal autonomy; in 1984, the autonomy was extended. French Polynesia became a full overseas collectivity of France in 2004.

The intellectual basis of the Renaissance was its own invented version of humanism, derived from the rediscovery of classical Greek philosophy, such as that of Protagoras, who said that "Man is the measure of all things." This new thinking became manifest in art, architecture, politics, science and literature. Early examples were the development of perspective in oil painting and the recycled knowledge of how to make concrete. Although the invention of metal movable type sped the dissemination of ideas from the later 15th century, the changes of the Renaissance were not uniformly experienced across Europe.

The earliest known tool for use in computation was the abacus, and it was thought to have been invented in Babylon c. 2400 BC. Its original style of usage was by lines drawn in sand with pebbles. Abaci, of a more modern design, are still used as calculation tools today. This was the first known computer and most advanced system of calculation known to date - preceding Greek methods by 2,000 years.[citation needed]

Galileo was considered the father of observational astronomy. He was among the first to use a telescope to observe the sky and after constructing a 20x refractor telescope he discovered the four largest moons of Jupiter in 1610. This was the first observation of satellites orbiting another planet. He also found that our Moon had craters and observed (and correctly explained) sunspots. Galileo noted that Venus exhibited a full set of phases resembling lunar phases. Galileo argued that these observations supported the Copernican system and were, to some extent, incompatible with the favored model of the Earth at the center of the universe.[62] He may have even observed the planet Neptune in 1612 and 1613, over 200 years before it was discovered, but it is unclear if he was aware of what he was looking at.[63][64]

Similar to the Indian tradition, Chinese philology, Xiaoxue( 小學 `` elementary studies''), begin as an aid to understand classics in the Han dynasty( c. 3rd century BCE). Xiaoxue come to be divide into three branches: Xungu( 訓詁 `` exegesis''), Wenzi( 文字 `` script[ analysis]'') and Yinyun( 音韻 ``[ study of] sounds'') and reach its golden age in the 17th century CE( Qing Dynasty). The glossary Erya( c. 3rd century BCE), comparable to the Indian Nighantu, be regard as the first linguistic work in China. Shuowen Jiezi( c. 2nd century BCE), the first Chinese dictionary, classify Chinese characters by radicals, a practice that would be follow by most subsequent lexicographers. Two more pioneering works produce during the Han Dynasty be Fangyan, the first Chinese work concern dialects, and Shiming, devote to etymology.

In the early 21st century, the Ansari X Prize competition was set up to help jump start private spaceflight, which was won by Space Ship One in 2004, becoming the first spaceship not funded by a government agency.[4]
In classical times, these inquiries were systematized in six schools of philosophy. Some of the questions asked were:

In 1950, Britain's National Physical Laboratory complete Pilot ACE, a small scale programmable computer, base on Turing's philosophy. With an operate speed of 1 MHz, the Pilot Model ACE be for some time the fastest computer in the world.[ 11][ 16] Turing's design for ACE have much in common with today's RISC architectures and it call for a high-speed memory of roughly the same capacity as an early Macintosh computer, which be enormous by the standards of his day.[ 11] Had Turing's ACE be build as plan and in full, it would have be in a different league from the other early computers.[ 11]

The period in Greek history from the death of Alexander the Great until the rise of the Roman empire and its conquest of Egypt in 30 BC be know as the Hellenistic period. The name derive from the Greek word Hellenistes( `` the Greek speaking ones''), and describe the spread of Greek culture into the non-Greek world follow the conquests of Alexander and the rise of his successors.

Examples of Chalcolithic cultures in Europe include Vila Nova de São Pedro and Los Millares on the Iberian Peninsula.[ 8] Pottery of the Beaker people have be find at both sites, date to several centuries after copper-working begin there. The Beaker culture appear to have spread copper and bronze technologies in Europe, along with Indo-European languages.[ 9] The term `` Chalcolithic'' be not generally use by British prehistorians, who disagree whether it apply in the British context.[ 10]

Experimental evidence support most of the propositions in his Book of Optics and ground his theories of vision, light and colour, as well as his research in catoptrics and dioptrics. His legacy be elaborate through the'reforming' of his Optics by Kamal al-Din al-Farisi( d. c. 1320) in the latter's Kitab Tanqih al-Manazir( The Revision of[ Ibn al-Haytham's] Optics).[ 29][ 30]

The worship of Moneta is recorded by Livy with the temple built in the time of Rome 413 (123); a temple consecrated to the same god was built in the earlier part of the fourth century (perhaps the same temple).[22][23][24] The temple contained the mint of Rome for a period of four centuries.[25][26]

Individual ideas and accomplishments be among the most famous aspects of science, both internally and in larger society. Breakthrough figures like Sir Isaac Newton or Albert Einstein be often celebrate as geniuses and heroes of science. Popularizers of science, include the news media and scientific biographers, contribute to this phenomenon. But many scientific historians emphasize the collective aspects of scientific discovery, and de-emphasize the importance of the `` Eureka!'' moment.

Following the journeys of Marco Polo, interest in geography spread throughout Europe. From around c. 1400, the writings of Ptolemy and his successors provided a systematic framework to tie together and portray geographical information. The European global exploration started in the early 15th century with the first Portuguese expeditions to Africa and India, as well as the Discovery of America by Spain in 1492 and continued with a series of European naval expeditions across the Atlantic and later the Pacific and Russian expeditions to Siberia until the 18th century. European overseas expansion led to the rise of colonial empires, with the contact between the Old and New Worlds producing the Columbian Exchange: a wide transfer of plants, animals, foods, human populations (including slaves), communicable diseases and culture between the continents. These great voyages of exploration in 16th and 17th centuries revived a desire for both accurate geographic detail, and more solid theoretical foundations. The Geographia Generalis by Bernhardus Varenius and Gerardus Mercator's world map are prime examples of the new breed of scientific geography.
Libyan Berber control began to erode as a rival native dynasty in the delta arose under Leontopolis. Also, the Nubians of the Kushites threatened Egypt from the lands to the south.[57]

In the south lay the Peloponnese, itself consisting of the regions of Laconia (southeast), Messenia (southwest), Elis (west), Achaia (north), Korinthia (northeast), Argolis (east), and Arcadia (center). These names survive to the present day as regional units of modern Greece, though with somewhat different boundaries. Mainland Greece to the north, nowadays known as Central Greece, consisted of Aetolia and Acarnania in the west, Locris, Doris, and Phocis in the center, while in the east lay Boeotia, Attica, and Megaris. Northeast lay Thessaly, while Epirus lay to the northwest. Epirus stretched from the Ambracian Gulf in the south to the Ceraunian mountains and the Aoos river in the north, and consisted of Chaonia (north), Molossia (center), and Thesprotia (south). In the northeast corner was Macedonia,[22] originally consisting Lower Macedonia and its regions, such as Elimeia, Pieria, and Orestis. Around the time of Alexander I of Macedon, the Argead kings of Macedon started to expand into Upper Macedonia, lands inhabited by independent Macedonian tribes like the Lyncestae and the Elmiotae and to the West, beyond the Axius river, into Eordaia, Bottiaea, Mygdonia, and Almopia, regions settled by Thracian tribes.[23] To the north of Macedonia lay various non-Greek peoples such as the Paeonians due north, the Thracians to the northeast, and the Illyrians, with whom the Macedonians were frequently in conflict, to the northwest. Chalcidice was settled early on by southern Greek colonists and was considered part of the Greek world, while from the late 2nd millennium BC substantial Greek settlement also occurred on the eastern shores of the Aegean, in Anatolia.

The Israelites be an ancient Semitic-speaking people of the Ancient Near East who inhabit part of Canaan during the tribal and monarchic periods( 15th to 6th centuries BC),[ 18][ 19][ 20][ 21][ 22] and live in the region in smaller numbers after the fall of the monarchy. The name Israel first appear c. 1209 BC, at the end of the Late Bronze Age and the very beginning of the Iron Age, on the Merneptah Stele raise by the Egyptian Pharaoh Merneptah.

The Antigonid Kingdom become involve in a war with the Roman Republic in the late 3rd century. Although the First Macedonian War be inconclusive, the Romans, in typical fashion, continue to make war on Macedon until it be completely absorb into the Roman Republic( by 149 BC). In the east the unwieldy Seleucid Empire gradually disintegrate, although a rump survive until 64 BC, whilst the Ptolemaic Kingdom continue in Egypt until 30 BC, when it too be conquer by the Romans. The Aetolian league grow wary of Roman involvement in Greece, and side with the Seleucids in the Roman-Syrian War; when the Romans be victorious, the league be effectively absorb into the Republic. Although the Achaean league outlast both the Aetolian league and Macedon, it be also soon defeat and absorb by the Romans in 146 BC, bring an end to the independence of all of Greece.

In industrial cities local experts and reformers, especially after 1890, take the lead in identify environmental degradation and pollution, and initiate grass-roots movements to demand and achieve reforms.[ 114] Typically the highest priority go to water and air pollution. The Coal Smoke Abatement Society be form in Britain in 1898 make it one of the oldest environmental NGOs. It be found by artist Sir William Blake Richmond, frustrate with the pall cast by coal smoke. Although there be earlier pieces of legislation, the Public Health Act 1875 require all furnaces and fireplaces to consume their own smoke. It also provide for sanctions against factories that emit large amounts of black smoke. The provisions of this law be extend in 1926 with the Smoke Abatement Act to include other emissions, such as soot, ash and gritty particles and to empower local authorities to impose their own regulations.[ 115]

The postmodern stage of military technology emerged in the 1940s, And one with recognition thanks to the high priority given during the war to scientific and engineering research and development regarding nuclear weapons, radar, jet engines, proximity fuses, advanced submarines, aircraft carriers, and other weapons. The high-priority continues into the 21st century.[19] It involves the military application of advanced scientific research regarding nuclear weapons, jet engines, ballistic and guided missiles, radar, biological warfare, and the use of electronics, computers and software.[20][21]

During the Industrial Revolution an intellectual and artistic hostility towards the new industrialisation develop, associate with the Romantic movement. Romanticism revere the traditionalism of rural life and recoil against the upheavals cause by industrialization, urbanization and the wretchedness of the working classes.[ 138] Its major exponents in English include the artist and poet William Blake and poets William Wordsworth, Samuel Taylor Coleridge, John Keats, Lord Byron and Percy Bysshe Shelley. The movement stress the importance of `` nature'' in art and language, in contrast to `` monstrous'' machines and factories; the `` Dark satanic mills'' of Blake's poem `` And do those feet in ancient time''. Mary Shelley's novel Frankenstein reflect concerns that scientific progress might be two-edged. French Romanticism likewise be highly critical of industry.[ 139]

The tensions between colonial countries in Europe, indigenous peoples, and escape slaves shape South America from the 16th through the 19th centuries. With the revolution for independence from the Spanish crown achieve during the 19th century, South America underwent yet more social and political changes. These have include nation building projects, absorb waves of immigration from Europe in the late 19th and 20th centuries, deal with increased international trade, colonization of hinterlands, and wars about territory ownership and power balance. During this period there have also be reorganization of Indian rights and duties, subjugation of Indians live in the states' frontiers, that last until the early 1900s; liberal-conservative conflicts among the ruling classes, and major demographic and environmental changes accompany development of sensitive habitats.

In 2011 archaeologists from Italy, the United States, and Egypt excavate a dried-up lagoon know as Mersa Gawasis have unearth traces of an ancient harbor that once launch early voyages like Hatshepsut's Punt expedition onto the open ocean.[ 197] Some of the site's most evocative evidence for the ancient Egyptians' seafaring prowess include large ship timbers and hundreds of feet of ropes, make from papyrus, coil in huge bundles.[ 197] And in 2013 a team of Franco-Egyptian archaeologists discover what be believe to be the world's oldest port, date back about 4500 years, from the time of King Cheops on the Red Sea coast near Wadi el-Jarf( about 110 miles south of Suez).[ 198]

The Land of Punt, also called Pwenet, or Pwene[158] by the ancient Egyptians, was a trading partner known for producing and exporting gold, aromatic resins, African blackwood, ebony, ivory, slaves and wild animals.[159] Information about Punt has been found in ancient Egyptian records of trade missions to this region. The exact location of Punt remains a mystery. The mainstream view is that Punt was located to the south-east of Egypt, most likely on the coast of the Horn of Africa. The earliest recorded Egyptian expedition to Punt was organized by Pharaoh Sahure of the Fifth Dynasty (25th century BC) although gold from Punt is recorded as having been in Egypt in the time of king Khufu of the Fourth Dynasty of Egypt.[160] Subsequently, there were more expeditions to Punt in the Sixth Dynasty of Egypt, the Eleventh dynasty of Egypt, the Twelfth dynasty of Egypt and the Eighteenth dynasty of Egypt. In the Twelfth dynasty of Egypt, trade with Punt was celebrated in popular literature in "Tale of the Shipwrecked Sailor".
Data have show that overall, technology create more jobs than it destroy even in the short run.[ 15]

The earliest recorded metal employed by humans seems to be gold which can be found free or "native". Small amounts of natural gold have been found in Spanish caves used during the late Paleolithic period, c. 40,000 BC.[2]

The Badari was followed by the Amratian (Naqada I) and Gerzeh (Naqada II) cultures,[13] which brought a number of technological improvements. As early as the Naqada I Period, predynastic Egyptians imported obsidian from Ethiopia, used to shape blades and other objects from flakes.[14] In Naqada II times, early evidence exists of contact with the Near East, particularly Canaan and the Byblos coast.[15] Over a period of about 1,000 years, the Naqada culture developed from a few small farming communities into a powerful civilization whose leaders were in complete control of the people and resources of the Nile valley.[16] Establishing a power center at Hierakonpolis, and later at Abydos, Naqada III leaders expanded their control of Egypt northwards along the Nile.[17] They also traded with Nubia to the south, the oases of the western desert to the west, and the cultures of the eastern Mediterranean and Near East to the east.[17] Royal Nubian burials at Qustul produced artifacts bearing the oldest-known examples of Egyptian dynastic symbols, such as the white crown of Egypt and falcon.[18][19]

During the 11th century, developments in philosophy and theology led to increased intellectual activity. There was debate between the realists and the nominalists over the concept of "universals". Philosophical discourse was stimulated by the rediscovery of Aristotle and his emphasis on empiricism and rationalism. Scholars such as Peter Abelard (d. 1142) and Peter Lombard (d. 1164) introduced Aristotelian logic into theology. In the late 11th and early 12th centuries cathedral schools spread throughout Western Europe, signalling the shift of learning from monasteries to cathedrals and towns.[218] Cathedral schools were in turn replaced by the universities established in major European cities.[219] Philosophy and theology fused in scholasticism, an attempt by 12th- and 13th-century scholars to reconcile authoritative texts, most notably Aristotle and the Bible. This movement tried to employ a systemic approach to truth and reason[220] and culminated in the thought of Thomas Aquinas (d. 1274), who wrote the Summa Theologica, or Summary of Theology.[221]

Towards the end of Oldowan in Africa a new species appear over the range of Homo habilis: Homo erectus. The earliest `` unambiguous'' evidence be a whole cranium, KNM-ER 3733( a find identifier) from Koobi Fora in Kenya, date to 1.78 mya.[ 30] An early skull fragment, KNM-ER 2598, date to 1.9 mya, be consider a good candidate also.[ 31] Transitions in paleoanthropology be always hard to find, if not impossible, but base on the `` long-legged'' limb morphology share by H. habilis and H. rudolfensis in East Africa, an evolution from one of those two have be suggest.[ 32]

In Britain, there be but three small hospitals after 1550. Pelling and Webster estimate that in London in the 1580 to 1600 period, out of a population of nearly 200,000 people, there be about 500 medical practitioners. Nurses and midwives be not include. There be about 50 physicians, 100 license surgeons, 100 apothecaries, and 250 additional unlicensed practitioners. In the last category about 25% be women.[ 80] All across Britain—and indeed all of the world—the vast majority of the people in city, town or countryside depend for medical care on local amateurs with no professional training but with a reputation as wise healers who could diagnose problems and advise sick people what to do—and perhaps set broken bones, pull a tooth, give some traditional herbs or brews or perform a little magic to cure what ail them.
By the end of the Bronze Age large states, which be often call empires, have arise in Egypt, China, Anatolia( the Hittites) and Mesopotamia, all of them literate.

The ancient Egyptians place a great value on hygiene and appearance. Most bath in the Nile and use a pasty soap make from animal fat and chalk. Men shave their entire bodies for cleanliness; perfumes and aromatic ointments cover bad odors and soothe skin.[ 147] Clothing be make from simple linen sheets that be bleach white, and both men and women of the upper classes wear wigs, jewelry, and cosmetics. Children go without clothing until maturity, at about age 12, and at this age males be circumcise and have their heads shave. Mothers be responsible for take care of the children, while the father provide the family's income.[ 148]

At the end of the 19th century, physics have evolve to the point at which classical mechanics could cope with highly complex problems involve macroscopic situations; thermodynamics and kinetic theory be well establish; geometrical and physical optics could be understand in terms of electromagnetic waves; and the conservation laws for energy and momentum( and mass) be widely accept. So profound be these and other developments that it be generally accept that all the important laws of physics have be discover and that, henceforth, research would be concern with clear up minor problems and particularly with improvements of method and measurement. However, around 1900 serious doubts arise about the completeness of the classical theories—the triumph of Maxwell's theories, for example, be undermine by inadequacies that have already begin to appear—and their inability to explain certain physical phenomena, such as the energy distribution in blackbody radiation and the photoelectric effect, while some of the theoretical formulations lead to paradoxes when push to the limit. Prominent physicists such as Hendrik Lorentz, Emil Cohn, Ernst Wiechert and Wilhelm Wien believe that some modification of Maxwell's equations might provide the basis for all physical laws. These shortcomings of classical physics be never to be resolve and new ideas be require. At the beginning of the 20th century a major revolution shake the world of physics, which lead to a new era, generally refer to as modern physics.[ 44]

In the United States, these changes brought destruction to many film companies, the Vitagraph company being an exception. Film production began to shift to Los Angeles during World War I. The Universal Film Manufacturing Company was formed in 1912 as an umbrella company. New entrants included the Jesse Lasky Feature Play Company, and Famous Players, both formed in 1913, and later amalgamated into Famous Players-Lasky. The biggest success of these years was David Wark Griffith's The Birth of a Nation (1915). Griffith followed this up with the even bigger Intolerance (1916), but, due to the high quality of film produced in the US, the market for their films was high.

Numerous states claimed descent from the Lunda. The Imbangala of inland Angola claimed descent from a founder, Kinguri, brother of Queen Rweej, who could not tolerate the rule of mulopwe Tshibunda. Kinguri became the title of kings of states founded by Queen Rweej's brother. The Luena (Lwena) and Lozi (Luyani) in Zambia also claim descent from Kinguri. During the 17th century, a Lunda chief and warrior called Mwata Kazembe set up an Eastern Lunda kingdom in the valley of the Luapula River. The Lunda's western expansion also saw claims of descent by the Yaka and the Pende. The Lunda linked Central Africa with the western coast trade. The kingdom of Lunda came to an end in the 19th century when it was invaded by the Chokwe, who were armed with guns.[78][79]

The indigenous people in what is now California and the Pacific Northwest practiced various forms of forest gardening and fire-stick farming in the forests, grasslands, mixed woodlands, and wetlands, ensuring that desired food and medicine plants continued to be available. The natives controlled fire on a regional scale to create a low-intensity fire ecology which prevented larger, catastrophic fires and sustained a low-density agriculture in loose rotation; a sort of "wild" permaculture.[75][76][77][78]

The most celebrated discoveries of Scottish chemist William Ramsay be make in inorganic chemistry. Ramsay be intrigue by the British physicist John Strutt, 3rd Baron Rayleigh's 1892 discovery that the atomic weight of nitrogen find in chemical compounds be lower than that of nitrogen find in the atmosphere. He ascribe this discrepancy to a light gas include in chemical compounds of nitrogen, while Ramsay suspect a hitherto undiscovered heavy gas in atmospheric nitrogen. Using two different methods to remove all know gases from air, Ramsay and Lord Rayleigh be able to announce in 1894 that they have find a monatomic, chemically inert gaseous element that constitute nearly 1 percent of the atmosphere; they name it argon.

The Bengal school of art be an influential style of art that flourish in India during the British Raj in the early 20th century. It be associate with Indian nationalism, but be also promote and support by many British arts administrators.

The first woman mathematician record by history be Hypatia of Alexandria( AD 350–415). She succeed her father as Librarian at the Great Library and write many works on applied mathematics. Because of a political dispute, the Christian community in Alexandria have her stripped publicly and execute.[ 79]

Northern China fragment into a series of independent kingdoms, most of which be found by Xiongnu, Xianbei, Jie, Di and Qiang rulers. These non-Han peoples be ancestors of the Turks, Mongols, and Tibetans. Many have, to some extent, be `` sinicized'' long before their ascent to power. In fact, some of them, notably the Qiang and the Xiongnu, have already be allow to live in the frontier regions within the Great Wall since late Han times. During the period of the Sixteen Kingdoms, warfare ravage the north and prompt large-scale Han Chinese migration south to the Yangtze Basin and Delta.
In 1481 the recently crown João II decide to build São Jorge da Mina factory. In 1482 the Congo River be explore by Diogo Cão,[ 56] who in 1486 continue to Cape Cross( modern Namibia).

Other landmark publications were Voltaire's Dictionnaire philosophique (Philosophical Dictionary; 1764) and Letters on the English (1733); Rousseau's Discourse on Inequality (1754) and The Social Contract (1762); Adam Smith's The Wealth of Nations (1776); and Montesquieu's Spirit of the Laws (1748). The ideas of the Enlightenment played a major role in inspiring the French Revolution, which began in 1789. After the Revolution, the Enlightenment was followed by an opposing intellectual movement known as Romanticism.

The beginnings of the Roman imperial decline seem less serious in North Africa than elsewhere. However, uprisings do take place. In 238 CE, landowners rebel unsuccessfully against imperial fiscal policies. Sporadic tribal revolts in the Mauretanian mountains follow from 253 to 288, during the Crisis of the Third Century. The towns also suffer economic difficulties, and building activity almost cease.[ citation need]

Predynastic Egyptians of the 5th millennium BC pictorially represented geometric designs. It has been claimed that megalithic monuments in England and Scotland, dating from the 3rd millennium BC, incorporate geometric ideas such as circles, ellipses, and Pythagorean triples in their design.[17] All of the above are disputed however, and the currently oldest undisputed mathematical documents are from Babylonian and dynastic Egyptian sources.

The most important film-producing country in Northern Europe up until the First World War was Denmark. The Nordisk company was set up there in 1906 by Ole Olsen, a fairground showman, and after a brief period imitating the successes of French and British filmmakers, in 1907 he produced 67 films, most directed by Viggo Larsen, with sensational subjects like Den hvide Slavinde (The White Slave), Isbjørnenjagt (Polar Bear Hunt) and Løvejagten (The Lion Hunt). By 1910, new smaller Danish companies began joining the business, and besides making more films about the white slave trade, they contributed other new subjects. The most important of these finds was Asta Nielsen in Afgrunden (The Abyss), directed by Urban Gad for Kosmorama, This combined the circus, sex, jealousy and murder, all put over with great conviction, and pushed the other Danish filmmakers further in this direction. By 1912, the Danish film companies were multiplying rapidly.
At elections hold in late 1975, Malcolm Fraser and the Coalition be elect in a landslide victory.

The above `` history of economics'' reflect modern economic textbooks and this mean that the last stage of a science be represent as the culmination of its history( Kuhn, 1962). The `` invisible hand'' mention in a lost page in the middle of a chapter in the middle of the to `` Wealth of Nations'', 1776, advances as Smith's central message.[ clarification need] It be play down that this `` invisible hand'' act only `` frequently'' and that it be `` no part of his[ the individual's] intentions'' because competition lead to lower prices by imitate `` his'' invention. That this `` invisible hand'' prefers `` the support of domestic to foreign industry'' be cleansed—often without indication that part of the citation be truncate.[ 117] The opening passage of the `` Wealth'' contain Smith's message be never mention as it can not be integrate into modern theory: `` Wealth'' depend on the division of labour which change with market volume and on the proportion of productive to Unproductive labor.

In 1883, Svante Arrhenius develop an ion theory to explain conductivity in electrolytes.[ 82] In 1884, Jacobus Henricus van't Hoff publish Études de Dynamique chimique( Studies in Dynamic Chemistry), a seminal study on chemical kinetics.[ 83] In this work, van't Hoff enter for the first time the field of physical chemistry. Of great importance be his development of the general thermodynamic relationship between the heat of conversion and the displacement of the equilibrium as a result of temperature variation. At constant volume, the equilibrium in a system will tend to shift in such a direction as to oppose the temperature change which be impose upon the system. Thus, lower the temperature results in heat development while increase the temperature results in heat absorption. This principle of mobile equilibrium be subsequently( 1885) put in a general form by Henry Louis Le Chatelier, who extend the principle to include compensation, by change of volume, for impose pressure changes. The van't Hoff-Le Chatelier principle, or simply Le Chatelier's principle, explain the response of dynamic chemical equilibria to external stresses.[ 84]

The change in the social relationship of the factory worker compared to farmers and cottagers was viewed unfavourably by Karl Marx, however, he recognized the increase in productivity made possible by technology.[76]

The Industrial Revolution be a period in the late 18th century and early 19th century when major changes in agriculture, manufacturing, and transport affect socioeconomic and cultural conditions in Britain and subsequently spread throughout Europe and North America and eventually the world, a process that continue as industrialisation. Technological advancements, most notably the invention of the steam engine by Scottish engineer James Watt, be major catalysts in the industrialisation of Britain and, later, the wider world. It start in England and Scotland in the mid-18th century with the mechanisation of the textile industries, the development of iron-making techniques and the increase use of refined coal. Trade expansion be enable by the introduction of canals, improve roads and railways. The introduction of steam power( fuel primarily by coal) and powered machinery( mainly in textile manufacturing) underpin the dramatic increases in production capacity.[ 70] The development of all-metal machine tools in the first two decades of the 19th century facilitate the manufacture of more production machines for manufacturing in other industries. The effects spread throughout Western Europe and North America during the 19th century, eventually affect most of the world. The impact of this change on society be enormous.[ 71]

The first five Governors of New South Wales realise the urgent need to encourage free settlers, but the British government remain largely indifferent. As early as 1790, Governor Arthur Phillip write: `` Your lordship will see by my ... letters the little progress we have be able to make in cultivate the lands ... At present this settlement only afford one person that I can employ in cultivate the lands ...''[ 151] It be not until the 1820s that numbers of free settlers begin to arrive and government schemes begin to be introduce to encourage free settlers. Philanthropists Caroline Chisholm and John Dunmore Lang develop their own migration schemes. Land grants of crown land be make by Governors, and settlement schemes such as those of Edward Gibbon Wakefield carry some weight in encourage migrants to make the long voyage to Australia, as oppose to the United States or Canada.[ 152]

Interest in the environment create by the American Dust Bowl produce a flurry of calls in 1935 for ecology to take a look at practical issues. Pioneering ecologist C. C. Adams want to return human ecology to the science.[ 70] Frederic E. Clements, the dominant plant ecologist of the day, review land use issues lead to the Dust Bowl in terms of his ideas on plant succession and climax.[ 71] Paul Sears reach a wide audience with his book, Deserts on the March.[ 72] World War II, perhaps, cause the issue to be put aside.

The discovery and description of new species and the collection of specimens become a passion of scientific gentlemen and a lucrative enterprise for entrepreneurs; many naturalists travel the globe in search of scientific knowledge and adventure.[ 29]

In 1974, Whitlam select John Kerr, a former member of the Labor Party and preside Chief Justice of New South Wales to serve as Governor-General. The Whitlam Government be re-elected with a decreased majority in the lower house in the 1974 Election. In 1974–75 the government think about borrow US$ 4 billion in foreign loans. Minister Rex Connor conduct secret discussions with a loan broker from Pakistan, and the Treasurer, Jim Cairns, mislead parliament over the issue.[ 407] Arguing the government be incompetent follow the Loans Affair, the opposition Liberal-Country Party Coalition delay passage of the government's money bills in the Senate, until the government would promise a new election. Whitlam refuse, Malcolm Fraser, leader of the Opposition insist. The deadlock end when the Whitlam government be dismiss by the Governor-General, John Kerr on 11 November 1975 and Fraser be instal as caretaker Prime Minister, pending an election. The `` reserve powers'' grant to the Governor-General by the Australian Constitution, have allow an elected government to be dismiss without warn by a representative of the Monarch.[ 408]

Many other theories of scientific change have be propose over the years with various changes of emphasis and implications. In general, though, most float somewhere between these three models for change in scientific theory, the connection between theory and truth, and the nature of scientific progress.

Ancient Egypt developed over at least three and a half millennia. It began with the incipient unification of Nile Valley polities around 3500 BC and is conventionally thought to have ended in 30 BC when the early Roman Empire conquered and absorbed Ptolemaic Egypt as a province. (Though this last did not represent the first period of foreign domination, the Roman period was to witness a marked, if gradual transformation in the political and religious life of the Nile Valley, effectively marking the termination of independent civilisational development).

US Navy Rear Admiral Richard Evelyn Byrd led five expeditions to Antarctica during the 1930s, 1940s, and 1950s. He overflew the South Pole with pilot Bernt Balchen on November 28 and 29, 1929, to match his overflight of the North Pole in 1926. Byrd's explorations had science as a major objective and extensively used the aircraft to explore the continent.

After the success of the overthrow of the Qing Dynasty, Sun Yat-sen be declare President, but Sun be force to turn power over to Yuan Shikai, who command the New Army and be Prime Minister under the Qing government, as part of the agreement to let the last Qing monarch abdicate( a decision Sun would later regret). Over the next few years, Yuan proceed to abolish the national and provincial assemblies, and declare himself emperor in late 1915. Yuan's imperial ambitions be fiercely oppose by his subordinates; face with the prospect of rebellion, he abdicate in March 1916, and die in June of that year.

Early Vedic society is described in the Rigveda, the oldest Vedic text, believed to have been compiled during 2nd millennium BCE,[82][83] in the northwestern region of the Indian subcontinent.[84] At this time, Aryan society consisted of largely tribal and pastoral groups, distinct from the Harappan urbanisation which had been abandoned.[85] The early Indo-Aryan presence probably corresponds, in part, to the Ochre Coloured Pottery culture in archaeological contexts.[86][87]

The ancestors of today's American Indigenous peoples were the Paleo-Indians; they were hunter-gatherers who migrated into North America. The most popular theory asserts that migrants came to the Americas via Beringia, the land mass now covered by the cold ocean waters in the Bering Strait. Small lithic stage peoples followed megafauna like bison, mammoth (now extinct), and caribou, thus gaining the modern nickname "big-game hunters." Groups of people may also have traveled into North America on shelf or sheet ice along the northern Pacific coast.

In all, the Renaissance could be viewed as an attempt by intellectuals to study and improve the secular and worldly, both through the revival of ideas from antiquity, and through novel approaches to thought—the immediate past being too "Gothic" in language, thought and sensibility.

On the eve of the Industrial Revolution, spin and weave be do in households, for domestic consumption and as a cottage industry under the putting-out system. Occasionally the work be do in the workshop of a master weaver. Under the putting-out system, home-based workers produce under contract to merchant sellers, who often supply the raw materials. In the off season the women, typically farmers' wives, do the spinning and the men do the weaving. Using the spinning wheel, it take anywhere from four to eight spinners to supply one hand loom weaver.[ 22][ 29][ 30] :823 The fly shuttle patent in 1733 by John Kay, with a number of subsequent improvements include an important one in 1747, double the output of a weaver, worsen the imbalance between spin and weave. It become widely use around Lancashire after 1760 when John's son, Robert, invent the drop box.[ 30] :821–22

Forms of sacred music which develop during the late 13th century include the motet, conductus, discant, and clausulae. One unusual development be the Geisslerlieder, the music of wander bands of flagellants during two periods: the middle of the 13th century( until they be suppress by the Church); and the period during and immediately follow the Black Death, around 1350, when their activities be vividly record and well-documented with notated music. Their music mixed folk song styles with penitential or apocalyptic texts. The 14th century in European music history be dominate by the style of the ars nova, which by convention be group with the medieval era in music, even though it have much in common with early Renaissance ideals and aesthetics. Much of the survive music of the time be secular, and tend to use the formes fixes: the ballade, the virelai, the lai, the rondeau, which correspond to poetic forms of the same names. Most pieces in these forms be for one to three voices, likely with instrumental accompaniment: famous composers include Guillaume de Machaut and Francesco Landini.

The first Ottoman constitutional experiment ended soon after it began, however, when the autocratic Sultan Abdul Hamid II abolished the parliament and the constitution in favor of personal rule. Abdul Hamid ruled by decree for the next 30 years, stirring democratic resentment towards his rule. The reform movement known as the Young Turks emerged in the 1890s against Abdul Hamid's rule, which included massacres against minorities. The Young Turks seized power in the 1908 Young Turk Revolution and established the Second Constitutional Era, leading to a pluralist and multiparty elections in the Empire for the first time in 1908. The Young Turks split into two parties, the pro-German and pro-centralization Committee of Union and Progress and the pro-British and pro-decentralization Freedom and Accord Party. The former was led by an ambitious pair of army officers, Ismail Enver Bey (later Pasha) and Ahmed Cemal Pasha, and a radical lawyer, Mehmed Talaat Bey (later Pasha). After a power struggle between the two parties of Young Turks, the Committee emerged victorious and became a ruling junta, with Talaat as Grand Vizier and Enver as War Minister, and established a German-funded modernisation program across the Empire.[16]

In the three-circles model, countries such as Poland, China, Brazil, Germany, Japan, Indonesia, Egypt, and other countries where English be teach as a foreign language make up the `` expanding circle''.[ 81] The distinctions between English as a first language, as a second language, and as a foreign language be often debatable and may change in particular countries over time.[ 80] For example, in the Netherlands and some other countries of Europe, knowledge of English as a second language be nearly universal, with over 80 percent of the population able to use it,[ 82] and thus English be routinely use to communicate with foreigners and often in higher education. In these countries, although English be not use for government business, the widespread use of English in these countries put them at the boundary between the `` outer circle'' and `` expand circle''. English be unusual among world languages in how many of its users be not native speakers but speakers of English as a second or foreign language.[ 83] Many users of English in the expand circle use it to communicate with other people from the expand circle, so that interaction with native speakers of English play no part in their decision to use English.[ 84] Non-native varieties of English be widely use for international communication, and speakers of one such variety often encounter features of other varieties.[ 85] Very often today a conversation in English anywhere in the world may include no native speakers of English at all, even while include speakers from several different countries.[ 86]

In the 9th century, the Persian mathematician Muḥammad ibn Mūsā al-Khwārizmī write several important books on the Hindu–Arabic numerals and on methods for solve equations. His book On the Calculation with Hindu Numerals, write about 825, along with the work of Al-Kindi, be instrumental in spread Indian mathematics and Indian numerals to the West. The word algorithm be derive from the Latinization of his name, Algoritmi, and the word algebra from the title of one of his works, Al-Kitāb al-mukhtaṣar fī hīsāb al-ğabr wa’l-muqābala( The Compendious Book on Calculation by Completion and Balancing). He give an exhaustive explanation for the algebraic solution of quadratic equations with positive roots,[ 111] and he be the first to teach algebra in an elementary form and for its own sake.[ 112] He also discuss the fundamental method of `` reduction'' and `` balancing'', refer to the transposition of subtracted terms to the other side of an equation, that be, the cancellation of like terms on opposite sides of the equation. This be the operation which al-Khwārizmī originally describe as al-jabr.[ 113] His algebra be also no longer concerned `` with a series of problems to be resolve, but an exposition which start with primitive terms in which the combinations must give all possible prototypes for equations, which henceforward explicitly constitute the true object of study.'' He also study an equation for its own sake and `` in a generic manner, insofar as it do not simply emerge in the course of solve a problem, but be specifically call on to define an infinite class of problems. ``[ 114]

During this period the Antarctic continent became the focus of an international effort that resulted in intensive scientific and geographical exploration and in which 17 major Antarctic expeditions were launched from ten countries.[14]

The Cold War begin in the mid-1940s and last into the early 1990s. Throughout this period, the conflict be express through military coalitions, espionage, weapons development, invasions, propaganda, and competitive technological development. The conflict include costly defense spending, a massive conventional and nuclear arms race, and numerous proxy wars; the two superpowers never fight one another directly.

Pax Americana be an appellation apply to the historical concept of relative liberal peace in the Western world, result from the preponderance of power enjoy by the United States of America start around the start of the 20th century. Although the term find its primary utility in the latter half of the 20th century, it have be use in various places and eras. Its modern connotations concern the peace establish after the end of World War II in 1945.

This open a new research field in chemistry, and by the end of the 19th century, scientists be able to synthesize hundreds of organic compounds. The most important among them be mauve, magenta, and other synthetic dyes, as well as the widely use drug aspirin. The discovery of the artificial synthesis of urea contribute greatly to the theory of isomerism, as the empirical chemical formulas for urea and ammonium cyanate be identical( see Wöhler synthesis). In 1832, Friedrich Wöhler and Justus von Liebig discover and explain functional groups and radicals in relation to organic chemistry, as well as first synthesize benzaldehyde. Liebig, a German chemist, make major contributions to agricultural and biological chemistry, and work on the organization of organic chemistry. Liebig be consider the `` father of the fertilizer industry'' for his discovery of nitrogen as an essential plant nutrient, and his formulation of the Law of the Minimum which describe the effect of individual nutrients on crops.

English, like the other insular Germanic languages, Icelandic and Faroese, developed independently of the continental Germanic languages and their influences. English is thus not mutually intelligible with any continental Germanic language, differing in vocabulary, syntax, and phonology, although some, such as Dutch, do show strong affinities with English, especially with its earlier stages.[19]

Muslim traders—mainly descendants of Arab sailors from Yemen and Oman—dominated maritime routes throughout the Indian Ocean, tapping source regions in the Far East and shipping for trading emporiums in India, mainly Kozhikode, westward to Ormus in the Persian Gulf and Jeddah in the Red Sea. From there, overland routes led to the Mediterranean coasts. Venetian merchants distributed the goods through Europe until the rise of the Ottoman Empire, that eventually led to the fall of Constantinople in 1453, barring Europeans from important combined-land-sea routes.[33][34]

In the Bohr model, however, electrons orbit the nucleus in orbits that have a set size and energy- the energy levels be say to be quantize, which mean that only certain orbits with certain radii be allow; orbits in between simply do n't exist. The energy of the orbit be relate to its size- that be, the lowest energy be find in the smallest orbit. Bohr also postulate that electromagnetic radiation be absorb or emit when an electron moves from one orbit to another. Because only certain electron orbits be permit, the emission of light accompany a jump of an electron from an excited energy state to ground state produce a unique emission spectrum for each element.

In the old Persian architecture, semi-circular and oval-shaped vaults were of great interest, leading Safavi architects to display their extraordinary skills in making massive domes. In the words of D. Huff, a German archaeologist, the dome is the dominant element in Persian architecture. Domes can be seen frequently in the structure of bazaars and mosques, particularly during the Safavi period in Isfahan. Iranian domes are distinguished for their height, proportion of elements, beauty of form, and roundness of the dome stem. The outer surfaces of the domes are mostly mosaic faced, and create a magical view. Safavi Isfahan tried to achieve grandeur in scale (Isfahan's Naghsh-i Jahan Square is the 6th largest square worldwide) knowledge about building tall buildings with vast inner spaces. However, the quality of ornaments was decreased in comparison with those of the 14th and 15th centuries.

The recognize founder of empiricism be John Locke who propose in An Essay Concerning Human Understanding( 1689) that the only true knowledge that could be accessible to the human mind be that which be base on experience. He argue that the human mind be create as a tabula rasa, a `` blank tablet,'' upon which sensory impressions be record and build up knowledge through a process of reflection.

The Mughal empire, which was descended from the Mongol Khanate, was bested by the upcoming Maratha Confederacy. All was going well for the Marathas until the British took an interest in the riches of India and the British ended up ruling not just the boundaries of Modern India, but also Pakistan, Burma, Nepal, Bangladesh and some Southern Regions of Afghanistan.

Via the Roman Empire, Greek culture come to be foundational to Western culture in general. The Byzantine Empire inherit Classical Greek culture directly, without Latin intermediation, and the preservation of classical Greek learning in medieval Byzantine tradition further exert strong influence on the Slavs and later on the Islamic Golden Age and the Western European Renaissance. A modern revival of Classical Greek learn take place in the Neoclassicism movement in 18th- and 19th-century Europe and the Americas.

Through warfare, the Iroquois drive several tribes to migrate west to what become know as their historically traditional land west of the Mississippi River. Tribes originate in the Ohio Valley who move west include the Osage, Kaw, Ponca and Omaha people. By the mid-17th century, they have resettle in their historical lands in present-day Kansas, Nebraska, Arkansas and Oklahoma. The Osage war with Caddo-speaking Native Americans, displace them in turn by the mid-18th century and dominate their new historical territories.[ 23]

During the 1960s and 1970s abstract painting continued to develop in America through varied styles. Geometric abstraction, Op art, hard-edge painting, Color Field painting and minimal painting, were some interrelated directions for advanced abstract painting as well as some other new movements. Morris Louis was an important pioneer in advanced Color Field painting, his work can serve as a bridge between abstract expressionism, Color Field painting, and minimal art. Two influential teachers Josef Albers and Hans Hofmann introduced a new generation of American artists to their advanced theories of color and space. Josef Albers is best remembered for his work as an Geometric abstractionist painter and theorist. Most famous of all are the hundreds of paintings and prints that make up the series Homage to the Square, (see gallery). In this rigorous series, begun in 1949, Albers explored chromatic interactions with flat colored squares arranged concentrically on the canvas. Albers' theories on art and education were formative for the next generation of artists. His own paintings form the foundation of both hard-edge painting and Op art.

Traces of a Neolithic culture have be allege to be submerge in the Gulf of Khambat in India, radiocarbon date to 7500 BCE.[ 50] Neolithic agricultural cultures spring up in the Indus Valley region around 5000 BCE, in the lower Gangetic valley around 3000 BCE, and in later South India, spread southwards and also northwards into Malwa around 1800 BCE. The first urban civilisation of the region begin with the Indus Valley Civilisation.[ 51]

In 2000, the Clay Mathematics Institute announce the seven Millennium Prize Problems, and in 2003 the Poincaré conjecture be solve by Grigori Perelman( who decline to accept an award, as he be critical of the mathematics establishment).

In 1639 a group of explorers lead by Ivan Moskvitin become the first Russians to reach the Pacific Ocean and to discover the Sea of Okhotsk, have build a winter camp on its shore at the Ulya River mouth. The Cossacks learn from the locals about the large Amur River far to the south. In 1640 they apparently sail south, explore the south-eastern shores of the Okhotsk Sea, perhaps reach the mouth of the Amur River and possibly discover the Shantar Islands on their way back. Based on Moskvitin's account, Kurbat Ivanov draw the first Russian map of the Far East in 1642.

The name of the movement comes from a painting by Kandinsky created in 1903 (see illustration). It is also claimed that the name could have derived from Marc's enthusiasm for horses and Kandinsky's love of the colour blue. For Kandinsky, blue is the colour of spirituality: the darker the blue, the more it awakens human desire for the eternal.

Political science operate on a smaller scale in European universities compare to American ones. Traditionally political studies be handle by law professors or professors of philosophy. American impulses toward behavioralism have make the European Consortium for Political Research( ECPR) be a unifying force. It sponsor several scholarly journals include European Political Science( EPS)( since 2001), European Journal of Political Research( EJPR) and European Political Science Review( EPSR).

For much of the 19th century, production be do in small mills, which be typically water-powered and build to serve local needs. Later, each factory would have its own steam engine and a chimney to give an efficient draft through its boiler.

Knowing that the citizens of Alexandria dislike him and be speak ill of his character, he serve a banquet for its notable citizens, after which his soldiers kill all the guests. From the security of the temple of Sarapis, he then direct an in-discriminant slaughter of Alexandria's people.[ 114][ 115] In 212, he issue the Edict of Caracalla, give full Roman citizenship to all free men live in the Empire, and at the same time raise the inheritance tax, levy only on Roman citizens, to ten percent. A report that a soothsayer have predict that the Praetorian prefect Macrinus and his son be to rule over the empire be dutifully send to Caracalla. But the report fell into the hands of Macrinus, who felt he must act or die. Macrinus conspire to have Caracalla assassinate by one of his soldiers during a pilgrimage to the Temple of the Moon in Carrhae, in 217 AD.

The superpowers develop ballistic missiles to enable them to use nuclear weaponry across great distances. As rocket science develop, the range of missiles increase and intercontinental ballistic missiles( ICBM) be create, which could strike virtually any target on Earth in a timeframe measure in minutes rather than hours or days. In order to cover large distances ballistic missiles be usually launch into sub-orbital spaceflight.
